abstract: Major-Gen. HALLECK's recent order, opening up the ports of Virginia and unloosing the reins from commerce, has acted already on this community like a beneficent Summer shower upon parched vegetation. What gave that order more joyful significance was the fact that it wes distinctly announced as given by command of the President himself.

abstract: To-day being the first Monday of the month, the terms of the courts will begin. The calendars in all the courts are unusually heavy, and quite a number of cases of much public importance stand foremost on the list. It is believed that the somewhat celebrated divorce suit of Strong vs. Strong will be brought on during the present week in the Superior Court. The General Term of the Supreme Court will open to-day in the Court-house, corner of Chambers and Centre streets, firs, floor. It will be held by INGRAHAM, Presiding Justice, and associates BARNARD and CLERKE. During this month there will be only two parts of the Supreme Court Circuit held: Part I. by Justice LEONARD, and Part II. (at No. 73 Duane-street) by a Justice from another district. Justice SUTHERLAND will sit at Special Term and Chambers. The General Term of the Superior Court will be held by Chief Justice ROBERTSON and Justices BARBOUR and MCCUNN. Justice GARVIN will sit at Special Term and Chambers. The Trial Term of Part I. will be held by Justice MONCRIEF, and Part II. by Justice MONELL. In the Court of Common Pleas, Trial Term, Part I. will be held by Judge DALY, Part II. by Judge BRADY, and Judge CARDOZA will sit at Chambers and Special Term.

abstract: Mott, Dr. Valentine, Funeral of
snippet: Mott, Dr. Valentine, Funeral of
lead_paragraph: The last sad rites and funeral services over the remains of Dr. VALENTINE MOTT, whose death we recorded a few days since, took place yesterday afternoon, at the Episcopal Church of the Transfiguration in East Twenty-ninth-street. The ceremonies were witnessed by a large congregation, and the church was densely crowded in every part by the sorrowing relatives of the venerable deceased, and the deeply interested friends sad professional acquaintances of the family.

abstract: The matinee at the German opera on Saturday failed to excite the usual degree of interest. It  was to speak plainly, badly attended. Although we may partly account for this by the fact that the National Academy is now the popular lounging place,  and the sterner fact that Saturday was set aside for the domestic convulsion called moving, there is still another reason.
lead_paragraph: The matinee at the German opera on Saturday failed to excite the usual degree of interest. It was to speak plainly, badly attended. Although we may partly account for this by the fact that the National Academy is now the popular lounging place, and the sterner fact that Saturday was set aside for the domestic convulsion called moving, there is still another reason. The people have had enough of "Martha." That highly respectable work has played its part in every known tongue. There is no longer speech for it, and, respectfully, we think it ought to be dump. Another remark, pertinent to the subject. The Italians can afford to ease off a hard week's work with a light performance on Saturday; but the Germans cannot. In the one case, people go on the strength of reputation; in the other, it is a mere matter of repertoire. To-night, for instance, we are sure the Academy of Music will be crowded to its greatest capacity. BEETHOVEN's only opera, "Fidelio," is to be produced, and every lover of music, whether classically disposed or otherwise, is bound to inform or refresh himself of or with its beauties. The work, we are assured, has been prepared with care, and if it be given with only the same completeness that characterized the performance of "Faust," on Friday last, it will, we doubt not, insure many profitable repetitions. MEYERBEER's opera of the "Huguenots" is in preparation, and will speedily he brought out.

abstract: Play for 1865 commenced; Play Commenced for 1865
snippet: Play for 1865 commenced; Play Commenced for 1865
lead_paragraph: The ball-playing season of 1865 was duly inaugurated during the latter part of last week, and henceforth, until the cold winds of November stop field sports, the invigorating exercises and manly recreations of our Metropolitan ball clubs will be the feature of the out-door sports of the season. Both the base ball and cricket fraternity of New-York and Brooklyn have made ample preparation for a brilliant campaign this season, and the prospects are that both games will flourish to a greater extent this Summer than they have done since the inauguration of the great rebellion.

snippet: Ram Webb; Escape of; Loan; Fall of in England; Loan in Europe, Signers of
lead_paragraph: The rebel ram Webb, which escaped from Red River on the 22d and rushed down the Mississippi at high speed, apparently on a raid against our shipping in that river, has gone the way of nearly all such vessels. She passed New Orleans, hoisted the rebel flag, and in a short time afterward her machinery got out of order, and she was at once deserted and blown up. Some of her crew got back to New-Orleans.

abstract: Chiefs; Importance of Capture of; Importance of Capture
snippet: Chiefs; Importance of Capture of; Importance of Capture
lead_paragraph: We trust that the government will spare no efforts to catch JEFF. DAVIS, and all his lieutenants in treason, not already in its hands. Most of them undoubtedly are in flight for Texas, thence into Mexico. Traversing a belt of country all through which there are very many still attached to them and anxious to facilitate their escape, they have many chances in their favor. Yet it is a ride of a thousand miles to the Mississippi; and this ride must be taken horseback, as all the great lines of railroad are either destroyed or in our possession. The Mississippi itself, if rightly guarded, cannot easily be crossed without observation. With prompt activity on the part of the government, it is not unlikely that the capture can yet be made.

abstract: Booth, the Assassin's, Tomb
snippet: Booth, the Assassin's, Tomb
lead_paragraph: -- We hope the report is true that the government has disposed of the body of the assassin BOOTH in such a way that its resting-place will never be known. The best thing that his relatives can wish for him is that his name and memory may perish forever; and every consideration of good taste and the public interest demands that no encouragement should be given to that morbid public appetite which glorifies great criminals and craves constant memorials of their crimes. The grave of the assassin of the President, if known, would be visited by thousands from curiosity, and would become a celebrated report of sight-seers, whose detestation of the deed would be overborne or modified by that strange wonder which always surrounds acts of desperate hardihood. We trust the secret of BOOTH's sepulchre will never be revealed.

abstract: Order for Reduction of; Now Reducing
snippet: Order for Reduction of; Now Reducing
lead_paragraph: The highly important order issued from the War Department, on Friday last, providing for the reduction of the army and the curtailment of the military expenses of the government, has a profound pervasive and permanent bearing on all the interests of the country. Taken in connection with the comprehensive and liberal proclamation of President JOHNSON, published to-day, making provision for the opening of commercial intercourse with the States and people of the South, it gives proof of the assured and definite advent of the new epoch of peace.

abstract: Rouher, M., Speech in French Senate; the, and American Affairs; Pelletan, M., on United States, in French Chamber
snippet: Rouher, M., Speech in French Senate; the, and American Affairs; Pelletan, M., on United States, in French Chamber
lead_paragraph: Our Paris correspondent, writing so long ago as the 3d of March, announced the probability of an amendment, in which we should feel interested, being moved to the Addrees of the Chamber in answer to the Emperor's Speech. The long interval of two months, and the overshadowing events that have marked that interval, have probably driven the matter almost from public recollection. It is, however, revived to-day in the report (published in another column) which describes a remarkable scene in the Chamber on the 15th ult.

abstract: MISTAKEN FOR BOOTH.--A noteworthy instance of mistaken identity to that of ReV. Mr. DURYEA, of the Dutch Reformed Church of this city, who has just returned from Niagara Falls, and who was mistaken by his fellow-travelers while on his way thither for the assasin BOOTH.
lead_paragraph: MISTAKEN FOR BOOTH. -- A noteworthy instance of mistaken identity to that of ReV. Mr. DURYEA, of the Dutch Reformed Church of this city, who has just returned from Niagara Falls, and who was mistaken by his fellow-travelers while on his way thither for the assasin BOOTH. The reverend gentleman observed, while in a car, that he was narrowly watched, and, aware of his strong resemblance to the published pictures of BOOTH, he at once perceived his situation and was disposed to see what might come of it. He accordingly kept his own counsel, and was closely pursued to a hotel. He there took a room and purposely omitted the registry of his name, thus confirming the suspicions of several gentlemen who had previously been in doubt; and when, at length, he hired a wagon and drove at high speed for Suspension Bridge, there seemed no longer a shadow of doubt, and he was put under arrest. Of course he was able to make his fellow-passengers' error clear, and the apprehension ended with a hearty laugh of all hands.

abstract: Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions Report
snippet: Presbyterian Board of Foreign Missions Report
lead_paragraph: Moving day yesterday proved to be most unpropitious for such unfortunate mortals as were compelied to change their abodes. Many persons differ as to the amount of moving which took place, but it was evident that there was less than on former May Days. This was owing to several causes, the chief one of which was the small number of dwelling-houses erected during the year. For several years past there has been a great scarcity of first-class houses, the increase of building not keeping pace with the augmenting population of the city. During the past year building has been still more limited, owing in great part to the high prices of material and labor. Landlords naturally took, advantage of the great demand for dwellings, and advanced their rents from twenty to thirty per cent., and in many instances still more. The increase was so uniform that tenants found it as profitable to remain and bear the extra burden as to move, pay an equal percentage to a new landlord, and suffer the expense and destruction of furniture incidental to moving. Many changes, however, took place last week in the upper part of the city, so that the full extent of the moving was not apparent yesterday. Such as were unfortunately classed with the migratory body suffered even more than the ordinary vexations and annoyances usually incident to that most unsatisfactory task. The drizzling, chilling rain made everyone fell uncomfortable and ill-natured, including that most amiable class, the carmen, and soaked many of the beds and blankets upon which the weary housewives rested their aching heads and tired bodies last night. Scores of coughs will be one of the legitimate results of moving day this year.

abstract: Paris Press on our Triumphs; London Press on Our Triumphs; European Press and our Opponents
snippet: Paris Press on our Triumphs; London Press on Our Triumphs; European Press and our Opponents
lead_paragraph: The rebel sympathizers in England die harder than the rebels themselves. The high-tory troglodytes, who live in caves, like the Herald and the Standard, fortify themselves with the delusion that the war will now back into the impregnable mountains. The open-air cockneys, like the Post and the Times, have a dizzy apprehension that the war is about over, but are refreshed with the notion that "it will require all the Federal soldiers now in the South to hold the country when they have overrun it," and that the close of the war may be only "the close of the first stage of a political revolution, and the beginning of the real troubles of the North." There is a class of high life, frequenters of the aristocratic clubs, who "consider that the war will drift westward, and that even though Virginia, the Carolinas and Georgia should ultimately join the Atlantic federation, there is a great game yet to be played on the shores of the Gulf and the banks of the Mississippi." This is so stated by the Southern correspondent of the Manchester Guardian, who is TOM TAYLOR, the creator of the character of Lord Dundreary and who doubtless understands the view at Brooks's and the Carlton.

abstract: ILLNESS OF GEN. FITZ HENRY WARREN. -- We regret to hear that Brig.-Gen. FITZ HENRY WARREN, the President of the Military Commission now sitting here, is seriously ill. The fatigue and excitement consequent upon the obsequies of the late President, in connection with a disease contracted in the field, have conspired to prostrate him. It is probable that a few days rest, the attention of Surgeon SWAN and careful nursing will restore him to his previous condition of invalidism.

lead_paragraph: -- Cape Cod. By HENRY D. THOREAU. 12mo. Boston: TICKNOR & FIELDS. The parters composing this work have appeared partially in the Atlantic Monthly. They will be welcome in their present shaps to all who remember them. They testify to the remarkable talent for observation, and graphic power of description possessed by the writer, and in this case, exercised con amore in portraying the peculiarities of a secluded, and, in many respects, remarkable region. Nothing escapes his grasp in animate or inanimate nature; the people and their strange surroundings that color every familiar object with a "sea change," are henceforward known to us with an intimacy that personal experience could scarcely deepen. Mr. THOREAU's friends are doing good service to his memory and to American literature by the collection and preservation of his remains.

abstract: Johannes, Count vs. Fiske; Libel Suit
snippet: Johannes, Count vs. Fiske; Libel Suit
lead_paragraph: George, the Count Joaunes vs. Stephen R Fiske. -- At about 5 o'clock yesterday afternoon the above entitled case was brought on before Mr. Sheriff Kelly and a jury, in the court-room usually occupied by the Court of Common Pleas, Part II. The action was commenced nearly a year ago, in the Superior Court, by George, the Count Joannes, against Stephen R. Fiske, who was then connected with the New-York Leader, to recover the sum of $25,000 damages, alleged to have been sustained by the Count by reason of a libelous article published in the Leader on the 7th of May last. The suit was brought in the Superior Court, the defendant put in no answer, and when it came up before that tribunal in the ordinary manner, it was referred to a Sheriff's jury to assess the damages which had been sustained by the Count, all the allegations in the complaint being admitted by the defendant's not having put in an answer. The only question now was the amount of damages which the Count had sustained, and as the Sheriff charged, it was a part of their duty to look into the evidence and satisfactorily ascertain for themselves whether or not there was any malice in the publication of the alleged libel. The article complained of has been several times published in this journal in connection with the sull, and we refer to it now merely that our readers may see the points in controversy. The Court brought an action in the Common Pleas against the editors of the New-York Tribune, which was tried in February last, for having published substantially the same matter now charged upon the Leader. The result in the court last named, was a verdict for the defendant.

abstract: Bequest to St. Luke's Hospital
snippet: Bequest to St. Luke's Hospital
lead_paragraph: The late Dr. JOHN S. WILEY, of Brooklyn, surgeon in the navy, at his death bequeathed ten thousand dollars to St. Luke's Hospital, in this city, and ten thousand dollars to other charitable institutions. The bequest to St. Luke's was for the benefit of naval officers, in founding and endowing alcoves or wards therein, under the direction of Messrs. Robert B. Minturn, Stephen Cambroling, Wm.C. Bryant, Alfred Pell, Theodore Sedgwick and Commodore Dupont. The above gentlemen, with the exception of Mr. MINTURN, who is in Europe, and Mr. SEDGWICK, deceased, met on the 25th of March, at house of Mr. Mr. ALFRED PELL. A letter from Mr. THOMAS W. OGDEN, Secretary of St. Luke's Hospital, was read acknowledging the receipt of the ten thousand dollars, and inclosing a resolution, adopted by the managers of the hospital, directing that the chief ward in the eastern wing of that institution, about to be erected, be designated and known as the "Wiley Ward." The trustees of the bequest approved the resolution, and recommended that a marble tablet be placed on the walls of the Wiley Ward, bearing this [???]s[???]tion: "The Wiley Ward, JOHN S. WILEY, M.D. beb[???]thed to St. Luke's Hospital ten thousand dollars, in the hope that his brother officers might share the benefits of this institution."
headline: {'main': "The Wiley Bequest to St. Luke's Hospital.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Wiley Bequest to St. Luke's Hospital.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Speech at Loyal League Club, on Reconstruction; Speech to Loyal League Club on Reconstruction; Loyal Letter of
snippet: Speech at Loyal League Club, on Reconstruction; Speech to Loyal League Club on Reconstruction; Loyal Letter of
lead_paragraph: We have the honor to meet here to-night, gentlemen, a distinquisted officer of the United States Army. The first to point out, at the opening of the war, how the negro should be treated he showed the country, to its immense satisfaction, how the rebels shoule be treated during the war; and certainty no one has a better right to express his views as to how that class of our fellow-citizens should be treated now that hostilities have ceased. This club is a private social body, its members bound together by a single principle, devoted loyalty to the government, the only grand principle that we have yet adopted. We have not yet agreed upon any general view of the policy to be pursued in dealing with rebels; of the great question of reconstruction, nor of any of the various questions growing out of the conclusion of the war; and perhaps, we are not yet ready to adopt unanimously any policy upon these questions; but we are ready -- I take it we are always ready -- to listen with becoming deference to the views of a gentleman so eminent and distinguished as he who is our guest to-night. [Applause.]

abstract: The rebel ram Albemarle, which was sunk at Plymouth, N.C., by Lieut. CUSHING, has been raised by some Northern contractors and has reached the Gosport Navy-yard. The cost of raising is about $20,000. Her machinery is in excellent order, and she has sustained but very little damage by the explosion of the torpedo. It is intended to put her in seagoing order and she will probably be sent to New-York to be fitted out as a first-class iron-clad.

abstract: Wainwright, W., Because "World is Played Out."
snippet: Wainwright, W., Because "World is Played Out."
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- The ordinary performances of "Fidello" in this city have been of so interior a character, that it is giving Mr. GROVER, but scanty credit to say that his representation of this fine work last evening was by all odds the best we have ever heard in America. The cast was as complete as possible. It included the following artists: Mme. BERTHA JOHANNSEN, (Leonere;) Mlle. PAULINE CANISSE, (Marcelus;) Mr. JOSEPH HERRMAN, (Rocco;) Mr. FRANZ HIMMER, (Florestan;) Mr. THEODORE HARLEMAN, (Jaquino;) Mr. HEINRICH STRINECKE, (Pizarro,) With a single exception, this distribution could hardly have been bettered, and that exception was so unimportant that we shall not further refer to it. In all healthy respects, the opera was finery rendered. It is a shame that the house, instead of being moderately well attended, was not filled to its greatest capacity. The apathy which prevails on the subject of amusements prevails universally. Our theatres are deserted, and Mr. GROVER, heavily weighted as he is [???] a very large and expensive company, simply [???] the bad fortunes of his neighbors.

lead_paragraph: The report of the Liverpool Cotton Market, which we receive by the Scotia, shows a less marked decline in prices than might have been anticipated. Up to Friday afternoon, the 21st ult., the fall caused by the news of the evacuation of Richmond had not averaged more than 1d. sterling a pound; and about half of this was recovered at the close of Saturday (the 22d), with a "buoyant" market.

abstract: of Washington, Arrested
snippet: of Washington, Arrested
lead_paragraph: NOBLE J. THOMAS, a former well-known resident of Washington, but who has been in the rebel army since the outbreak of the rebellion, was arrested in this city on Friday, by Officer MCELFRESH, of the Fourth Ward, and on Saturday was taken before Justice MILLER, to answer to certain charges preferred against him. THOMAS was a lieutenant of the auxiliary guard of this city under the administration of Mayor BERRET; and he had previous to that time held the position of assistant warden of the penitentiary. At the commencement of the rebellion he left the city and joined the rebel army, and of late has been Captain and Assistant Quartermaster in WISE's battalion. Being connected with LEE's army, he was among those paroled by the terms of surrender at Burkesville, and returned at once to this city. As soon as his presence in the city became known many old charges were revived against him, prominent among which was one that at the commencement of the war, he had acted as a spy and informer, and that he pointed out Union men from this city to the rebel authorities in Alexandria and vicintiy, and thus endeavored to procure their imprisonment and punishment.
headline: {'main': 'Arrest of a Rebel in Washington.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Arrest of a Rebel in Washington.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Trial. The Argument for Defendant
snippet: Trial. The Argument for Defendant
lead_paragraph: The court-martial convened by order of Gen. DIX, for the trial of Mr. B.S. OSBON, charged with furnishing contraband information to the enemy, by publications in the newspapers, met yesterday in pursuance of adjournment. In absence of Gen. WARREN, Brig.-Gen. W.H. MORRIS presided. Ater the reading of the minutes of the several adjournments, by Major BOLLES, Gen. PRATT presented a plea to the charge, which he desired to be substituted in place of one put in on the 10th of April. The plea states that Mr. OSBON is a civilian, belonging neither to the army or the navy, and not amenable to martial law, and ought therefore to be discharged from custody. The plea was admitted nunc per tunc, and Gen. PRATT then submitted an argument, of which the following are the points.

abstract: -A number of pugilists assembled in an old barn near the corner of Gates and Reed avenues, on Monday evening, for the purpose of having a prize-fight. JAMES GILLEN, of New-York, and DENNIS FREEL, of Brooklyn, had the first bout, which lasted for about one hour, resulting in the defeat of GILLEN, who was badly whipped. JAMES RATIGAN and FRANCIS HIGGINS then entered the ring, when the affair was broken up by the police. HIGGINS and GILLEN were arrested, and held to answer.

abstract: Brooklyn, Flato, Fulton-st., $3,000
snippet: Brooklyn, Flato, Fulton-st., $3,000
lead_paragraph: BURGLARIES A[???] [???] OF A PORTION OF THE GOODS. -- The dry goods store of Mr. J. FLATO, No. 223 Fulton-street, was feloniously entered on Monday night, and robbed of silks and other valuable goods, worth nearly $3 000. The entrance was gained through a rear window by boring the bolts out of the shutter and then breaking open the window. Yesterday afternoon two boys at play on the corner of Concord and Washington streets, discovered a portion of the stolen articles, valued at about $500, under a stoop. The articles were brought to the Forty-first Precinct Station-house and identified by the owner.

abstract: England Begged to Keep him
snippet: England Begged to Keep him
lead_paragraph: We see that that intolerable busy-body, Colorado JEWETT, is said to have arrived in Europe on a "special mission" from New-York. We are glad, for a double reason, that he has gone to England -- we get rid of him, and we punish the British. We fervently trust they will continue their faith in his assurances, and invest largely on his advice in Confederate bonds. But if they have any wish to befriend this country, now that it no longer needs even their good wishes, we beg them to keep JEWETT on the other side of the Atlantic. If they will do this, we can afford to forgive them a good deal of their "neutrality." If they send him back, their real hatred of the United States can no longer be doubted.

abstract: MORTAL COMBAT ON SHIPBOARD -- The sailor boarding house keepe's slipped a very drunken crew on board the Neptune, on Monday, and at night they indulged in a free fight on the main deck, and WM. PRICE and THOMAS MULLIGAN stabbed each other in the abdomen, making incisions which, it is believed, must prove mortal. Information of the aff[???]ay having been sent to the First Ward Police-station, Sergt. CHERRY and a number of officers boarded the ship and apprehended ANGUS MCKATENZ, JOHN POWERS,JOHN WHALEN, and JAMES MCDERMOTT, and took them to the Tombs, where they where held for examination by Justice HOGAN. PRICE and MULLIGAN were sent to the New-York Hospital, where Coroner GOVER took their ante-mortem depositions yesterday.

abstract: Lecture on President Lincoln; Douglass, Frederick, Lecture on
snippet: Lecture on President Lincoln; Douglass, Frederick, Lecture on
lead_paragraph: On Monday evening a meeting of colored people was held at Shiloh Church, Prince-street, when a committee of fifteen was appointed to make arrangements for the delivery, by FREDERICK DOUGLASS, of a discourse on the life and death of ABRAHAM LINCOLN. A charge for admission is to be made, and the receipts, over the necessary expenses, are to be given to the Lincoln monument. The proposition was very warmly received, and the money to carry it into effect was promptly supplied by the meeting. The idea prevailed that, though the City Council refused to recognize the colored people as mourners of our late beloved President, they would, nevertheless, demonstrate on this occasion in it and the world that they appreciate his acts and goodness. The meeting also adopted the following resolution:

abstract: Our, The Breaking up of
snippet: Our, The Breaking up of
lead_paragraph: The great volunteer army of the Union is in process of disruption. The old Army of the Potomac has already ceased to exist as a unitary body, and the ranks of its various corps are in process of depletion. The old army of SHERMAN is terminating its long battle march, which began at Atlanta one year ago, by marching into Virginia, where in short time its body will be regularly dissolved. All over the land, -- in the hospitals, at the recruiting rendezvous, and in the camps -- soldiers are receiving honorable discharges from the service in which they have done such noble and effective work. We suppose the month of May will not have passed before our army will be reduced to one-quarter of the strength at which it has been maintained during the last three years.

abstract: Madison-av. Baptist Church vs. Baptist Church in Oliver-st.
snippet: Madison-av. Baptist Church vs. Baptist Church in Oliver-st.
lead_paragraph: The Madison Avenue Baptist Church vs. The Baptist Church in Oliver street. -- This was a controvery between two religious corporations. The Madison-avenue Baptist Church brings ejectment against the Baptist Church in Oliver-street, to recover possession of their church property in Madison-avenue. The congregation of the Oliver-street Church allege, that they should not be ejected, because they say the two corporations or societies, by a majority of their members at regular meetings, agreed that the church or corporation in Madison-avenue should cease to exist, and that an its property should be merged in or conveyed to the corporation of the Oliver-street Church; and that the members of both churches should worship together thereafter in the Madison-avenue Church; and that the Supreme Court, upon the application of the parties, directed an order and transfer to that effect. They further claim to hold the property as mortgagees in possession. The Madison-avenue people allege, in answer to all this, that the proceedings taken by the majority of the two congregations, and the action taken by the Supreme Court thereunder, were insufficient in law, either to dissolve the corporation of the Church in Madison-avenue, or to convey their property, and that the mortgages under which defendants claim to hold possession were not due at the time of the commencement of this action.

abstract: Meeting South with Liberality
snippet: Meeting South with Liberality
lead_paragraph: The people in all parts of the South, heard from since the surrender of LEE, accept the new situation with a good spirit. It is true there is little positive exultation. That could hardly be expected from a proud people, who have been overborne in arms. But there is an acquiesence which is yet more manly -a frank acknowledgement that further opposition is useless, and a readiness to take the oath without reserve. This is the general disposition both in town and country. Of course there are numerous exceptions. In the diversity of human nature, this could not be otherwise. There was never a public feeling yet that was strictly universal. Nor is it of any practical account that this should be so. Very few of the exceptions are found in that class of men who are capable of exercising a public influence; and these few can easily he visited with penalties for the past, and subjected to regulations for the future, that would entirely disable them from all power for mischief. The all-important fact is that the great weight of public sentiment is now on the right side. To keep it there is comparatively easy. The chief concern was once how to get it there, supposing it should obstinately settle on the wrong side. That problem out of the way, the path to reconstruction is open and smooth.
headline: {'main': 'The Present Spirit of the South-Its Auspicious Aspect.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Present Spirit of the South-Its Auspicious Aspect.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Crop, Extortion, History
snippet: Crop, Extortion, History
lead_paragraph: Of all the extraordinary people In this extraordinary country, the dealers in ice are the must noticeable. In the very face of victory, with gold in the forties, with labor comparatively cheap, with expenses of every sord reduced and on the eve of a long and prosperous season, these men deliberately profits from the pockets of their pations, and evince themselves mean in their avarice and unscrupulous in their pecuniosity. From the scriptural days of Solomon, who was accustomed to the best of everything, and who said, "As the cold of snow in the time of harvest, so is a faithful messenger to them that send him," to these days of camp and hospital suffering, and of luxurious living, ice has been a necessity and a prominent article of commerce. With some, ice simply indicates the congelation of a fluid, a crystalline pyramidic prismatic formation, unavoidable in cold latitudes, pleasant for the use of skillful boys, and helpful to the iron-bound cutter or sled; to Solomon and to those of us who are disposed to regard that eccentric monarch as a well-informed and thoroughly cultured person, ice had and has a different significance. Cold water on the table, cooling pillows for the sick, antiseptic layers for meats and fruits, cobblers, juleps and smashes, neat plates of well moulded butter, wines not flat but bright and sparkling; these are the consequence of ice -- ice which gives useful refreshment to the parched lip and the burning brow; which has carried in triumph thousands and tens of thousands of our wounded soldiers from the hospital cot to the cot where they were born; which has eased the fretted brain of the dying, and lightened the sufferings of the sick; which saves annually millions of dollars from waste in this city alone, and which is now being used by the iron hand of monopoly as a lever of avarice and extortion.

abstract: Mr. ADAM KERCHARD appeared and made affidavit that at 9 o'clock on Monday evening, when he was passing through Moore-street, near Pearl, PATRICK FOLEY sprang from a doorway and knocked him to the pavement, and, stealing his carpet-bag, fled. Officer NEALIS, of the First Ward, deposed that he arrested FOLEY, with the carpet-bag in his possession, and Justice HOGAN committed the accused, in default of $1,000 ball.

abstract: The New-Orleans Times of the 25th reports that the steamer Gen. Hodges came out of the Red River on the 23d under flag or truce, for the purpose of negotiating with Col. SPRAGUE, Chief of Staff of Gen. POPE, for the surrender of KIRBY SMITH and his force. Col. SPRAGUE left Cairo on the gunboat Lexington, for the purpose of meeting the Gen. Hodges at the mouth of the Red River, and there can be little doubt that KIRBY SMITH has surrendered his entire force. The terms are those proffered by Gen. GRANT to LEE. The Lexington and Hodges, at last accounts, were anchored at Hog Point, a few miles below the mouth of the Red River.

abstract: International Congress Advised by Gerrit Smith; Advises International Congress
snippet: International Congress Advised by Gerrit Smith; Advises International Congress
lead_paragraph: President JOHNSON is adjured by Mr. GERRIT SMITH to make his presidency memorable, by leading in a great movement for substituting international congresses, hereafter, for the arbitrament of the sword. If this project is practicable and wise to-day, it was the same five years ago. Does Mr. JOHNSON's instructor reckon, at all, what would have been the result as regards the grand question at issue here, if that question had been submitted to the decision of an international congress? If we except the more liberal section of Germany, Switzerland, and perhaps Russia, what vote would have been cast against the "Confederacy" in the whole of the rest of Europe? Should we have held ourselves bound by a judgment which, from the foreign sympathies developed by the rebellion, would have -- all but surely -- been given in favor of an empire founded on slavery?

lead_paragraph: The trials, yesterday, were racy. President ACTON had occasion to reprimand several officers, and two were incontinently dismissed. Of the latter, Officer PATRICK MCGUIRE, of the Second Ward, was one. The complainant was Miss Dr. ELLEN B. HARMAN, of No. 776 Sixth-avenue, and the substance of the complaint is that on the afternoon of the 20th ult. she was walking down Fulton-street, attired in Bloomer costume, and that the officer, instead of protecting her from the unmannerly crowd that were pursuing her, apprehended her, and took her to the Second Ward Police Station. Capt. DE CAMP released her, of course, as soon as the case came, to his knowledge. President ACTON desired the officer to explain his conduct, and that individual remarked that he did not know whether it was man or woman. "Well. Sir," rejoined ACTON, "we want men on the force who know more than you appear to. You will go down stairs at once, get a blank resignation paper, and fill it up."

abstract: Miles, Pliny, American Advocate of Cheap Postage
snippet: Miles, Pliny, American Advocate of Cheap Postage
lead_paragraph: Our London correspondent announces the death, at the Island of Malta, of PLINY MILES, a native of this State, and well known all over the world by his letters and books of travel, and his earnest advocacy in this country of a comprehensive system of postal reform. Mr. Miles was a native of Watertown, N.Y., and was known while quite young for remarkable talents as a school-teacher and miscellaneous writer. Ten or twelve years ago he made a trip in Northern Europe, visiting the slightly out-of the-way region of Iceland. His observations in this strange land of snow and fire were published in a pleasant book of the gossippy sort, which attracted considerable attention. Of late years Mr. MILES devoted his time and talents almost entirely to the improvement of our postal system, with a view (until the breaking out of the war made it for the time impracticable) of achieving his grand idea of one cent postage on half-ounce letters for any distance. He was a plain but forcible writer, depending upon a laborious array of facts, rather than rhetorical effort. In person he was a striking figure -- tall, thin, of nervous-sanguine temperament, wearing a beard that never scraped acquaintance with a razor; a rapid walker, keen observer, talking with wonderful volubility, always cordial, open-hearted, and everywhere welcome for his agreeable social qualities.

abstract: The Assassin; The Reward for; Really an Assassin
snippet: The Assassin; The Reward for; Really an Assassin
lead_paragraph: President JOHNSON, as will be seen, has issued a proclamation announcing that, as appears from evidence in the Bureau of Military Justice, the atrocious murder of the late President, and the attempted assassination of the Secretary of State, were incited, concerted and procured by and between Jefferson Davis, late of Richmond, Jacob Thompson, Clement C. Clay, Beverly Tucker, Geo. N. Sanders, W.C. Cleary and other rebels and traitors harbored in Canada; therefore, to the end that justice may be done, the following rewards are offered and promised for the arrest of said persons, or either of them, within the limits of the United States, so that they can be brought to trial, to wit: For the arrest of Jefferson Davis, one hundred thousand dollars; for the arrest of Clay, Thompson, Sanders and Tucker, twenty-five thousand dollars each; and for the arrest of Cleary, ten thousand dollars. The Provost-Marshal-General of the United States is directed to cause a description of said persons to be published, with the notice of the above rewards.

abstract: Yesterday morning, many gentlemen who in boyhood were pupils in Ward Grammar School No. 13 (No. 14 when under the rule of the old Public School Society,) assembled to greet their venerable and esteemed teacher, Mr. LEONARD HAZELTINE, on the occasion of the thirtieth anniversary of the school. The school-room still bore the mourning emblems which were introduced immediately on receipt of...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning, many gentlemen who in boyhood were pupils in Ward Grammar School No. 13 (No. 14 when under the rule of the old Public School Society,) assembled to greet their venerable and esteemed teacher, Mr. LEONARD HAZELTINE, on the occasion of the thirtieth anniversary of the school. The school-room still bore the mourning emblems which were introduced immediately on receipt of the awful tidings which reached us from the national capital on the 15th ultimo, and to these was added a streamer stretching across the west wall, dated May 3, and inscribed in red, white and blue: "1835 -- We come again to greet you -- 1865." The formal programme embraced music on the piano, by Miss MINNIE FLOWERY, one of the teachers, and Prof. BARTLETT, the ward music master; a selection from the Scriptures and prayer by Mr. HAZELTINE and the entire school; songs and chorusses by the school, and recitations and declamations by Masters SAMUEL KRIZER, ARTHUR M. THOM, HENRY G. GABAY and FRANCIS MCARDLE -- the last named, a promising youth of about thirteen, making a congratulatory address to his Principal, the close of which was an invocation to the Deity, pronounced with pathos worthy of an older head, thus:

abstract: A CITIZEN SHOT BY A POLICEMAN.--Mr. THOS. CHAPPEL, a painter, working in Seventeenth-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, Gowanus, was shot by Policeman VINCENT, of the Forty-eighth Precinct. The ball entered CHAPPEL'S shoulder.
lead_paragraph: A CITIZEN SHOT BY A POLICEMAN. -- Mr. THOS. CHAPPEL, a painter, working in Seventeenth-street, between Fifth and Sixth avenues, Gowanus, was shot by Policeman VINCENT, of the Forty-eighth Precinct. The ball entered CHAPPEL'S shoulder. There appears to have been no cause whatever for firing at the man. As alleged, the policeman was intoxicated and hardly knew what he was about. Capt. BROWN, of the precinct, promptly ordered the policeman's arrest and he was locked up to await an investigation of the affair.

abstract: The Eagle Club, of this city, was to have gone to Philadelphia to-morrow morning, the 5th inst., in order to participate in the opening of the new ball-grounds of the Champion Athletics, of Philadelphia, but in consequence of the sudden death of Mr. MCBRIDE, the father of the pitcher of the Athletic Club, the opening games have been postponed to May 12, on which day the Eagles will take the 8 A.M. train via Jersey City, for Philadelphia.

abstract: Memorial Diplomatique and our Prize Courts
snippet: Memorial Diplomatique and our Prize Courts
lead_paragraph: -- We referred some time ago to an article from the Memorial Diplomatique, renewing its attack upon our Prize Courts, on the strength of a decision of the English Court of Common Pleas, in the case of HOBBS vs. HENNING, which was an action on a policy of insurance on some of the cargo of the Peterhoff. It seemed to us that the report of the decision which we found in the English papers, meagre though it was, by no means justified the statement of the Memorial, that the Court of Common Pleas had "declared the condemnation of the United States Prize Court to be unsound and illegal," and that the grounds upon which that condemnation rested were "completely demolished" by this decision of the Common Pleas.

abstract: Coming Back, Philadelphia Inquirer
snippet: Coming Back, Philadelphia Inquirer
lead_paragraph: A correspondent of the Evening Post says: "Mr. SEWARD is so well that he is expected to take this place in Cabinet meetings in a few days. The newspaper accounts of the attempt to assassinate him were generally incorrect. PAVNE, the assassin, only had an opportunity to strike one blow at Mr. SEWARD, who was, at that moment, sitting up in bed. The knife struck the swelling over the fractured jaw and did not touch the throat. At that instant ROBINSON, the nurse, clutched PAYNE from behind, and did not for a moment let go his hold, though stabbed four times. Mr. SEWARD rolled off upon the floor, feigning death. To Mr. ROBINSON he owes his life. This heroic soldier is in hospital here and is doing well, though very badly wounded. Mr. SEWARD now dictates the foreign dispatches to Mr. HUNTER.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- MOZART's opera of the "Magic Flute" was given here on Tuesday evening, to a good house -- the best of the week. We take this opportunity of remarking that there was a perceptible improvement in the attendance at all our places of amusement last night. MOZART's well-known opera has recently achieved a very marked success in Paris. The charm of its melodies, the variety and ingeniousness of its ensemble, entitle it to warmest recognition in any land. The Parisians, however, enjoy one advantage over ourselves. They are not compelled to listen to the awful twaddle of the libretto. A new version has been prepared for their acceptance, and the various scenes have been linked together with some degree of consistency. For us there remains the old Vienna trash, amusing, to be sure, but not otherwise edifying; tending in fact to that condition so suggestively illustrated in the case of papayeno, namely, locked-jaw. Mr. GROVER's caste was exceedingly good; better than any we have ever had in this city. There was a mistake, however, in the announcement of Mr. HERMANN's name, the part of Sarastro being sung not by that gentleman, but by Mr. WEINLICH. The usual apology was made before the curtain, but it did not wholly satisfy Mr. HERMANN, who at the end of the first act appeared before the curtain, and stated that it was not unwillingness that prevented his appearing in the part. The matter ended here, and Mr. WEINLICH, who was in excellent voice, sang the role. A few superfluous hisses were directed at his unoffending head, but he maintained his ground, and did well. Beyond this incident, it is only necessary to say that the performance passed off pleasantly.

abstract: Details and Cost
snippet: Details and Cost
lead_paragraph: - Our Quebec correspondent sends some exclusive information of the details of the fortification scheme intended for the province. It is clear, from these details, that the burden of paying for the proposed works is to fall on the Canadian colonists, after all. What the Home Government propose to do applies only to Quebec, and some new outer forts on the south side of the St. Lawrence River, opposite that city.

abstract: -- An organ concert was given on Tuesday evening at St. George's Church, Stuyvesant-square, for the purpose of introducing Mr. W. EUGENE THAYER, of Boston, to our community. Mr. THAYER is a fine player. He knows the instrument thoroughly, and can express his own individuality on it -- which means the repose of a solid and reliable education. His choice of "stops" was good and legitimate; and his pedal playing was at times quite remarkable. For one of the latter passages Mr. THAYER received an encore. He is an artist of decided merit, and we shall be glad to hear him again.
lead_paragraph: -- An organ concert was given on Tuesday evening at St. George's Church, Stuyvesant-square, for the purpose of introducing Mr. W. EUGENE THAYER, of Boston, to our community. Mr. THAYER is a fine player. He knows the instrument thoroughly, and can express his own individuality on it -- which means the repose of a solid and reliable education. His choice of "stops" was good and legitimate; and his pedal playing was at times quite remarkable. For one of the latter passages Mr. THAYER received an encore. He is an artist of decided merit, and we shall be glad to hear him again.

abstract: Ocean Steamship Enterprise; Line to Spain; Steamship Line to Genoa, Madeira and Cadiz
snippet: Ocean Steamship Enterprise; Line to Spain; Steamship Line to Genoa, Madeira and Cadiz
lead_paragraph: The close of the war promises to be followed speedily by the increase and extension of ocean steamship lines far beyond our experience of this branch of public enterprise. We learn of the early opening of an international line from New-York to Genoa, taking in Madeira and Cadiz as calling places; and so well do the Italian Government think of this enterprise that they have guaranteed for the company 4 per cent. interest on a capital of one million dollars. The first-class passenger traffic on such a line ought itself to form a good basis for a paying business. The trade of Cadiz, the principal commercial city of Spain, would unquestionably receive a large development from a direct intercourse by steam with this city. At present, we believe, it barely exceeds thirty million dollars, while that of Genoa has reached close to eighty million dollars. The great matter for this company to aim at will be to inspire confidence in the safely, the regularity and the thorough discipline of their line. It is useless, hereafter, for any company, we care not what financial guarantees it operates under, what promises of traffic, in freight and passengers, it has to open with, or what parade it can make in the shape of a directory, to overlook the fact that the public will demand thorough reliability in the working of the enterprise. To insure this, much more is needed than a magnificent fleet of fast vessels. Ships of moderate size, of moderate pretensions to decoration, and even of moderate speed, will do well enough to make a commencement with, provided there is the assurance, first, that they are properly manned, and commanded by officers of thorough experience, character and authority; second, that the line, when it does start, shall run at regular intervals, on stated days, and not be the subject of spasms, and breaks, and unforeseen delays; third, that the company shall compute, beforehand the full extent and depth of their resources, so that they shall not make the lack of public subsidies an excuse for failure.

abstract: Broadway and Seventieth-street, Incendiary; boy burned; New-York, Cole, H. B., Lawyer, Arrested for; City Hall Park, Plowed and Renovated
snippet: Broadway and Seventieth-street, Incendiary; boy burned; New-York, Cole, H. B., Lawyer, Arrested for; City Hall Park, Plowed and Renovated
lead_paragraph: FIRE AND LOSS OF LIFE. -- At about 3 o'clock yesterday morning, a fire was discovered in the third story of the wooden building at the intersection of Broadway and Seventieth-street, occupied on the first floor as a lager-bier saloon, by AMBROSE SCHILLER; on the second, by a school; and on the third, by a number of families. The building was consumed and ARMAND LANG, a youth of eight years, was burned to death. It is supposed that the house was set on fire by one JOHN WENCEL, one of the tenants, who had quarreled with the landlord, and is alleged to have made threats. He was apprehended by Policeman Dark, of the Thirty-first Precinct, upon Mr. SCHILLER's complaint, and held to await the action of a coroner. Mr. SCHILLER was insured for $300 in the Manhattan office, and WENCEL, who had packed up his goods and made them ready for removal, had $600 insurance in the Hamilton office. The building, which was owned by Mr. R.A. WITTHAUS, was valued at $1,000.

abstract: Scribner's Hours at Home
snippet: Scribner's Hours at Home
lead_paragraph: In another column Messrs. SCRIBNER & CO. announce the appearance of the first number of their new magazine Hours at Home. It is defined as "A Popular Monthly, devoted to Religions and Useful Literature," and its object is evidently to supply the public with a variety of reading for which they have heretofore been dependent for the most part upon foreign periodicals. The first number of Hours at Home promises well. The new serial is attractive in form and neat in typographical appearance. The subjects discussed are sufficiently varied to suit all tastes, and they are treated by writers whose popularity and well-known ability entitle it to a large measure of popular favor.

abstract: Naussett, Monitor, Launch and Dimensions
snippet: Naussett, Monitor, Launch and Dimensions
lead_paragraph: The light-draft monitor Nausett was launched, in the presence of 2,000 spectators, last week, at the yard of MCDONALD MCKAY, of East Boston. She is the last monitor of her class contracted for at Boston. She is 225 feet long, 45 feet wide, and 17 feet 10 inches in depth; draft of water, 6 1/2 feet; height of turret, 9 feet; inside diameter of turret, 20 feet. Her inner hull is 6 feet thick, of solid oak, and the outer hull, separated by water-tight compartments, is composed of three layers of one-inch iron plates. She will carry two 15-inch guns. She is propelled by two direct acting engines and two four-bladed cast iron propellers, 9 feet in diameter and 12 feet pitch. It will take at least four weeks to make her trial trip and get equipped for active service.

abstract: Fashion Course Trotting
snippet: Fashion Course Trotting
lead_paragraph: In addition to the splendid racing programme prepared for the opening of the Paterson Spring meeting, so affluent in its character, the numerical strength of the entries, and the renowned quality of the horses engaged for the various stakes, a new and absorbing feature of interest has been added, in the shape of a thorough English steeple chase. It will be remembered that at the Saratoga meeting, last year, the hurdle race (dignified by the title of a steeple chase) was the great exciting feature of the meeting -- eliciting a display of enthusiasm not usually manifested on a race-track, and requiring an amount of skill and hardihood to which ordinary flat racing is mere child's play. The steeple chase is a thoroughly English institution, and none but a man accustomed to follow the hounds over "moss and fell" -- over brook, ditch, fence, stone wall, and through thicket -- would venture in the saddle, however competent he might be to steer a thoroughbred on the ordinary level race course.

abstract: -- Mr. GROVER fulfilled his promise last evening by reviving MEYERBEER's opera of "Les Huguenots." Any words of ours in praise of the work would be superfluous. It is accepted -- and rightly -- as the grandest opera of the Italian or German reportoire. It contains more ideas than any half-dozen of the present run of works. We reserve for another opportunity, which we hope may soon occur, the remarks which, in view of a lengthy performance, we could only now imperfectly express. Briefly, we wish to say that the opera was given most creditably. The orchestra and chorus were both superb, and the artists were generally excellent. We doubt, indeed, if MEYERBEER's opera has ever been heard to greater advantage.

abstract: Flight of and Price on his Head
snippet: Flight of and Price on his Head
lead_paragraph: ON HIS HEAD. -- The news that STONEMAN's cavalry had got on the track of JEFF. DAVIS, on his way to Charlottesville, S.C., was promptly followed yesterday by a proclamation of the President, declaring the existence of proof which implicates the fugitive rebel in the assassination of Mr. LINCOLN, and offering a reward of one hundred thousand dollars for his capture. The proclamation links together in the murderous plot the names of DAVIS, JACOB THOMPSON, CLEMENT C. CLAY, GEORGE N. SANDERS, BEVERLEY TUCKER and W.C. CLEARY, rewards amounting to one hundred and ten thousand dollars being offered for bringing to trial the five agents of the Confederacy included in the list of conspirators. We cannot doubt that the proofs on which this official announcement is made are all-sufficient; otherwise their existence would not have been proclaimed. The public will hardly be surprised that the murder is to be brought home directly to the leading rebels. Anyone who has carefully followed the progress of the conspiracies for burning down the Northern cities, for making indiscriminate havoc on all the railways of the North, and for doing secret murder by every available agency, will be forced to the conclusion that the Kennedys, the Bealls, the Booths, and the Harrolds were all the hired and desperate instruments of the Richmond conspirators -- organized and drilled for the service by the "Peace Missionaries" in the neighboring provinces.

abstract: We published a letter the other day from GEO. N. SANDERS, filled with vehement abuse of us for having hinted that he possibly had something to do with the plot for assassinating the President. GEORGE put on the air of an injured innocent. He thought it monstrous that he should be deemed capable of such a crime; and in order that the public might be the more impressed by his protestations, he offered to come to the United States and stand his trial upon this charge, if the government would agree not to prosecute him on any other. He had better come. He is wanted -- very badly wanted by the President of the United States. It seems that evidence now in possession of the military authorities, renders it pretty certain that SANDERS was concerned, as we suggested, in the conspiracy which led to Mr. LINCOLN's murder.

abstract: Lieut.-Gen. ULYSSES S. GRANT, our great national leader, the great soldier of the war, passed through this city yesterday en route for Burlington, N.J. He arrived in the afternoon train from Baltimore, and passed quietly down Market-street to the wharf, where he took the boat for Bristol. He displayed his usual modest dislike of noisy ovations by appearing in citizen's clothes, even wearing a very ordinary looking slouch hat. The face of the "indomitable ULYSSES" is too deeply impressed, however, on the hearts of his countrymen to admit of his successfully maintaining any assumed incognito, and being recognized on Market-street, he was loudly cheered by the enthusiastic crowd which thronged the sidewalks of that busy thoroughfare. It is reported that Gen. GRANT's visit is for the purpose of bringing his wife to Philadelphia, to enter upon the occupation of their palatial mansion on West Chestnut-street, presented to the gallant hero some months since. He will certainly be heartily welcomed, if such be the case, by his fellow-citizens of the City of Brotherly Love. -- Philadelphia Inquirer, May 2.

abstract: ARMAND LANG, a youth of eight years, was burned to death on Wednesday morning, in a wooden building at the intersection of Broadway and Seventieth-street, which it believed to have been set on fire by JOHN WENZEL, one of the occupants, who had recently disputed with the landlord about the rent, and who is said to have uttered threats. There seeming to be reasonable ground of suspicion, Policeman DARK, of the Thirty-first Precinct, apprehended WENZEL, and, holding him until yesterday morning, delivered him to Coroner GOVER and a Jury. The testimony confirmed Officer DARK's suspicions. ELIZABETH MORGANBECK, one of the tenants who was burned out, made oath that she was awakened by the fire, and that it was in WENZEL's room; that when she ran down stairs she saw WENZEL also going down; that his trunk was standing in the hall; that he remarked that he cared only to save his trunk, as his effects were insured, and that not long ago he cautioned her to watch Mrs. SCHILLER, wife of the keeper of a lager-bier saloon on the first-floor, as she might set the house on fire. The jury found a verdict against WENZEL, and the Coroner committed him to await the action of the Grand Jury.

abstract: Yesterday an injunction restraining the Mayor and Commonalty of the city, and the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, from surrendering the property, apparatus and premises of the department, and likewise restraining the new Fire Commissioners from interfering with the department, was issued by Judge SUTHERLAND, of the Supreme Court. The...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday an injunction restraining the Mayor and Commonalty of the city, and the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, from surrendering the property, apparatus and premises of the department, and likewise restraining the new Fire Commissioners from interfering with the department, was issued by Judge SUTHERLAND, of the Supreme Court. The new Board of Commissioners organized yesterday by electing Mr. CHARLES C. PINCKNEY President, Mr. CHARLES E. GILDERSLEEVE Secretary, and Mr. PHILIP W. ENGS Treasurer, They will at once enter on their duties, unless restrained by the injunction. A meeting of the leading members of the Fire Department was held at Fireman's Hall on Wednesday evening. After considerable debate, it was determined to contest the action of the newly-appointed Commissioners in their attempts to establish a paid fire system. Only one company present dissented from this course.

abstract: It has already been stated that the last letter which Mr. COBDEN wrote was addressed to Mr. T.B. abstract: The members of Rev. Mr. STRYKER's church and congregation assembled, last evening, to congratulate each other upon the extinction of their debt, and the removal of a heavy mortgage from their fine church edifice in Thirty-fourth-streeet, near Eighth-avenue. Rev. Dr. CAMPBELL, of Rutgers College, opened the meeting with prayer, in which he besought the Great Ruler to smile upon the church and the nation, and discover to us the conspirators who were engaged in the late atrocious tragedy at the nation's capital. After the prayer, the choir and audience sang WATT's hymn for the opening of a house of worship.

abstract: Fire Department; New (Paid) Board Organization; Fire Department; Opposition to the Paid
snippet: Fire Department; New (Paid) Board Organization; Fire Department; Opposition to the Paid
lead_paragraph: A temporary injunction was granted by Mr. Justice SUTHERLAND, yesterday, restraining the Mayor and Commonalty of the City, and the Chief Engineer of the Fire Department, from transferring the aparatus and other property of the Fire Department to the newly-appointed commissioners. The injunction is understood to have been based upon the opinion of the Attorney-General of the State that the law is unconstitutional, inasmuch as it exempts the City of Brooklyn from its operation, and leaves New-York alone under the control of the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners, virtutually making them city officers, who, according to the State Constitution, can only be elected by the people or appointed by such authorities of the city as the Legislature shall designate. Without attempting to dispute whether this point of the opponents of the law is well taken or not, it seems very clear, from the spirit which actuated the representatives of the Fire Department at their meeting on Wednesday evening, that the attempt to establish any paid system will meet with factious opposition. Chief-Engineer DECKER and his colleagues announced their determination, even before the injunction was obtained, to recognize in no manner the authority of the new commissioners, and to hold tenaciously, in spite of law, the control of the old department and its property, threatening with immediate disbandment any company which might be found favoring the new order of affairs. We can assure the members of the Volunteer Fire Department, that in yielding to this improper spirit, they are committing a grave error, which will condemn them before the public, whose good opinion, in so far as they, as a body, are entitled to it, has never yet been withheld.

abstract: LAUNCH OF THE BARK ELLA NEVINS. -- The bark Ella Nevins, 500 tons burthen, intended for the Italian trade, was launched at 4 P.M. yesterday, from the yard of THOMAS STACK, foot of North Sixth-street, Eastern District. A large number of ladies and gentlemen from New-York were present. The dimensions of the bark are as follows: Length 140 feet; breadth of beam, 30 feet; depth of hold, 18 1/2 feet. She is of superior model and fine finish.... At the same yard there is on the stocks, in a forward state, a steam revenue cutter, of 500 tons burthen. Her dimensions are: Length of keel, 120 feet; breadth of beam, 13 feet; depth of hold, 8 feet.

abstract: The Points to be Secured Before; Freedmen; Security Must be Provided for; a Permanent, Necessary
snippet: The Points to be Secured Before; Freedmen; Security Must be Provided for; a Permanent, Necessary
lead_paragraph: The government has always demanded, and has now substantially obtained of the rebels an unconditional submission. This does not mean simply an unconditional submission to the Federal Constitution and the laws of the land. It takes in an antecedent submission to military rule. Until an amnesty is declared by President JOHNSON, in accordance with the power which has been conferred upon him by Act of Congress, all Southern rebels have no civil status whatever. So far as their civil rights and franchises are concerned, they are to-day practically as much outside of the pale of the Federal Constitution as the people of Russia. They are subject to military rule only.

abstract: BROADWAY THEATRE.--SHAKESPEARE'S comedy --kindly called "brilliant" in the programme--of "Much Ado About Nothing," was played here last evening. We would say "produced " if it lay in our power, but it is impossible. The avoirdupoise of the actors, the incongruity of the scenery, and the slothfulness of all that relates to a stage performance, compels us to say that the comedy was given badly.
lead_paragraph: BROADWAY THEATRE. -- SHAKESPEARE's comedy -- kindly called "brilliant" in the programme -- of "Much Ado About Nothing," was played here last evening. We would say "produced " if it lay in our power, but it is impossible. The avoirdupoise of the actors, the incongruity of the scenery, and the slothfulness of all that relates to a stage performance, compels us to say that the comedy was given badly. Mr. DE GROAT was decent as Dogberry. Beyond this it is hardly possible to go. The Don Pedro of Mr. G. EVERETT was flagrantly weak, and Mr. CATHCART, who has a good stage presence and an excellent voice, was hardly better as Claudio. The gentleman last-named has unquestionable merit, but the redundancy of his style is, to say the least, overwhelming. Miss CHAPMAN, as Hero, played charmingly. The lady has had but few chances, so far, but we are persuaded that she could readily become a favorite of our public. The rest of the cast was execrably bad.

abstract: Chamber of Commerce and National Affairs
snippet: Chamber of Commerce and National Affairs
lead_paragraph: There is no doubt much to be said in favor of the expression of the sentiments of such a body as the New-York Chamber of Commerce upon the question of restoring peace throughout the country. Every commercial man is interested directly in the revival of industry in the South, which promises to follow the closing up of the war. And it is altogether proper for the Chamber to recognize, by a formal resolution, the promptitude and liberality which dictated the recent order of the President, relieving well-disposed citizens in the late seceded States from unnecessary commercial restrictions. But we doubt whether resolutions affirming of deprecating a particular line of policy on the general question of pacification, can be introduced into such a body with advantage. The future management of the South involves problems which can hardly be disposed of in a few hastily considered propositions. The question, moreover, is one which will mark the great division line hereafter between opposing parties. Of this fact the members of the Chamber themselves had practical evidence yesterday in their own body, one set of resolves being adopted apparently to neutralize the effect of another set, and thus establish something like a party equipoise.

abstract: Geographical and Statistical Society, Annual Meeting; Officers, >amp;c.
snippet: Geographical and Statistical Society, Annual Meeting; Officers, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The annual meeting of the American Geographical and Statistical Society took place last evening at their rooms in Clinton Hall. The attendance was both good and select. After the reading of the minutes of the last meeting, and their adoption, the annual report of the council was submitted. The exhibit proved the society to be out of debt, owing to the liberality of certain gentlemen who had advanced the requisite funds. There have been received into the library during the past year 500 new books, and the total number of volumes now on the shelves of the society will reach nearly 5,000. Attention was called to a new loan or subscription in progress, the sums of which are only binding when $10,000 were raised. It was intended to enable the society to enlarge their premises, increase their facilities, and give them greater scope. The report was interesting and satisfactory.

abstract: the Last Rites to
snippet: the Last Rites to
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the last of the funeral rites in honor of Mr. LINCOLN were observed at his late home in Springfield. For fifteen days, and along a route of two thousand miles, through crowded cities, and in sight of millions of sorrow-stricken on-lookers, the solemn pageant has been borne onward, with no abatement in the public sympathy, and no lessening in the tributes of popular affection which surround the memory of the dead President. No such picture of national mourning has, probably, ever been witnessed before. None such will, probably, ever be witnessed again by the living generation. Henceforth, while remembering his services and cherishing his example, the nation will turn with redoubled earnestness to the great task which his untimely death left unaccomplished. This will now be the best tribute that can be paid to the memory of ABRAHAM LINCOLN.

abstract: Orphan Asylum Society, Anniversary
snippet: Orphan Asylum Society, Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The fifty-ninth anniversary of the Orphan Asylum Society of New-York, was celebrated at Irving Hall yesterday afternoon. A large and fashionable audience was present. About 160 of the children under the care of the society were on the platform, the boys dressed in brown and gray, the girls in blue, with white aprons trimmed with red. Several of the youngest children were brought in their nurses' arms. All appeared to be healthy and happy.

abstract: A long official report on the Russian epidemic has been published at St. Petersburgh, in answer to a series of seven questions put by the English Ambassador to the Russian Administration. To the first question, as to the names by which the epidemic is known, the reply is that it presents simply the "typhoid character with different modifications already known, such as typhoid fever, petechial typhus, bilious typhoid fever (the bilioeses zyphoid of the Germans,) fievre recurrente (febris recurrens,) in German recurrirende Fieber, and in English relapsing fever." Russian acquaintance with the latter fever is due chieftly to English physicians. In reply to the second question, it is stated that, although the relapsing fever had never before been known in St. Petersburgh, it had declared itself at various times since 1840 in other parts of Russia -- at Moscow, at Novo-Archangelsk in Russian America, and last year at Odessa. At present it prevails in various places beside the capital, along with petechial typhus. In reply to the third question, the relapsing fever, simple and bilious, it is stated, like typhus in general, to have shown itself to be contagious. Only two deaths have occurred among the physicians, and a few among the attendants and nurses. In reply to the fourth question the following particulars are stated. They have mostly already been published, but it is desirable to snow what portion of the various unofficial statements has received official confirmation:

abstract: Fire Department, Opposition, Injunction, Meeting, >amp;c.
snippet: Fire Department, Opposition, Injunction, Meeting, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday Justice SUTHERLAND granted a temporary injunction restraining the Mayor, the Common Council and Chief Engineer DECKER, of the old Fire Department, from turning over the machines, apparatus, , belonging to the city, to the new department, represented by the Fire Commissioners appointed under and by virtue of a recent act of the Legislature. A second injunction was also obtained on behalf of the people of the State, restraining the new Fire Commissioners from acting in their capacity as such. These injunctions are, of course, merely temporary ones. They were obtained by Attorney-General COCHRANE, acting in behalf of the people of the State, and thus far they are wholly ex parte. The object of the injunction, we understand, is to test the constitutionality of the law creating the new commission. All the legal questions involved will be fully argued and determined before and by the Supreme Court, at an early day. Mr. WM.H. WILSON, of No. 125 Bowery, and JAMES E. NOLAN, of West Twenty-seventh-street, signed the bonds required to obtain the injunction order. They testified that they were each worth the sum of $4,000 over and above all their debts and liabilities, and over and above all property exempt by law from levy and sale under execution.

abstract: Magazines for May; Hours at Home, First Number
snippet: Magazines for May; Hours at Home, First Number
lead_paragraph: -- The Atlantic Monthly (Boston: TICKNOR & FIELDS) contains an interesting sketch of "Student Life at Hofwyl," the famous Swiss educational establishment, by ROBERT DALE OWEN; the continuation of DONALD G. MITCHELL's New-England tale, "Dr. Johns," every number of which shows a growing power in the author, as the plot of the story widens before the reader; "Gold Egg, a Dream Fancy," a poem, by JAMES RUSSELL LOWELL, and a paper evincing a rare faculty for nice observation of nature: "With the Birds," by JOHN BURROUGHS; "The Diplomacy of the Revolution," by GEORGE W. GREENE, passes in review the services to the national cause rendered by FRANKLIN and JAY in the courts of Europe; Col. HIGGINSON estimates the condition and prospects of the lately freed negroes, with confidence in their future destiny, in "Fair Play is the Best Policy; Mrs. STOWE, GOTTSCHALK and D.A. WASSON continue the series of papers already commenced by them in the Atlantic. The number is a fair average one, without any startling novelty.

abstract: AN ALLEGED ACCOMPLICE OF BOOTH--A few days since a young man, whoso name has not been divulged, was arrested by Detective FROST and others on the charge of theit, and, proving to be a smart fellow, told something more than he knew to be facts, in order to exculpate himself from the actual offence of which it is alleged he is guilty. He stated...
lead_paragraph: AN ALLEGED ACCOMPLICE OF BOOTH. -- A few days since a young man, whoso name has not been divulged, was arrested by Detective FROST and others on the charge of theit, and, proving to be a smart fellow, told something more than he knew to be facts, in order to exculpate himself from the actual offence of which it is alleged he is guilty. He stated that be knew the assassin BOOTH, having acted as errand boy, &c., and said that HARROLD had been a resident of Brooklyn and an attendant of a physician who formerly resided here. The officers believing that he knew something of the assassination, and having an eye to the reward, kept him in custody for some days, and reported the case to General Superintendent KENNEDY, of the Metropolitan Police. That officer examined the matter thoroughly, and, as recorted, found it to be "bosh," and ordered the young man's release. He is still held, however, upon the charge upon which he was originally arrested.

abstract: His Specie Lost
snippet: His Specie Lost
lead_paragraph: -Col. CLARK, of the rebel army, who was captured by one of our scouting parties while endeavoring to escape from Richmond on one of the last trains from the doomed city, asserts that he was in charge of all the specie which was removed from Richmond; that when his train broke down, and he found it impossible to get it on the track and off again, and seeing our forces approaching, he ordered it set on fire, and that all his efforts to save the specie were unavailing; that the soldiers broke open the kegs, and amid the excitement and tumult, soldiers and citizens appropriated all there was. He asserts that he knows that no other amounts of specie, not in the pockets of its owners, were taken from Richmond, and that this lot was all stolen. He states further, that the amount has been vastly over estimated, and confirms the statement heretofore made by Gen. GRANT, that it amounted only to $200,000. Col. CLARK was an old regular army officer previous to the breaking out of the war, and is a near relative of one of our most distinguished naval officers, to whom he communicated the above statements.

lead_paragraph: FATAL ACCIDENT ON THE NEW-HAVEN RAILROAD. -- At about 7 o'clock last evening, an aged woman, whom the police of the Nineteenth Ward believe to have been a homeless wanderer, was run over and instantly killed by a New-Haven Railroad train, near Fifty-sixth-street. The engineer made made the usual alarm signals, but the woman paid no heed to them, and hence it is inferred that she was deaf. Patrolmen JUMP and LONSDALE took the body to the Nineteenth Precinct Police Station, and a notification was sent to Coroner COLLIN.

abstract: The trees in our streets and squares will soon be in full leaf, but how long they are destined to remain clad with verdure depends on the greater or less degree of vigor with which that intolerable nuisance, the measure-worm, prosecutes its ravages. Many suggestions for the destruction of the worm have been made, and not a few tried, but without success. In Brooklyn, a few years ago, small troughs were placed around each tree, and filled with oil, but without any perceptible effect in protecting the trees from the attacks of the worm. The eggs from which the measure-worm is produced are deposited by the "miller" moth in the bark of the trees during the previous Summer, and are warmed into life by the power of the sun during the ensuing Spring. No sooner do the leaves expand than the worm, which grows with their growth, attacks them, and in two or three weeks the tree is divested of its foliage. It is known that where birds are plentiful, the worm never becomes troublesome, in the Central Park the trees preserve their foliage to the end of the season. The birds feed on the worm, and thus prevent its undue increase. But birds cannot be induced to remain in the populous parts of our cities. Naturalists who have devoted some time to the observation of the measure-worm and its habits, recommend the application of a strong stream of water to the trees for the purpose of destroying the worm. This remedy has been successfully applied, and there appears to be no reason why our steam fire engines should not be brought into play against this rapacious and disgusting creature. A trial will not cost much, and if successful, all New-York and Brooklyn may be rid of a nuisance by the expenditure of a very few dollars.

abstract: Bettersworth vs. Hough Case Decision; Decora, Winnebago Chief, 133 years old; Chapin, Rev. W., Missionary to India
snippet: Bettersworth vs. Hough Case Decision; Decora, Winnebago Chief, 133 years old; Chapin, Rev. W., Missionary to India
lead_paragraph: The case of BETTERSWORTH vs. HOUGH, for false imprisonment, was decided at Quebec on Saturday, the plaintiff receiving $500 damages. After the St. Albans raiders were discharged by Judge COURSOL, HOUGH took part in the pursuit for their recapture, and arrested BETTERSWORTH, supposing him to be SCOTT, one of the party. Subsequently BETTERSWORTH was discharged by Judge SMITH, and then brought this action against HOUGH, laying his damages at $10,000. The defendant claimed exemption from liability on the ground that he was a special constable, whilst the plaintiff urged that the arrest was made for the sake of obtaining the reward offered by the government. The jury decided as above. BETTERSWORTH has also brought an action against Mr. MAGUIRE, the Judge of Sessions, for illegal imprisonment.
