abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports, items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriagesand deaths of the week.

abstract: Lucas, Samuel, of London Morning Star
snippet: Lucas, Samuel, of London Morning Star
lead_paragraph: The news of the death of Mr. SAMUEL LUCAS, for many years past the managing proprietor of the London Morning Star, has created no less sorrow in America than in England. His connection with the great movements for social and political reform among his own countrymen, his deep seated sympathy with all efforts towards true progress throughout the world, especially the warmth, ability and steadfastness with which he defended the cause of freedom in this country against the sneers and detractions of the Southern party in England, gave him a high place in the affections and esteem of our people; and it is gratifying to know that be lived long enough to see that the triumph of the North was assured. He heard of the fall of Richmond on Saturday morning, and expressed at once his gratification at the prospects of peace and the triumph of freedom, mingled with his deep regret for the sacrifices which on both sides had been offered. Early next morning he died.

abstract: Rebel Commissioner of Exchange, in Prison, also Col. Hatch; Our Unimployed
snippet: Rebel Commissioner of Exchange, in Prison, also Col. Hatch; Our Unimployed
lead_paragraph: An order from Gen. HALLECK, issued at Richmond, allows all persons, without regard to rank or employment, in the civil or military service of the late rebel government, to take the amnesty oath, and will receive the corresponding certificate. Those excluded from the benefit of such oath can make application for pardon and restoration to civil rights, which applications will be received and forwarded to proper channels for the action of the President of the United States. The fact that such persons have voluntarily come forward and taken the oath of allegiance will be evidence of their intention to resume the status of loyal citizens, and constitutes a claim for Executive clemency. Gen. MEADE had arrived in Richmond. The van of the Army of the Potomac reached Manchester on the 3d, from City Point, en route for Washington. The heavy equipments and paraphernalia go by water.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- HALEVY's grand opera of the "Jewess" was given here last evening to a good audience; the best, numerically considered, of the season. The work is certainly one of the finest of the French repertoire. It is filled with ideas, and contains more melodic suggestions than any two or three productions of the present day. It was the exhaustive effort of its composer. Writing many other works, he has yet always returned to this as the fountain of his freest and best inspiration. Like all really elaborate works, it has made its way slowly, but its acceptance has been based on the firmest judgments of the world, and it would be superfluous and impertinent to question their authority now.

abstract: Church of the Holy Trinity, Rev. S. H. Tyng, Jr.
snippet: Church of the Holy Trinity, Rev. S. H. Tyng, Jr.
lead_paragraph: Passengers by the New-Haven or Harlem Railroad may have lately observed an edifice going up in East Forty-second-street, in the immediate neighborhood of the depot, the exact purpose of which may have puzzled them somewhat, the walls being so low and the roof crowned with a ventilating turret so cut up with gables and valleys. This edifice is the Church of the Holy Trinity, erected for Rev. STEPHEN H. TYNG, Jr., from the designs and under the superintendence of W.J. WREY MOULD, architect, and is most admirably adapted to the requirements of the congregation for whom it has been built. The enterprise, commenced under circumstances of no little discouragement, and carried forward through many difficulties, has been singularly blessed, both in its spiritual growth and its temporal affairs. A year ago last January a proposition was made to the young pastor, then Rector of the Church of the Mediator, to unite with the Church of the Ascension in establishing a new Episcopal Church on Murray Hill. The chapel of the Rutgers Institute had been alraedy engaged and opened for public services under the supervision of Dr. DYER, of whom the present rector speaks with affection, as really the father of the parish. It was then thought that five years at least would be required to establish the enterprise in an edifice of its own; but the encouragement met with was such that on the 4th of April following it was decided to organize a new, independent parish, under the title of the Church of the Holy Trinity. On the 1st of May Rev. Mr. TYNG was invited to serve as rector, and on the 8th of September the corner-stone of the present edifice was laid, at the northeast angle of the intersection of Madison-avenue and Forty-second-street. The plan is that of a cross, with four entrance porches filling up the angles made by the transepts with the nave or main body of the church, Extreme length, 127 feet; width of nave, 40 feet; extreme breadth through transepts, 81 feet. There are one hundred and sixty pews, seating over nine hundred persons, all on the ground floor. The walls of the church are low, and the building, as approached from Murray Hill, presents a somewhat stunted appearance; but on entering the interior proves sufficiently lofty, the roof trusses being framed so as to show. There is a ventilating spire for light and air at the intersection of the nave and transept roofs, forming an elevated central feature to the whole composition. The organ and choir screen form the sole decorative features of the interior, and are situated behind the chancel and altar -- the radiating pipes of the organ being decorated and illuminated, and so disposed as to show the rich stained-glass windows in the extreme rear wall. Mr. MOULD has not assumed to embody any features of the so-called Gothic, Byzantine, Italian or renaissance styles, but simply such a combination of architectural elements as are best adapted to produce a temporary, economical and yet commodious church building, in which design he has succeeded very thoroughly; indeed for charming novelty of effect, and a cheerfulness of interior aspect that most effectually combines the church with the home, we know of no ecclesiastical edifice in the city at all comparable to it; and we earnestly advise our readers to take an early opportunity of visiting it. Divine service has been held there since Easter Sunday, although the building is not yet quite complete. A word for the trustees: they had the good sense to go right straight to Mr. MOULD and place the commission in his hands, without beating about the bush, consulting the ideas, and exciting the hopes of half a dozen architects -- as is too often the case. How excellently Mr. MOULD has carried out their wishes, every one connected with the Church most willingly testifies, and we feel sure the general public will sustain their verdict.

abstract: How Provided for
snippet: How Provided for
lead_paragraph: It the comfortably clad and sanitarily clean people of this city are in doubt as to the effects produced by the rebeilion and its consequences upon the white population of the Soutn, they can easily ascertain by visiting Gen. DIX's headquarters in Bleeckerstreet, any day after the arrival of a transport from the South. A day or two since we were present when a batch of Southerners, some thirty in number made their appearance forlorn and desolate, seeking aid and comfort. Men, women and children, dirt, squalor and vermin, wretchedness and discomfort. In the lower hall were several ordinarily good looking men, whose long hair fell disheveled over gaunt faces and hungry eyes; their garments were of gray homespun, worn, threadbare and ragged, into whose very fibre the dirt from without and the uncleanliness from within, had worked and become ingrained. They stood listlessly waiting for somebody or something to turn up; they were from the broad belt of destruction made by the track of SHERMAN's army; their homes were burned, their properly gone, their means of subsistence entirely swept away, and their [???] and preserved by the kindness of the General, who pitying their helplessness took them with him to the coast and ordered them North. The women differed in this respect, that while their husbands presented an unbroken front of abjectness, they varied, some seem'ng bright and hopeful, some morose and sullen, others simply downcast and broken-hearted. The children played about the hall, crept up the stairway guarded by the orderlies, peeped at the prim face of Col. Van Buren, looked wistfully at the door of Capt. RIVES' office, wherein went their parents to take the oath or obtain transportation, grasped eagerly the piece of biscuit extended by a friendly hand, or cuddled close to their mothers and cried for rest. It was a pitiable sight, and yet one which was not a fair specimen; it was above rather than under the average.

abstract: Since the surrender of LEE and JOHNSTON, the guerrilla leaders, from whom so much was at one time feared, are all surrendering as fast as they can. The two smartest and notablest of these characters -- MOSBY, in Virginia, and JEFF. THOMPSON, in Missouri -- are now out of the field. MOSBY, in his order bidding a final adieu to his troopers, tells them that, as the vision of Southern independence has vanished, he disbands his organization, in preference, as he says, to surrendering to his enemies. This will do just about as well as a surrender, and in some respects better, as it gives the country riddance of a murderous marauder. JEFF. THOMPSON, however, regularly surrendered his whole force at Memphis on Tuesday last; and thus the State of Missouri, which has for some time been in dread of an incursion by THOMPSON, will now be relieved. Beside these guerrilla chieftains, scores of lesser leaders of the same character, in Kentucky, Tennessee, Southwestern Virginia, and elsewhere, have lately surrendered or disbanded their forces.

abstract: Street-Cleaning; the New Law
snippet: Street-Cleaning; the New Law
lead_paragraph: At the last session of the Legislature, the law in relation to street leaning was repealed, and a new one adopted, appropriating $500,000 for street-cleaning purposes, and appointing the Mayor, Recorder, Comptroller. City Inspector, and Counsel to the Corporation a commission who are authorized and required to enter into a contract with some responsible party to clean the streets for a term not less than three years. The law further says that, after advertising for proposals for ten days, a contract shall be awarded to the person or persons whose proposals shall, in the judgment of said commissioners, or a majority of them, secure the most effective service, and shall be most advantageous to the public interests; and in case the acceptance of any of the proposals should appear to a majority of such commissioners as not for the public interests, the said commissioners, or a majority of them, may re-advertise for proposals; but no contract shall be awarded except after at least ten days' previous advertisement. The Comptroller is hereby authorized to pay all arrearages for street cleaning, and all expenses and cost thereof until the contractor under this clause shall be prepared to proceed with his contract, and the amount of such arrearages, cost and expenses shall be included in the tax levy and assessed upon the taxable property of said city by said Supervisors.
headline: {'main': 'Street Cleaning.; THE NEW LAW--AN ENTIRE CHANGE IN THE MODE OF AWARDING CONTRACTS--THE PRESENT CONDITION OF THE STREETS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Street Cleaning.; THE NEW LAW--AN ENTIRE CHANGE IN THE MODE OF AWARDING CONTRACTS--THE PRESENT CONDITION OF THE STREETS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: CHANGING THE NAMES OF CERTAIN STREETS-- The Committee of the Brooklyn Common Council having full charge of the subject, have been engaged in renaming all streets in the city which are duplicated, and there are many such. There are several Wyckoff-streets, Nassau-streets. Grand-streets, Clinton-streets and avenues, and the streets of nearly the...
lead_paragraph: CHANGING THE NAMES OF CERTAIN STREETS. -- The Committee of the Brooklyn Common Council having full charge of the subject, have been engaged in renaming all streets in the city which are duplicated, and there are many such. There are several Wyckoff-streets, Nassau-streets. Grand-streets, Clinton-streets and avenues, and the streets of nearly the entire Eighth Ward are named, First, Second, Third, &c., precisely as those in a large portion of the Eastern Districts. All these names are now changed. The following are among the most prominent: Kent-avenue will extend through First Franklin and Commercial streets in the Eastern District to Newtown Creek. Franklin-avenue will extend from the Flatbush line, through Wythe-avenue, Second-street and Norman-avenue, to Newtown Creek, a distance of five miles. Nassau-avenue in the Eastern District, will run through Third-street to Division-avenue. Bedford-avenue embraces Fourth-street. Van Cott avenue is continued through Fifth-street to Division-avenue. Montrose-avenue extends through South Fifth-street, commencing at the city lines; Meserole-street takes out South Fourth-street; Wyckoff-street takes out South Second street; Remsen-street takes out South First-street; Broadway takes out South Seventh-street; Atlantic-avenue wipes out Atlantic street. Fulton-avenue wipes out Fulton-street. Both the above thoroughfares will be known as avenues from the East River to East New-York, and will be numbered accordingly. Flushing avenue will extend through Nassau-street to Fulton; Third-avenue will extend through Powers-street to Flatbush-avenue; Washington-avenue is to be known as either Sheridan or Woolsey-avenue (not yet decided;) Clinton-avenue as Sherman-avenue, Grand-avenue as Grant avenue, and Meserole-avenue as Lincoln-avenue. The report of the committee will probably be presented to the Common Council, on Monday evening next, for confirmation.

abstract: Atrocious Admissions to G. A. Sala
snippet: Atrocious Admissions to G. A. Sala
lead_paragraph: The three most notable rebel spies that are still at large in the neighboring provinces -- SANDERS, TUCKER and CLEARY -- have met the President's proclamation, offering a reward for their capture, by loud protests of their innocence, made public through the local prints, SANDERS, however, still persists in having his case brought to trial -- that is, upon certain conditions as to locality and assurances of personal safety being complied with by the United States Government. SANDERS, who preferred, the other week, to come to New-York for trial, now, on second thought prefers Rouse's Point, a border village about two hours' ride from Montreal, where he would have a chance of friendly assistance in case of matters going hard with him. We do not know that this new proof of his innocence will entirely satisfy the public. It would be interesting, meanwhile, to have an explanation from SANDERS of his conference with GEORGE AUGUSTUS SALA, on the subject of these assassinations, six or nine months before they took place. SALA says distinctly that SANDERS told him of the plotting of atrocities which would make the world shudder. These atrocities have been committed; and, if SANDERS desires to save his own neck, he may turn States' evidence against his Confederates. He knows who planned the murders. He boasts of knowing it. Let him purchase his personal safety by a full confession. He has done things quite as villainously mean as this before.
headline: {'main': 'SANDERS AND SALA.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'SANDERS AND SALA.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Democratic Party and the Chicago Platform
snippet: Democratic Party and the Chicago Platform
lead_paragraph: Some of our Democratic cotemporaries take in ill part our good-natured allusions to the sad figure now presented by the Chicago platform. They call it ungenerous to twit the party about that, when it is now so lustily shouting glory for the national triumph. Well, we are sorry. We did not think they were so sensitive. Henceforth we will try to remember that even the smallest pleasantry upon that subject is a great cruelty, and there shall be no more of it.

abstract: At about 7 o'clock on Thursday evening, an unknown woman was run over and instantly killed by a New-Haven Railroad train, at the intersection of Fifty-fifth-street and Fourth-avenue. It appeared in evidence that the engineer sounded an alarm and whistled down the brakes, and the jury failed to discover that any person was in fault. The deceased was about 55 years of age, had grey hair and blue eyes, and wore a crimson shawl and thick leather boots.

abstract: There is nothing new in the matter of the disputed legality of the new Fire Commissioners. At a late hour on Thursday evening the Sheriff succeeded in serving the injunction upon Messrs. ENGS and BOOTH, but it was not until yesterday afternoon the other two commissioners could be found. The injunction was, however, served upon all the parties, and the new board resolved to go on with the matter and test it in the courts without delay. Conusel will be engaged to-day by the commissioners, and every effort be made to bring the entire dispute to a speedy and satisfactory end.

snippet: Fire Department; The Old and New; Decker, Chief Engineer, and the Old Fire Dept.; Wood, Hon. Fernando, on Constitutionality of Laws
lead_paragraph: We seem likely to have in the matter of the Fire Commissioners a fresh attempt to carry out the famous doctrine invented by FERNANDO WOOD, that no law is entitled to obedience until it has been pronounced constitutional by the courts. We thought that this question, which ought never to have been raised, had been settled, for this generation at least, in 1857.

abstract: Samuel Holmes vs. Sarah C. Clark et al. -- The action was brought by the judgment creditors of the defendant, Mrs. Clark, to set aside a conveyance made by her to her infant children, on the ground that the same was fraudulent and therefore void as to the creditors. An action of the same nature has been tried heretofore, in which the same defendants were sued, and a judgment recovered in plaintiff's favor. The debt claimed to be due to the plaintiffs in this action was incurred after the alleged fraudulent conveyance. The defendants moved to dismiss the complaint on the pleadings and on the opening argument of plaintiff's counsel. The court said that inasmuch as the infants could not be parties to the fraud, their rights and interest in the property in dispute could not be attacked by subsequent creditors, especially those without notice of the transfer, and that in no case could creditors subsequent to the conveyance alleged in be fraudulent set it aside, where such conveyance was to infants. The complaint must therefore be dismissed.
lead_paragraph: Samuel Holmes vs. Sarah C. The defendants moved to dismiss the complaint on the pleadings and on the opening argument of plaintiff's counsel. The court said that inasmuch as the infants could not be parties to the fraud, their rights and interest in the property in dispute could not be attacked by subsequent creditors, especially those without notice of the transfer, and that in no case could creditors subsequent to the conveyance alleged in be fraudulent set it aside, where such conveyance was to infants. The complaint must therefore be dismissed.

abstract: Joyce vs. the Mayor; Croton Aqueduct Contract
snippet: Joyce vs. the Mayor; Croton Aqueduct Contract
lead_paragraph: Wm. Joyce vs. The Mayor, &c. -- In 1861 plaintiff made a contract with the Croton Aqueduct Department to construct a sewer in Fifty-eighth-street, between Seventh and Eighth avenues. While the work was progressing, the water-pipes in the street burst, and a large quantity of water flowed upon the rocks which plaintiff had to blast, in order to complete his contract. The plaintiff proved, by several experts, that the difference in labor and expense between blasting a wet and dry rock was very great. The foreman testified that the work took about four months more time by reason of the break. The case was submitted to the jury under the charge of His Honor. After a long deliberation they were discharged without having been able to agree upon a verdict.

abstract: Sergeant CARPENTER, of the Fourth Ward, preferred a charge against patrolman GAYNOR. It appears that GAYNOR took an inebriated female to the station-house, and while on the way to a cell she seized a baluster, and hereupon the officer struck her. There were many policemen in the house at the time, and the officer might have had assistance in taking the female into cellar, and there being no excuse for his conduct, President ACTON sharply reprimanded him.

lead_paragraph: INCENDIARISM IN SIXTEENTH-STREET. -- Fire Marshal BAKER was engaged, yesterday, in investigating an atrocious attempt at incendiarism in Mr. THOMAS W. MARSHALL'S dwelling, at No 33 West Sixteenth-street, where, it appears, that the incendiary kindled two fires at about 5 o'clock on Thursday morning, in the front and fear parlors. Providentiatly the family were awakened by the smoke, and the flames were extinguished, without giving alarm, before they had gained headway. Mr. MARSHALL's furniture, which is insured for $1,500 by the Washington Insurance Company, was damaged to the extent of about $1,200, and the building, which is insured in the Importers' and Traders' Office, may be repaired for $600. The Fire-Marshal has obtained evidence upon which he will probably order an arrest to-day.

lead_paragraph: Each successive day develops amazingly the popular interest in the national 7-30 Loan, and the measure of public confidence in the solvency of the government. The daily sales of the loan thus far, have averaged $5,942,887, (as against a daily average of $4,238,233 last week, and of $3,054,140 the preceding week,) as follows : Monday, $5,175,900; Tuesday, $5,231,100 :Wednesday, $7,261,300; Thursday, $6,103,250. The current sales of the loan are at the unprecedented rate of $35,657,322 a week. At this rate, all the unsold balance (about 175,000,000) of the pending series of $300,000,000, will be easily marked before the date (June 15) when the notes formally commence to bear interest. The orders for the $50 and $100 notes of the loan, this week, have averaged 3,786.

lead_paragraph: The Chicago Tribune says: Quite a feat was accomplished between Michigan City and Lake Station, on the occasion of the reception of the funeral cortege, which railroad men, if not the general public, will appreciate. At the former place, at which the funeral train arrived at 8.25 on Thursday morning, Gen. HOOKER stepped off to get breakfast, and while eating, the train left. Major JAMES S. HOPPER, train dispatcher of the Michigan Central at Michigan City, went to the company's shop, and took out a locomotive, which, with the General on board, overtook the train at Lake Station. The distance between Porter and Lake Stations, eight miles, was run in the unprecedented time of nine minutes.

abstract: The Sixteenth Ward Draft Association, which was organized for the purpose of freeing the ward from the draft, held a meeting to close the business of the association. The Finance Committee reported that there was about $1,400 remaining in the treasury. It was unanimously resolved to appropriate the money to the Patriot Orphan Home, at Flushing, L.I. The Executive Committee will publish the names of contributors, together with the amount of subscriptions.

snippet: Erie Railroad Train in Conestoga River--Several Killed
lead_paragraph: The express train on the Erie Railroad, which left Buffalo at 6 o'clock on Thursday evening, the 4th inst., met with a most frightful accident while crossing the bridge over the Conestoga River, near the village of Painted Post, about two miles west of Corning. The train, it appears, broke bodily through the bridge, precipitating the first passenger-car, the baggage-car, and the locomotive into the stream below.

abstract: Amnesty Order; Gen. Halleck's Order; the
snippet: Amnesty Order; Gen. Halleck's Order; the
lead_paragraph: The important order which Gen. HALLECK issued from Richmond on Wednesday last, and which was published in the TIMES of yesterday, received, we must suppose, the authorization of the government. It announced that "all persons, without regard to their rank or employment in the civil or military service of the late rebel government, will be permitted to take the amnesty oath, and will receive the corresponding certificate; and that those excluded from the benefit of such oath can make application for pardon and restoration to civil rights, which applications will be received and forwarded to the proper channels for the action of the President of the United States."

abstract: Two of our paroled prisoners have arrived at Raleigh, hanging news that JEFF. DAVIS was at Charlote, N.C., on the 25th of April, but that be left on that day bound for the West. He had a train of twenty wagons, escorted by 3,000 cavalry under Gen. ECHOLS and BASIL DUKE.
lead_paragraph: Two of our paroled prisoners have arrived at Raleigh, hanging news that JEFF. DAVIS was at Charlote, N.C., on the 25th of April, but that be left on that day bound for the West. He had a train of twenty wagons, escorted by 3,000 cavalry under Gen. ECHOLS and BASIL DUKE. These men were mostly of MORGAN's old command, and were committing all sorts of our rages upon the people. DAVIS had the impudence to make a speech to the people, in which he assured them that he would soon be again on the field with an army larger than ever before.

abstract: and Tab e of Declaration of Independence
snippet: and Tab e of Declaration of Independence
lead_paragraph: There is now living in Charleston a maiden lady -- 84 years of age -- Miss RAMSEY. She is a grand-daughter of HENRY LAURENS, and is connected with the Pinckney and Rutledge families. This lady is the owner of the table on which the Declaration of Independence was signed. When the ordinance of secession was passed in the City of Charleston, by the State of South Carolina, every possible effort was made to obtain this table on which to sign that foul deed. Miss RAMSEY not only indignantly refused to have it taken from her house, but threatened to shoot, with her own hand, the miscreant who should attempt to remove it.

abstract: Correspondence Hon. C. C. Nott
snippet: Correspondence Hon. C. C. Nott
lead_paragraph: It affords us much pleasure to publish the correspondence between Hon. CHARLES C. NOTT, Judge of the Court of Claims (and late Colonel of United States Volunteers) and the Executive Committee of the Protective War Claim Association. It shows the interest a true officer takes in the welfare of those who have risked their lives, and, in many instances, given their limbs in behalf of their country; and we hope it may awaken a responsive echo in the public heart. Now that the war seems to be drawing to its close, and the fair presumption is that not many more of our noble volunteers will be disabled in their country's service, there may be a tendency to forget, in a most important particular, those who have saved the life of the nation. This must not be. Hundreds and thousands of worthy men are returning to their homes from battle-fields where they have received the stroke which unfits them for the duties formerly performed by them, and it now rests with us as individuals, and as a nation, to see that these men shall be provided with work suitable to their crippled condition. We appeal to every private individual and public officer, to see that every situation at their disposal shall be filled by men who have served their country, in preference to those who have not raised an arm in its defence, but who have, during the past four years, lived in ease and safety. Our returned braves have a claim upon us; they have served us faithfully, and it is now our duty to serve them, and we urge upon all, who require employes, to apply at the "Bureau of Employment for Disabled and Discharged Soldiers and Sailors," No. 35 Chambers-street, where can be furnished men of all grades and conditions.
headline: {'main': 'Bureau of Employment for Disabled and Discharged Soldiers and Sailors.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Bureau of Employment for Disabled and Discharged Soldiers and Sailors.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Disbandment of, Astonishing the World
snippet: Disbandment of, Astonishing the World
lead_paragraph: It seems that this country is never able for any length of time to avoid "astonishing the world." We suppose this must be the real "mission" of the United States. The nations of Europe are rarely astonished at anything that takes place in Asia or in Africa. It is rare that any one of them is astonished at anything that takes place in any other one. But all of them seem to be in a condition of ceaseless astonishment at each and every successive development of affairs in the United States. Before the war we astonished them all by our industrial and peaceful republican glories; during the war we have astonished them every day by the wonderful exploits of our soldiers and sailors. We astonished them at the close of last year by carrying through a political campaign and Presidential election in the very heat of the war -- votes being cast, in thousands of cases, in the brief lull of battle; and last month we astonished them by the regularity with which the administration was continued, and the orderliness in which the country maintained itself after the assassination of the Chief of the State. The steamer of yesterday took out a new astonishment for these unhappy people -- the news, that though our gigantic war is but a few days over, we have already begun the disbandment of the great Army of the Union. On this point the Army and Navy Journal of yesterday pertinently remarks: "In a few weeks a very large part of those gallant soldiers who have saved the country from destruction, and crowned it with unfading laurels, will be dispersed. They will go to improve the coming season in tilling the land they have saved, and to set an example of loyal and useful citizenship, such as only our army of citizen-soldiers can furnish. The most singular and striking aspect of the whole scene is, however, the perfect assurance, self-confidence, and independence of foreign criticism, advice, or action, which the country shows in this course. For a month past the English and French press has been filled with articles on the relations of the United States with Canada on the one hand, and with Mexico on the other. All the possibilities of an invasion in either direction have been canvassed. The fall of Richmond, momentous and decisive as it was on the rebellion, was but briefly discussed, in press or in public, upon its intrinsic importance, but its possible influence on the Canada question and the Mexican question, became of the profoundest interest. Like men guilty of beating an antagonist already in a death-struggle with a powerful opponent, and who fear, when he has thrown his adversary to the earth, that he will serve upon them well-merited punishment, England and France watch with intense anxiety the future course of America. What will be the astonishment of those countries when they see that this Western Republic, without the slightest regard to their hopes or their fears, their predictions or their costly preparations, without regard to the daily and excited discussions in Parliament and in the Corps Legislatif; and at the very moment when upon this Mexican and Canadian question, the French Government has proposed an offensive and defensive alliance to protect MAXIMILIAN's ill-gotten Franco-Austrian empire on the one hand, and to protect Canada on the other, our self-reliant republic disbands its armies, sends home its faithful soldiers, closes its recruiting tents, stops its contracts for material, and prepares to abandon the gloomy path of war for the broad and shining highway of peace?"
headline: {'main': '"Astonishing the World."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': '"Astonishing the World."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Queer Attempt at Correction; Fertilizers Deducted from Income Tax; Revenge--Reconstruction--Tribune
snippet: Queer Attempt at Correction; Fertilizers Deducted from Income Tax; Revenge--Reconstruction--Tribune
lead_paragraph: The arrest of Col. OULD and HATCH, rebel Exchange Commissioners, continues to excite attention, and the belief that it is on a charge of misappropriation of supplies and money sent to our prisoners, grows more general. When LEE surrendered, OULD and HATCH were not included in the parole, because it was supposed the bottom of the rebellion was not yet out, and there was much business in their departments still to attend to. They were simply put upon their good behavior while inside our lines. But a cloud seems to have come over their path. Gen. GRANT did not order their arrest, as has been represented. The order came from the War Department.

abstract: Brooklyn Navy-yard, work resumed
snippet: Brooklyn Navy-yard, work resumed
lead_paragraph: A report has just been submitted to Secretary WELLES by Chief Engineer KING, United States Navy, who was cetalied by the Navy Department to report the condition and progress of construction of all the steam machinery, from vessels and iron-clads building from Maine to Missouri. The following resume is interesting: the most important of the contracts yet to be completed are the immense screw engines of 100 inch diameter of cylinders for the six figures building in the navy-yard, and the engines of 60 inched diameter of cylinders for the 20 screw sloops building in the yards. These vessels, when competed will be the best and fastest war vessels in the world. Besides the above, there are three contract frigates, six side-wheel double-enders, nine screw tugs, four double turreted wooden iron-clads, and twenty-four monitors yet to be completed. No more contracts are to be given out. All future vessels built are to be for the ocean, and will be constructed in the navy-yards, and not by contract.

abstract: On the 1st instant MICHAEL GREEN, of No. 207 East Thirteenth-street, fell from his cart in Twenty-fifth-street, near Ninth-avenue, and one of his thighs was broken. He lingered at the New-York Hospital until yesterday morning, when he died. He was a native of Ireland, 30 years of age, and had been employed as a truckman by Messrs. FLANNIGAN, WALLACE & CO., brewers, of No. 300 West Twenty-sixth-st.....An inquest, yesterday morning, at the Fifteenth Ward Police Station, over the body of JAMES W. BARTHOLF, resulted in a verdict of "death from pulmonary phthisis." As stated in yesterday's TIMES, Patrolmen DARKE and BARBALETTE found BARTHOLF sitting on a door-step at No. 676 Broadway, at about 11:30 on Friday evening, and took him to their station-house, where he expired shortly after admission. REBECCA ELLA BARTHOLF, of Staten Island, daughter of the deceased, testified before the jury that her father had been ill two years or more, and Dr. JOHN BEACH, Deputy Coroner, having made a post-mortem examination, deposed that he found the lungs filled with tubercles. Deceased, whom the police characterize as a gambler, was aged 53 years.

abstract: Religious Convictions of
snippet: Religious Convictions of
lead_paragraph: It was publicly stated not long since that a visitor to the President asked him if he loved Jesus. He buried his face in his handkerchief and wept. He then said: "When I left home to take this chair of State, I was not a Christian; when my son died, the severest trial of my life, I was not a Christian. But when I went to Gettysburgh, and locked upon the graves of those who had fallen in defence of their country, I then and there consecrated myself to Christ. I do love Jesus."

abstract: About 3 o'clock yesterday morning, the Erie Railway car manufactory, situated near the east end of the Bergen Tunnel, took fire and was entirely destroyed, together with nearly all its contents. The manufactory comprised two buildings, one four hundred and fifty feet long and eighty feet wide, and the other three hundred feet long and seventy-five feet wide. Five cars were standing in the shop when the fire broke out, and three of them, unfinished, were burned up, while the others were seriously damaged. All the buildings were of wood, and as the wind blew briskly from the direction of the machine shop toward the car and blacksmith shops, they were also in flames in the course of a few minutes. The stoppage of the manufacture of cars at this shop, which has produced as many as one hundred and twenty-five a month of some kinds, (particularly of coal cars,) and sixty of all kinds on the average for the past year and a half, will be perhaps a greater loss to the company than the sum of money involved in the fire. There are other shops, however, and the Jersey City business [???] be transferred to Piermont.

lead_paragraph: THE STREET-CLEANING COMMISSION. -- The newly-appointed Street-Cleaning Commission, comprising the Mayor, Comptroller, City Inspector, Corporation Counsel and Recorder, met on Saturday afternoon in the Mayor's office. His Honor was elected Chairman and the Recorder appointed Secretary. Tne Corporation Counsel was directed to draw up specifications for the work of cleaning the streets, and submit them to the commission at its next meeting. The commission then adjourned to Monday next, at 4 P.M.

abstract: the Old and New
snippet: the Old and New
lead_paragraph: The life and strength of the old Democratic party was its national spirit. From its earliest history this never failed to assert itself clearly, fervently, we may say, indeed, fiercely, on every question involving the preservation, or the enlargement, or the honor and glory of the country. In our great controversies with England, with France, with Mexico, it was peculiarly the war party. In every minor dispute with other nations, it was always the party most, apt to plant itself on high pretentions and extreme claims. In our domestic affairs it was the party that always labored most earnestly to put down sectional discord, and to strengthen the bonds of the Union.
headline: {'main': 'The Old and the New Democracy.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Old and the New Democracy.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mill, John Stuart, on Parliamentary Reform
snippet: Mill, John Stuart, on Parliamentary Reform
lead_paragraph: Mr. JOHN STUART MILL, as our readers are aware, has been brought forward in the Liberal interest as a candidate for the representation of Westminster in the British House of Commons. For such a position Mr. MILL is believed to be fitted not less by his profound training as a student of political science, than by his long experience in a vastly important department of the civil administration -- that of the government of India. By his opponents Mr. MILL's unequated skill as a reasoner is readily admitted. But he is represented as a mere theorist, whose views are so far from being practical, that even the most advanced of his own party would not dare venture to follow where he would lead. There is just a grain of truth in this estimate of his character as a politician, sufficient to give plausibility to the objections urged against his candidature alike by Tories and so-called Conservative Whigs. Mr. MILL is unquestionably far in advance of his party on all the broad questions of political philosophy. But he has never sought to conceal from himself or from others that he does not expect, in the present state of public education in England, to carry into practical effect a tithe of the reforms which he thinks will one day be introduced into the fundamental laws of the United Kingdom. He might be called a visionary, were he going to Parliament to urge the introduction of what has been called a "fancy franchise." But he proposes to accept a seat in the House of Commons -- if it is tendered to him voluntarily -- with no such purpose before him.

lead_paragraph: TROUBLES OF A FOREIGN CONSUL. -- A gentleman named HEMRICHS, who is said to be Consul for Strasburg at New-York, and who resides near the Centreville Racecourse, L.I., has recently experienced considerable trouble from his neighbors, who persist in maintaining that he has a batch of Secessionists from LEE's army at his house, some of them wearing the Confederate uniform. Two of the party, it is asserted, are his own sons. An officer from Major DODGE's headquarters yesterday visited Mr. HEMRICHS, to ascertain the truth of these allegations, but was satisfied with the explanations of that gentleman.

abstract: Family Marketing in New-York
snippet: Family Marketing in New-York
lead_paragraph: During the war, housekeepers have been tormented and perplexed by the continuous rise in the price of all the luxuries and necessities of the domestic economy. From day to day prices have gone up, until it became a matter of serious consideration with the great mass of consumers how they should contrive to sustain the heavy expenses so determinedly thrust upon them, and in a great number of cases many have had to exercise the strictest economy or inaugurate a system of healthy retrenchment in matters never dreamed of before.

abstract: Officer SOULES, of the Fourteenth Ward, appeared with JOHN McGRAEFF, of No. 221 Canal-street, and THOMAS F. MURRAY, of No. 421 Broadway, whom he had arrested while they were engaged in mortal combat in the latter's place of business, at about 3 o'clock yesterday morning. MURRAY's head was frightfully beaten in the fight, and McGRAEFF was stabbed in the back and right side.
lead_paragraph: Officer SOULES, of the Fourteenth Ward, appeared with JOHN McGRAEFF, of No. 221 Canal-street, and THOMAS F. MURRAY, of No. 421 Broadway, whom he had arrested while they were engaged in mortal combat in the latter's place of business, at about 3 o'clock yesterday morning. MURRAY's head was frightfully beaten in the fight, and McGRAEFF was stabbed in the back and right side. PETER F. CRANE, who is alleged to have been a participant in the encounter, was also arrested, and subsequently Officer DOWDELL, of the Tombs Court, apprehended one MICHAEL WALSH, the person who is alleged to have used the knife. The prisoners were committed for examination.

abstract: About 3 o'clock on Saturday morning, the Erie Railway car manufactory, situated near the east end of the Bergen Tunnel, took fire and was entirely destroyed, together with nearly all its contents. The manufactory comprised two buildings, one four hundred and fifty feet long and eighty feet wide, and the...
lead_paragraph: About 3 o'clock on Saturday morning, the Erie Railway car manufactory, situated near the east end of the Bergen Tunnel, took fire and was entirely destroyed, together with nearly all its contents. The manufactory comprised two buildings, one four hundred and fifty feet long and eighty feet wide, and the other three hundred feet long and seventy-five feet wide. Five cars were standing in the shop when the fire broke out, and three of them, unfinished, were burned up, while the others were seriously damaged. All the buildings were of wood, and as the wind blew briskly from the direction of the machine shop toward the car and blacksmith shops, they were also in flames in the course of a few minutes. The stoppage of the manufacture of cars at this shop, which has produced as many as one hundred and twenty-five a month of some kinds, (particularly of coal cars,) and sixty of all kinds on the average for the past year and a half, will be perhaps a greater loss to the company than the sum of money involved in the fire. There are other shops, however, and the Jersey City business will be transferred to Piermont.

abstract: A frightful accident occurred on Friday last on the Erie Railroad, by which the express train leaving Buffalo the previous evening, was precipitated through the bridge spanning the Conestoga River. Three passengers were killed, and several others seriously injured. The company considered the bridge safe, it having been rebuilt some three years ago.

abstract: The Times City Article of Tuesday, April 25, says: "An active business and some considerable fluctuations were expected in the funds this morning, (Monday,) in consequence of the American news, but the transactions have been limited and the changes in price of consols merely fractional. Consols closed at 90 3/4@1/8. There was very little demand for discount at the Bank to-day and in the Stock Exchange loans were offered at 2 1/2@3. Confederate Loan closed 13 at 15. The war excitement in America being now virtually at an end, the financial question becomes the grand one. During the next three months, the most extensive speculative operations of the two hemispheres will depend upon it.

abstract: Anecdote
snippet: Anecdote
lead_paragraph: AND HIS FATHER. -- Young WADE HAMPTOM was sent, when a very young man, to the West with a large sum of money to buy land. His father was very rich. When young WADE reached New-Orleans, he had a desire to look at the pictures and see the sights. He went one evening to a gambling-house, and was induced to play at a faro-table. He was cleaned out, having lost twenty-five thousand dollars. He wrote to his father and confessed his folly and his loss. The old gentleman came on to New-Orleans, and caused his son to point out the gambling-house where he lost his money. Dropping in he looked at the play for a while and then threw down a purse upon the table. He lost, and the keeper emptied the purse of five hundred dollars in gold. He threw down another purse, and this time he was a winner. The keeper opened the purse and counting the gold was about to pay over the amount won, when Mr. HAMPTON remarked that he had not emptied it of all its contents. A little examination discovered in the purse a check for twenty-five thousand dollars, which had been so concealed that it would not fall out with the gold. The keeper of the bank made no objection to paying over the sum, which Mr. HAMPTON quietly put in his pocket and walked off. The next morning he handed the twenty-five thousand dollars to his son, told him to be more careful of his money, never to gamble again, but to go about his business and complete his purchase of land. -- Troy Whig.
headline: {'main': 'A HARD STORY ABOUT GEN. WADE HAMPTON', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A HARD STORY ABOUT GEN. WADE HAMPTON', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Central Park Base Ball Ground, The
snippet: Central Park Base Ball Ground, The
lead_paragraph: In the Central Park a large held is set apart and known as a Base Ball Ground, but thus far it has been a ball field only in name, the commissioners having refused all applications for its use, even from the National Association of Base Ball players, who desired to use the field as a neutral ground in playing the third games in home and home matches. Inasmuch as up to the present season the cricket grounds of the Park have alike been unattainable by the cricket clubs of the metropolis, who have applied for the use of the field for match games, the decision of the commissioners in the matter has been quietly acquiesced in; but now that English cricketers have been allowed the privilege of playing their national game on the cricket field of the Park, it is hoped American Base Ball players will be allowed the use of the ball grounds of the Park for playing their national game. It appears that the principal objections of the Park Commissioners to the use of either field is, that the turf will be injured and partially destroyed by practicing these games, and also that the crowds of spectators, each contest attracts, will lead to infringements of the rules and regulations of the Park in reference to walking on the grass, &c.

abstract: REIMBURSEMENT OF DRAFTED MEN UNDER THE STATE BOUNTY LAW. -- The office of the Paymaster General of the State of New-York, recently established at No. 544 Broadway, by Brig.-Gen. S.E. MARVIN, in connection with his Department Headquarters in Albany, is in charge of the Assistant Paymaster-General. Col. C.W. DARLING, and now presents a very busy appearance. Large numbers of visitors are each day calling with their exemption certificates, showing that they have furnished substitutes for one, two and three years. Blank forms which are necessary to be filled up in accordance with the requirements of the department are provided at the office.

abstract: Two of our paroled prisoners have arrived at Raleigh, bringing news that JEFF. DAVIS was at Charlotte, N.C., on the 25th of April, but that he left on that day bound for the West. He had a train of twenty wagons, escorted by 3,000 cavalry under Gen. ECHOLS and BASIL DUKE. These men were mostly of MORGAN's old command, and were committing all sorts of outrages upon the people. DAVIS had the impudence to make a speech to the people, in which he assured them that he would soon be again on the field with an army larger than ever before.

abstract: Inquiry among the fruit-growers and farmers affords very pleasing information as to the prospects of the seasons in their important departments of industry and production. Fruit of all kinds most cultivated hereabouts promises well. The trees have withstood the Winter and have budded in a promising manner. May has opened mildly, and there is reason to hope that no frost will blight the tender fruit. Bountiful crops of peaches, apples, bears, cherries, plums, grapes and strawberries, will yield those who cultivate in Western New-York hundreds of thousands of dollars, and afford pleasure to all who consume these luxuries that Providence permits us to enjoy in this favored climate. The reports from the fields are no less favorable than from the orchards. The farmers began their Spring work pretty early, and accomplished more in the way of planting and sowing in April this year than in any that has preceded for a long time. The weather has been opportune. Owing to the scarcity of help more time was requisite. But little ground will go uncultivated for want of labor, as the hoeing, haying and harvesting times come along there will be plenty of laborers from the returning army at the South. The Fall sown crops -- wheat, rye and barley promise well. The Winter and the Spring were as favorable as the farmer could desire. We may congratulate the farmers and all others of Western of New-York -- for all are interested in the success of the crops -- an the prospect the season affords.  -- Rochester Union.

abstract: A mortal combat occurred at about six o'clock yesterday morning in ANDREW MULLIGAN'S liquorstore, No. 76 Essex-street, corner of Broome, and SAMUEL McMAHON, of No. 150 Fifth-street, suffered a compound fracture of the skull, which, it is believed, must result in death. It appears that a gang of...
lead_paragraph: A mortal combat occurred at about six o'clock yesterday morning in ANDREW MULLIGAN'S liquorstore, No. 76 Essex-street, corner of Broome, and SAMUEL McMAHON, of No. 150 Fifth-street, suffered a compound fracture of the skull, which, it is believed, must result in death. It appears that a gang of roughs who were in the place quarreled upon a matter of no importance whatever, and at length engaged in a general fight, in which knives, decanters and clubs were used, and several half-drunken loungers were stabbed and otherwise injured. MULLIGAN, the landlord, fearing that if the hostilities continued his house might be demolished, found a club and entered into the midst of the combatants and soon quelled the rioters, not, however, until MCMAHON had received a probably mortal blow. This was the work of only a few minutes; but it awakened the neighborhood and attracted the attention of Patrolman SWETT, of the Tenth Ward, and that officer entered upon the scene and apprehended MULLIGAN and ANDREW MCNULTY, and took them to Justice SHANDLEY's court. Police Surgeon WATERMAN having been summoned, dressed MCMAHON's wounds and instructed the Tenth Ward Police to take him to his abode. On the hearing at court, MULLIGAN, whom the Justice committed to await, the result of MCMAHON's injuries, preferred a complaint against ANDREW MCNULTY for assault and battery, and MCNULTY was required to give $300 bail to appear for trial at the Court of Special Sessions. Yesterday afternoon MCMAHON's ante-mortem deposition was taken by Coroner GOVER.

abstract: Bounty Jumper, Tossed in a Blanket
snippet: Bounty Jumper, Tossed in a Blanket
lead_paragraph: HALES was yesterday formally initiated into the O.W.B.B.S. of U.S., (Order of Well-Beloved Swindlers of Uncle Sam.) I.C. of U.B.J., (Inner Circle of Unlucky Bounty-Jumpers,) A.S.I.C. of P.M.P., (Albany Squad in Clutches of Provost-Marshal PARSONS.) For the information of our readers we will describe the manner of initiation into this squad of the inner circle of these swindlers. Whenever a beloved brother graduates from the outer circle, which operates freely in the outer world, loses his standing in that circle, and from lack of shrewdness falls into the hands of the Provost-Marshal, the Marshal details one of the guard to act as Grand Usher, and conduct him into the inner temple, where he is received by those who have preceded him, who immediately proceed to divest him of all his apparel, save his shirt and pants. They then place him on a large blanket, and a sufficient number take hold of the corners and sides, and elevate him into mid-air, and then toss him up and down. Now he strikes the ceiling. Anon, the blanket is slacked, and he reaches the floor. Again, by rapid movements, he files quickly between the two. During all this time it behooves the candidate for orders to hold his temper and his tongue, else sundry rapid evolutions from side to side, caused by the brawny palms of his worthy companions, might be the result. So he silently, and often with grim smiles, rides this new-fashioned "goat" until it is the will of the Inductors into the Inner Circle to cease their initiatory rites.

abstract: Very little of interest happened on Saturday in the matter of the Fire Department. The new Board of Commissioners have engaged Mr. WALDO HUTCHINGS as their counsel in the legal proceedings now about commencing. The necessary papers will at once be put on file and the matter pushed to a speedy action. The Chief Engineer of the old department has issued an order to officers and members of the department, desiring them to do duty, and await quietly the decision of the courts.

abstract: Discourse to Congregational Union
snippet: Discourse to Congregational Union
lead_paragraph: The anniversary of the Congregational Union was celebratad at Plymouth Church last evening, a very large audience being present. After prayer by Rev. HENRY WARD BEECHER, the Secretary of the Union read the annual report, showing that about $14,000 had been subscribed during the year, and that a balance of about $2,000 still remained unexpended. It was stated that at least $50,000 per annum was required by the Union to enable it to carry out the work it had undertaken. Three new churches have been organized during the year in Philadelphia, one in Canterbury, Del., and one in Baltimore.

abstract: Europe, News of Death of in
snippet: Europe, News of Death of in
lead_paragraph: The news of President LINCOLN's murder, as was anticipated, has produced not only a thrill of horror throughout Europe, but a feeling of profound sympathy for the United States as well. Lord RUSSELL, in the British House of Lords, and the Home Secretary, in the absence of the Premier, in the Commons, gave notice of addresses (to be moved on Monday, the 1st of May,) to the Queen, praying her to convey an expression of the national feeling to the United States Government. The principal commercial bodies of the British Kingdom met and gave expression to their intense feelings of horror and sorrow.

abstract: Sermon to American Christian Union; Female Guardian Society, Anniversary
snippet: Sermon to American Christian Union; Female Guardian Society, Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The churches of this city and Brooklyn found large accessions to their usual congregations yesterday, in the strangers -- both clerical and lay -- who are here to take part in the anniversaries of the various religious and reformatory bodies, which are to be held during the next few days. The initiatory exercises of "Anniversary Week" were opened last night by the preaching in four of the churches of annual sermons, an idea of which discourses we present below. It is believed that the proceedings of the week will be of extraordinary interest, especially in the case of the American Anti-Slavery Society, a portion of whose prominent members, including WILLIAM LLOYD GARRISON, we believe, are of opinion that it has fulfilled its mission and should be disbanded, while another portion, among whom is WENDELL PHILLIPS, consider that its disorganization now would be premature.

abstract: Even the news of LEE's surrender has failed to drive the rebel cotton loan entirely out of the market. It still maintains its hold on the affections of a small sympathizing party of capitalists, at the slightly reduced quotation of 11. At this rate the three-million sterling loan has brought the sympathizers already to grief, to the tune of thirteen million dollars, or thereabout. And it must be additionally consoling for the hopeful leaders in this case to find that before the final collapse of the Confederacy, its principal foreign financial agency had been transferred from London to Havana, where, we believe, there are no interest accounts payable.
lead_paragraph: Even the news of LEE's surrender has failed to drive the rebel cotton loan entirely out of the market. It still maintains its hold on the affections of a small sympathizing party of capitalists, at the slightly reduced quotation of 11. At this rate the three-million sterling loan has brought the sympathizers already to grief, to the tune of thirteen million dollars, or thereabout. And it must be additionally consoling for the hopeful leaders in this case to find that before the final collapse of the Confederacy, its principal foreign financial agency had been transferred from London to Havana, where, we believe, there are no interest accounts payable.

abstract: When the St. George Club lost their grounds at Hoboken, this Spring, the made immediate application to the Central Park Commissioners for the use of the Park cricket ground, but it was not until Wednesday last that permission to use the field was granted. On that day, however, they met in force...
lead_paragraph: When the St. George Club lost their grounds at Hoboken, this Spring, the made immediate application to the Central Park Commissioners for the use of the Park cricket ground, but it was not until Wednesday last that permission to use the field was granted. On that day, however, they met in force on the cricket-field of the Park, and, selecting sides, composed of an equal number of the bachelors and benedicts of the club, they prayed a lively and interesting game of one innings, the result being the defeat of the bachelors. This done, they all adjourned to the Central Park Hotel, where the players and a number of invited guests sat down to dinner, a number of the Park officials being among the latter. The game was merely an experimental one, arranged for the purpose of affording the commissioners an opportunity of judging of the extent of the injury the turf would be liable to from playing cricket on the field. What their ultimate decision in the matter will be is not yet known, but if they grant the use of the cricket-field to English cricketers, they must of course allow American base-ball players the privilege of the ball-ground of the Park.

abstract: At Williamsburgh
snippet: At Williamsburgh
lead_paragraph: FIREMEN's FIGHTS -- ARREST OF FOUR OF THE BELLIGERENTS. -- Yesterday afternoon a man named KELLY was badly beaten by some men who were on bad terms with the company from which he halled. KELLY then applied to his friends of Engine No. 1, situated at the corner of North Second and Third streets, for help. He succeeded in getting a large crowd together at the corner of North Eighth and Fifth streets, where KELLY and his assailants also assembled. The latter were composed principally of members and friends of Hose Company No. 10, whose house is situated in Sixth-street, near North Second. The battle then opened and raged furiously for a short time, when Capt. WOGLOM and Sergt. MADDOX, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, with a posse of men came on the ground on a double quick, when the rioters dispersed and fled in all directions. Some time after this, a party of Engine Co. 1's men were passing Hose Co. 10's house, when they were assaulted by the latter, it is said, and another and more serious fight took place, in which the hose-cartmen were badly defeated, seeking refuge in their house and closing the door. Four of them then ascended to the roof and threw missiles on the crowd below, injuring severely several persons. Sergt. MADDOX and some men again made their appearance and forced the door of the house, intending to arrest those on the roof, but finding the ladder gone, they were unable to ascend. They then ordered the rioters to surrender, but this was at first refused. After considerable parley, however, they capitulated unconditionally, and were taken to the station-house and looked up. Their names are WALTER BASTWICK, MICHAEL QUINN, PATRICK CONNISKY, and HUGH MORAN.

lead_paragraph: The annual sermon on behalf of the American and Foreign Christian Union was preached last evening in the Thirteenth-street Presbyterian Church, (Dr. BURCHARD'S,) by the Rev. C.S. ROBINSON, of Brooklyn. The spacious edifice was crowded by an intellectual and interested audience. Rev. Dr. CAMPBELL presided, and read the fifth chapter of Romans, followed by an impressive prayer by Rev. Mr. VAN CLEVE, of Jersey City, Rev. Mr. ROBINSON then preached an eloquent sermon on the growth, errors, and aggressions of the Roman Catholic Church, choosing for his text the twenty-first chapter of Isaiah, eleventh and twelfth verses:

abstract: The steamship America from Southampton, April 20, at this port, and the Hibernian, from Liverpool, April 28, at Point Au Basque, we have five days' later news from Europe. The intelligence of the assassination of President LINCOLN created intense horror and grief throughout Europe. Official notice of the event was taken in the English Parliament, and it was voted to prepare an address to the Queen in reference to it. At London, Paris, and other cities, the expression of detestation and horror at the crime was universal. Mr. MASON issued a card, denying the complicity of the South with the the bloody deed. The English press continue to comment on American affairs, generally admitting the utter downfall of the Confederacy. The Czarwitch is dead. The King of Belgium has been very sick, but is recovering.

abstract: MILITARY FUNERALS. -- The remains of the late Maj. EMIL DUYSING, formerly Colonel of the Forty-first New-York Volunteers, and late of the Fifteenth New-York Artillery, were yesterday consigned to their last resting-place. The deceased was an officer in the Prussian army, and participated in the battles in Holstein. He was promoted for gallant conduct, but becoming dissatisfied with the service, emigrated to this country and engaged in mercantile pursuits in New-York. When the war broke out he offered his services and they were accepted. He was chosen Lieutenant-Colonel of the Forty-first Regiment, and subsequently was transferred to the Fifteenth Artillery. He participated in a number of the hardest fought battles of the war, and was wounded at Five Forks, from the effects of which he died. The funeral services were held at No. 192 Atlantic-street, and were attended by a large concourse of citizens, Anglo Saxon Lodge F.A.M., and the officers of the Fourteenth and DeKalb Regiments. The remains were escorted to Greenwood Cemetery by the Ninety-sixth Regiment, National Guard, Col. KREHBIEL. The deceased was 38 years of age. He was highly esteemed for his personal worth as well as his military efficiency....The funeral services of the late CHARLES RODGERS, a member of Company B, Thirteenth Regiment, National Guard, took place in the Middle Dutch Reformed Church in Joralemon-street, yesterday afternoon. He served with the regiment in the three-months' campaign in Pennsylvania, where he contracted disease which eventually resulted in his death. His remains were conveyed to Greenwood Cemetery, escorted by the company to which he had been attached.

abstract: Flight from Montreal; And Tucker, the Flight of
snippet: Flight from Montreal; And Tucker, the Flight of
lead_paragraph: No one acquainted with the history of those leading rebel spies who have been playing the alternate roles of peace commissioners and cut-throat conspirators in the neighboring provinces can be at all surprised to learn that SANDERS and TUCKER have tied from Montreal. Had there been nothing else to point to their complicity with the assassins, they have merited suspicion, ever since the murder was committed, by protesting too much. But aside altogether from the guilty bearing of these outlaws, the direct evidence against them has been accumulating so fast, that even that easy tribunal, wherein COURSOL and SMITH shed the lustre of their genius upon British jurisprudence, seemed to have terrors for the conspirators too strong to abide. They are therefore reported missing by their friends in the provinces -- missing within twenty-four hours after pretending in a published declaration to court a trial within the jurisdiction of the United States.

abstract: Amnesty Order; Gen. Halleck's Order on
snippet: Amnesty Order; Gen. Halleck's Order on
lead_paragraph: The amnesty order issued from Richmond on the 3d of May by Major-Gen. HALLECK is the most important and significant of recent military documents. In form it is merely a letter of instructions from the officer commanding the new Military Division of the James, to his subordinate commanding the Department of Virginia. But, in fact, it is the first definite official disclosure of the policy of President JOHNSON's administration with regard to the treatment of the lately insurgent Southern people. The well-known confidential advisory position held until recently by Gen. HALLECK at Washington, his selection, consequently, for command at Richmond, that great head and front of the rebellion, and his assignment to the special duty of fixing the status of loyalty or disloyalty in the Division of the James, all show that our inferences are correct.

abstract: Miners' Strike in Pennsylvania
snippet: Miners' Strike in Pennsylvania
lead_paragraph: The strike among the coal-miners in the vicinity or Mahoning still continues, and, with one or two exceptions, none of the banks there are being worked. The state or the case is briefly stated thus; Coal has fallen in Cleveland from $10@$12 to $7@$7 50 per ton, rendering it impossible for the proprietors of the mines to sell their coat at any profit without reducing the wages of their workmen. In fact it became absolutely necessary to do this, to avoid a heavy loss. Notice was therefore given that after a certain date a reduction of forty cents per ton would be made in the price for mining coal, making the wages of miners amount to three dollars per day, instead of over four, as during the last Fall and Winter. The miners refused to work on these terms. They therefore "struck," and are now all out of employment, except such as are called "blacklegs" or "black sheep" -- that is, men who do not belong to the miners' unions, and who work for lower wages than those prescribed by these associations. -- Pittsburgh Chronicle, May 3.

abstract: It is announced, somewhat abruptly as it seems to us, that the season of German Opera will end with this evening's performance. We have of course seen, and with constant regret, that the attendance was not of a remunerative character, but the Academy has not been worse off in this respect than any other place of amusement.
lead_paragraph: It is announced, somewhat abruptly as it seems to us, that the season of German Opera will end with this evening's performance. We have of course seen, and with constant regret, that the attendance was not of a remunerative character, but the Academy has not been worse off in this respect than any other place of amusement. The mute agony of that terrible 14th of April, has not yet been comforted. With the last few days there has, however, been a more cheerful disposition on the part of the public, and we certainly expect that Mr. GROVER would be able to profit by it. He is the very last man to be discouraged. We have not in fact heard him complain. Still, as we see it announced that the season will posivively close with to-night's performance of "Les Huguenots," we may reasonably conclude that he has urgent reasons for his course of action. The business, in truth, has been bad, and the company quarrelsome. So far as the members of the latter are concerned, it became absolutely necessary to disband them, and so dispose of certain antagonistic elements which interfered with the free action of the management. Mr. GROVER, who has, we believe, prospered with the German opera, will, we presume, speedily crystalize a new company. The public will be glad to see him return to management, for he has displayed energy and a desire to please. In the meantime the wreck will drift through the country. There will be half a dozen German opera companies, and in six months as many failures. No one should neglect the opportunity of hearing MEYERBEER's grandest work to-night. It is excellently rendered by Mr. GROVER's artists. The matinee on Saturday was, of course, badly attended. Who could be expected to go through such weather even for "Faust?" The distribution of the parts was not particularly interesting. Mlle. CANISSA, who appeared in the character of Marguerite, lacks voice, method, and personal appearance for the role. She cannot be favorably compared with Mlle. FREDERICI, who at least possess two or three essentials. The same remark applies, but with less force, to the Siebel of Mlle. DJIUBA, heretofore played by Madame JOHANNSEN.

abstract: Yesterday, on the morning train from Big Black, the rebel Gen. HODGE, and Cols. HENDERSON and WATTS, came into the city on an official visit to the military authorities here. They stopped at the Washington Hotel, and were well received by our military officers as well as citizens. They left on the afternoon train for Big Black, after an interview of several hours with Gens. DANA and SMITH.

abstract: Surrender

lead_paragraph: The absolute surrender of DICK TAYLOR, the only rebel commander east of the Mississippi, is positively announced by a telegram from Gen. WILSON, at Macon, to the War Department. There are now no organized rebel forces east of the Mississippi, and guerrillas become outlaws, to be hunted without mercy.

abstract: London Times on President Lincoln's Death and President Johnson; Europe, His Death in
snippet: London Times on President Lincoln's Death and President Johnson; Europe, His Death in
lead_paragraph: The fuller details which we publish to-day of the effect produced abroad by the report of President LINCOLN's death, show the vast influence which the foreign policy of his administration has, all along, exercised on the political mind of Europe. It was never till now made so perfectly clear how thoroughly Western Europe, in spite of the prevailing sympathies with the rebellion, respected the honesty of purpose, the firmness yet temperateness of character, and the perfect purity of motive which appertained to all the official acts of the late Executive. We hear, without perhaps more interest than we attach to the natural condolence of friendship, the touching tributes paid to the memory of the dead President by the high-minded journalists of London, who have stood by us unwaveringly through all this bloody trial. We have tested their sympathy often on other occasions more or less calamitous, and we anticipated that now it would be what it has always been, free, generous, and intelligent. From the hostile press, on the other hand, nothing could be looked for beyond a decent regard to propriety in whatever it might say of the murder, or whatever results it might predicate thereupon. The pro-rebel British journals, among them the London Times, have gone -- whether wittingly or not, we cannot say -- much further than this, in attempting to give their own expression to the public sentiment. The "leading journal " discovers that "nothing in political history has ever drawn forth a more unanimous feeling," than the news of Mr. LINCOLN's death. "Personally," we are told, "President LINCOLN enjoyed the kind regards of every one in England." And again it says: "The extent to which his influence was estimated in upholding amicable relations between England and the United States, has been shown by a fall of unusual severity in all classes of securities."
headline: {'main': "The Political Effect in Europe of President Lincoln's Death.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "The Political Effect in Europe of President Lincoln's Death.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found, in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: New-York, Brennan, E., Trial of H. A. Main
snippet: New-York, Brennan, E., Trial of H. A. Main
lead_paragraph: At the opening of the court, yesterday morning, John Gallagher convicted last week of committing a robbery at the house of Mr. Daniel Leroy, was brought up for sentence. His Honor said that the statement of the prisoner after his conviction, and the remarks of counsel and Defective Farly, to the effect that the man was innocent had led the jury to think that they might have been mistaken in their verdict. The Court had looked into this matter carefully, and was satisfied of the prisoner's guilt. He was sent to the State Prison for two years.

abstract: Released from Arrest
snippet: Released from Arrest
lead_paragraph: The Springfield State Journal has been shown by some gentlemen from Iowa the identical "Kirkham's Grammar" which Mr. LINCOLN studied while living in Petersburgh, Menard County, Illinois, about the year 1830. It was presented by Mr. LINCOLN to the present Capt. R.B. RUTLEDGE, now of Burlington, Iowa, with whose father Mr. LINCOLN boarded at the time. It originally boreupon a fly-leaf the name of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, with these not unfamiliar lines, "steal not this book, &c.," but this has been torn out by subsequent usage. The volume, which is highly valued for its associations, is still the property of Capt. RUTLEDGE.

abstract: Seven-Thirty Loan; Copperhead Sneers at; Emigration Scheme; Sig. Romero's Letter; Cavalry, our, Should be Retained
snippet: Seven-Thirty Loan; Copperhead Sneers at; Emigration Scheme; Sig. Romero's Letter; Cavalry, our, Should be Retained
lead_paragraph: There can be no harm in associations of enterprising and muscular young men being formed for carrying out a scheme of peaceable emigration to Mexico. There is plenty of room for any number of emigrants in that country, as there is in our own great West. The difference is something in climate, and very much more in the political and social state of things that await the adventurer it Mexico. This, we presume, intelligent emigrants understand full well. Let us also hope they understand that it is not the time for volunteer missions designed for the regeneration of Mexico, Nicaragua, Cuba, Japan, or any other indifferently-governed community. There is a class of mischief-making journalists bent at the present time on presenting visionary schemes of military adventure to tickle visionary and thoughtless young men who may think of settling in Mexico. They are no friends of the government of the United States, and no friends of our discharged volunteers -- who are mainly intended to be influenced -- that propose such irresponsible enterprises. No doubt much exciting and apparently patriotic discourse may be indulged in respecting the French invasion of Mexico. But those who urge filibustering enterprises at this crisis -- whether they are friends of the Mexican Republic or not, are enemies of the United States.

abstract: DANIEL O'CONNELL and FRANCIS KINNEY fought in Vandewater-street, near Pearl, at about 9 o'clock on Sunday night, and O'CONNELL received a severe stab in the abdomen. He was taken to Bellevue Hospital, and Patrolman HORBELT, of the Fourth Ward, apprehended KINNEY and took him to the Tombs. The prisoner was committed to await the result of O'CONNELL'S wound.

abstract: Yesterday was barren of interest so far as regards the Fire Department. Everything remains in status quo, and the commissioners only held an informal meeting, transacting no business of importance. There seems to be considerable dispute regarding the actual power of the new board. The old department claim that the new commissioners have no authority over their actions, inasmuch as an injunction has been served upon them, restraining them from taking possession of the apparatus of the old department.
