abstract: Fine Art Association of Brooklyn; Brooklyn Art Association Incorporated as Fine Art Association
snippet: Fine Art Association of Brooklyn; Brooklyn Art Association Incorporated as Fine Art Association
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN BOARD OF ALDERMEN.--The board met last evening, Alderman WHITNEY, the President in the chair. A communication from the Mayor was received, calling the attention of the board to the neglected and disgraceful condition of Washington Park, stating that the walks should be graded, trees planted, shrubbery arranged, and that the whole required to be inclosed with a substantial iron railing. Its eleveted position, and the historical associations connected with it, should prompt the authorities to fix it up in a manner worthy of the city. Attention was also called to the condition of Carroll Park. The Mayor recommended that seats should be placed in the walks, and placards placed warning visitors to keep off the grass. He also suggested that the gates be closed at 9 o'clock during the Summer months. Both communications were referred to the Committee on Parks. The City Railroad Company was authorized to place a switch near the junction of Flatbush and Fifth-avenues, with the view of enabling them to furnish more accommodations on the Flatbush-avenue line. A resolution was adopted directing the removal of Justice MOREHOUSE's court from the Forty-fourth Precinct Station-house, and Justice WALTERS' court from the Forty-fifth Precinct Station-house. Both station houses are required for the use of the police force. Considerable routine business was transacted and the board adjourned.

abstract: ACADEMY OF MUSIC.--There was an exceedingly fine house last evening to witness the final representation of "Les Huguenots," and the regret was general that it should, indeed, be the only remaining opportunity of hearing MEYERBEER'S grand work. Mr. GROVER'S season terminated with the evening, and for the present, at least, we shall have no more of German singers or German music.
lead_paragraph: ACADEMY OF MUSIC. -- There was an exceedingly fine house last evening to witness the final representation of "Les Huguenots," and the regret was general that it should, indeed, be the only remaining opportunity of hearing MEYERBEER'S grand work. Mr. GROVER'S season terminated with the evening, and for the present, at least, we shall have no more of German singers or German music. The opera was rendered with the same effect that we recorded on the occasion of its first production here a few nights ago. It is unnecessary to speak in detail of a combination which we shall probably never hear again. The artists, orchestra and chorus were generally all good, and the satisfaction of the audience was complete.

abstract: Union, Campaign Paper, Hayes vs. Charlick Suit; Hayes vs. Charlick; Union newspaper Suit
snippet: Union, Campaign Paper, Hayes vs. Charlick Suit; Hayes vs. Charlick; Union newspaper Suit
lead_paragraph: Wm.M. Hayes vs. Oliver Charlick. -- This action was brought by the plaintiff, Mr. Hayes, to recover the sum of $10,000 damages, which he alleges he has sustained by reason of the unlawful conduct of the defendant. It appears from the pleadings and testimony which has been given, that on the 2d day of November, 1861, the plaintiff was the printer, if not the proprietor, of a campaign newspaper, known as the Union. It was only a few days prior to the State election. Mr. Charlick, was a prominent candidate for office. The paper, which was published at No. 16 Spruce-street, had the preceding day, an article which, as the defendant claims, was highly offensive and very much calculated to injure him politically and socially. Mr. Charlick went legally to work, to bring the offender to justice. He procured a warrant from Justice Quackenbush, at that time presiding at the Jefferson Market Police Court, placed it in the hands of two officers, and the latter went for the purpose of effecting the arrest of the plaintiff in this suit. What there transpired appears from the testimony of Mr. Hayes, the plaintiff, who was put upon the stand, and testified substantially as follows:

abstract: British Concern about
snippet: British Concern about
lead_paragraph: It is imagined generally in England that the United States, now that the rebellion is overthrown, will soon attempt to get possession of Canada, either by violence or by negotiation. Parliament debates solemnly how best to fortity and defend it; and a great deal is said in the press about the expediency of letting it go rather than fight for it. A question is made whether it is consistent with the honor of England to abandon colonists who insist upon protection; and another question is raised, whether England can afford to cede a colony to a foreign Power, even if its own people should wish it.

lead_paragraph: The deaths in New York during the past week numbered 472 -- 113 men, 103 women, 128 boys, and 128 girls -- an increase of 35 from the mortality of the previous week, and a decrease of 37 as compared with the mortality of the corresponding week of 1864. Of the deceased 210 were children under 5 years of age. The mortality by the principal diseases was as follows: Consumption, 81; infantile convulsions, 39; infantile marasmus, 28; inflammation of the lungs, 37; smallpox, 28; typhus fever, 12; disease of heart, 14; scarlet fever, 9.

abstract: Home for Disabled Soldiers. (United States Sanitary Commission); Homes for Disabled Soldiers (U. S. San. Com.)
snippet: Home for Disabled Soldiers. (United States Sanitary Commission); Homes for Disabled Soldiers (U. S. San. Com.)
lead_paragraph: Now that the excitement of actual war is over, and the demand upon the men and women at home for thought, time, money and supplies for sick and wounded soldiers has nearly ceased, people are turning their attention to the question of how best to provide permanently for those soldiers who have been disabled in the service. And it is one of the questions which require a great deal of careful thought. There has been a vast amount of earnest philanthropy aroused by this war, and the ardent feeling cannot at once be put to sleep in its old ways. For a while, at least, it must be allowed to spend itself upon something. Yet it will, because of its very force, require guidance and constraint, and the influence of men who insist upon slower steps and patient investigation, else in its earnestness it will do unwise things.

abstract: Delegated to English May Meetings
snippet: Delegated to English May Meetings
lead_paragraph: A DELEGATE TO ENGLAND. -- The Rev. J. SELLA MARTIN, of this city, has been appointed by the American Missionary Association to represent that Society at the May Meetings in London, and among such Christians in England as have an interest in the freedmen of this country. The Shiloh Church, of which Mr. MARTIN is Pastor, has voted him a leave of absence for this purpose, and we understand he will sail in the Africa, from Boston, on the 10th inst. The appointment cannot but be a good one, both on account of the access which Mr. MARTIN is likely to have to the popular ear, and the confidence reposed in him by the Christian Churches of England when he has himself been a Pastor. A colored man representing the interests of his newly freed race cannot fall to be acceptable to the true friends of it abroad when possessing the character and talent of Mr. MARTIN.

abstract: The Hibernian, a short summary of whose news was yesterday telegraphed from Port-au-Basque, arrived off Father Point yesterday morning. The news of the assassination of President LINCOLN was published in England on the 26th ult., and created the most profound sensation. The strongest feelings of sympathy, indignation and horror were everywhere expressed; and those who sympathised with the South evinced as much indignation as the warmest friends of the North. In all places it was the prevailing topic of conversation, and caused an almost total suspension of busines, particularly in Liverpool and Manchester.

abstract: Annual Exhibition
snippet: Annual Exhibition
lead_paragraph: The annual exhibition by the inmates of this Institution took place at Irving Hall yesterday afternoon. Quite a large audience was present considering the inclemency of the weather. On the platform were about 125 of the inmates of the Institution, the young ladies being dressed in white with red or blue sashes, and presenting a very beautiful appearance. After prayer a number of solos, duetts and quartetts, vocal and instrumental, were given. MENDELSSOHN's "Wedding March" was played on the piano by four young ladies, with surprising accuracy and delicacy of touch, and elicited great applause. A little boy named JOHN MAHONEY gave several solos on the piano, showing considerable power for so young a boy. The music was under the direction of Mr. THEO. THOMAS, Mr. S. BARCOCK, one of the blind teachers of the Institution then exercised some of his pupils in geography, the use of the globes and maps, having projections and hollows to indicate the different countries, seas and rivers. Several lads not over ten years of age, readily pointed out the principal countries, and described the routes by land and sea necessary to take in order to reach them. One young lady put a sectional map of the United States together in a few minutes. Afterwards the pupils read a number of verses from the Bible in raised print, almost as readily as if they had possessed the power of sight. One boy read with facility after the print had been covered with a handkerchief four times folded. The mental arithmetic class showed great proficiency -- the answers to very difficult questions being given with astonishing rapidity. The ordinary method of calculating was also shown -- letters being used instead of figures.
headline: {'main': 'Institution for the Blind.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Institution for the Blind.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Surrender; Interpretation of Terms of
snippet: Surrender; Interpretation of Terms of
lead_paragraph: -- It transpired, incidentally, at the trial of Senator HARRIS before the Military Commission in Washington on Monday, that nine days after the surrender of LEE, and four days after the murder of President LINCOLN, the Lieutenant-General had found it expedient to issue special orders to some of his subordinate commanders as to the interpretation to be given to the terms of parole granted to LEE's men. These orders, it appears, fully coincide with the opinion of Attorney General SPEED in their definition of the rights which rebel officers and soldiers acquired by the surrender. The Lieutenant-General instructs Gen. ORD that paroled men residing south of Richmond must get home, by land, as speedily as possible, and by the most direct route; and that only those who, in conformity with the terms of the agreement, proceed toward their homes, can be supplied with transportation or subsistence at the expense of the government.

abstract: Young Mens' Christian Association Anniversary
snippet: Young Mens' Christian Association Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The eleventh annual meeting of the Brooklyn Young Men's Christian Association was held in their Rooms at the Washington Institute last evening, and in view of the unfavorable state of the weather, was well attended. The President, Mr. WM. EDSALL, occupied the chair, and after the usual preliminary exercises the business of the meeting was proceeded with. The President's report showed that the association had just closed a year of gratifying prosperity, the receipts having been $2,100, the debts all paid, and a balance left in the treasury. The library now consists of 3,400 volumes. The meetings during the past year have been better attended than ever before, and an increasing interest has been manifested in the welfare of the association, and with the most gratifying results. Allusion was made to the war just closed, and the hope expressed that the pacific policy of the late President would be imitated by those now in authority -- that no vindictive feeling should be displayed toward the South, but that they should be won back by good deeds, and in that spirit of charity which bids us love our enemies.

abstract: Tuesday, May 9, will be memorable in the history of our great national loan negotiations. Nothing like its results can be found in the marvelous financial history of our country. Over fifteen million dollars of the Seven-Thirty Loan were subscribed for yesterday, through the sub-agency of Mr. COOKE, the General Subscription Agent. Of this enormous amount our city took about eight million dollars -- of which sum a single banking-house ordered, on behalf of their own customers exclusively, five millions and fifty-nine thousand dollars -- being over three times the amount of the heaviest preceding single order, (also from this city,) nearly twice the daily average of the aggregate sales in the early weeks of last month, and within a few thousand dollars of the total of last Tuesday's liberal subscriptions to the loan throughout the country.

abstract: Mercantile Library Association, Annual Meeting
snippet: Mercantile Library Association, Annual Meeting
lead_paragraph: The Mercantile Library Association held its forty-fourth annual meeting at their hall in Astorplace last evening. Several interesting reports were read, showing the prosperity of the Organization. The society now has over 73,000 volumes of books, and the list shows that there are over 6,000 paying members. Interesting speeches were made by Hon. Judge DALY and Messrs. LATHERS, PRIME, DODGE and HUNT. The proceedings were enlivened by excellent music, furnished by DODWORTH's Band.

abstract: Speech at Anti-Slavery Society Anniversary; Anniversary; Speech at Anti-Slavery Anniversary; Speech at Anti-Slavery Anniversary; Speech at Anti-Slavery Anniversary
snippet: Speech at Anti-Slavery Society Anniversary; Anniversary; Speech at Anti-Slavery Anniversary; Speech at Anti-Slavery Anniversary; Speech at Anti-Slavery Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The first session of the thirty-second anniversary of the American Anti-Slavery Society was held yesterday morning, at 10:30 o'clock, in the Church of the Puritans, (Rev. Dr. CHEEVER'S.) The heavy fall of rain in no way interfered with the entire numerical success of the occassion, as at 9:30 the spacious edifice was crowded to its fullest capacity. Upon the platform sat the venerable Wm. Lloyd Garrison, the perpetual President of the Society, Wendell Phillips, George Thompson, of England, Mrs. Francis Watkins Harper, Thomas Garrett, of Delaware, Robert Purvis, of Philadelphia, Samuel May, Jr., Rev. J.T. Sargent, Hon. George B. Lincoln, of Brooklyn, and Edmund Quincy, Esq., of Boston, and one or two others of note. The entrance of Messrs. GARRISON and PHILLIPS was the signal for enthusiastic applause and most friendly greeting on the part of the audience.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE.--Precious to the habitues of Wallack's Theatre are the memories of olden times. From that fortunate year when Mr. WALLAOX succeeded to Mr. JOHN BROUGHAM and turned the utterly vacant and yawning Lyceum into a crowded boudoir of youth and beauty; from then until now--when a larger house and a vaster patronage ...
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- Precious to the habitues of Wallack's Theatre are the memories of olden times. From that fortunate year when Mr. WALLAOX succeeded to Mr. JOHN BROUGHAM and turned the utterly vacant and yawning Lyceum into a crowded boudoir of youth and beauty; from then until now--when a larger house and a vaster patronage bear witness to the success of the experiment -- hardly an actor or an actress has appeared on the Wallack stage that would not gladly be recalled, if that were possible. Alas! some are in the grave, and the rest are scattered far and wide in the eager search for fame. Could we draw them together again, how great would be our joy. A feeling so general in its application naturally has a peculiar intensity when directed toward Mr. J. LESTER WALLACK. From the beginning he has been the most prominent member of the combination. Few actors, indeed, have worked so persistently and conscientiously. Until his health failed, only a few weeks ago, (from causes which we all respect and keep silent,) he has never to our knowledge disappointed the public, or sought relief from duties which, although they rightfully fell to his share, were frequently overwhelming. Popular favorites are seldom so reliable. It is gratifying to know that in a small measure Mr. LESTER WALLACK had his reward last evening. His appearance on the stage was the signal for the heartiest round of applause we have ever heard in this usually sedate house. It was the recognition of a gentleman by gentlemen; of an artist by true lovers of art. Mr. WALLACK has been very ill, and is yet barely recovered. But as the grasp of a friendly hand imparts strength, so the cheering of many hands will, we trust, give vigor. We are glad to see that Mr. J.L. WALLACK will appear every evening this week.

The number of subscribers for small sums was 10,617.

abstract: Sensitiveness
snippet: Sensitiveness
lead_paragraph: Our government was conducted for eighty years on the principle that the great object of its existence and the first duty of every good citizen at the North was to keep Southerners in good humor. To say anything that hurt their feelings, to refuse them anything they demanded, to hint even in the mildest manner that the Free States could exist without them, that the withdrawal of their custom or countenance would not ruin everybody at the North and bring up the grass in all our streets, came at last to be considered little short of fratricidal. The theory of the advocates of this policy was, that it was thus and only thus that brotherly feeling between the people of the two sections could be kept up and the Union be preserved.
headline: {'main': 'Rebel Sensitiveness.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Rebel Sensitiveness.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: --It has been proved that the increase of lunacy in France has kept pace with the augmentation of the revenue from tobacco.
lead_paragraph: -- It has been proved that the increase of lunacy in France has kept pace with the augmentation of the revenue from tobacco. From the years 1812 to 1832 that tax produced 28,000,000, and the lunatic asylums of the country contained 8 000 patients. The tobacco revenue has now reached the sum of 180 000,000, and there are no less than 44 000 paralytic and lunatic patients in the various hospitals devoted to their accommodation. This parallel has been drawn by M. JOLLY and laid before the Academy of Science. The last words of his speech on that occasion are worth recording in this age of universal smoking, and young boys, to whom this pernicious practice has not yet become second nature, would do well to reflect, ere it be too late, on the frightful warning the above statistics contain, as well as on M. JOLLY's words. He says: "The immoderate use of tobacco, and more especially of the pipe, produces a weakness in the brain and in the spinal marrow which causes madness."

abstract: Atlantic Cable; Progress of
snippet: Atlantic Cable; Progress of
lead_paragraph: There is a prevalent belief that the great work of laying the Atlantic Telegraph anew will commence in the early part of next month. Occasional intimations to that effect come to us in the European news summaries. And we should presume that there can be no possible object which would lead the promoters of the scheme to deceive the public, by anticipating the date at which the great undertaking, after seven years of preparation, will be resumed. At the same time, we fail to find in the latest reports of the progress made at the manufactory of Messrs. GLASS, ELLIOT & CO., or on board the Great Eastern, a very strong assurance that the expectations of the well-wishers of the enterprise can possibly be met as to time. On April 24, some fourteen hundred miles of the wire had been placed in the tanks of the vessel; one tank was reported full, another a little more than half full, and the third only commenced filling. At the date named, there was still fully a thousand miles to be shipped. This uncompleted work, even if the wire were already finished -- which it does not appear to be -- would occupy, at the present rate of filling the tanks, fully forty days. Forty working days from April 24 would carry the task of stowing away the cable forward at least to the middle of June -- that is allowing twenty-five miles, which is a full average, to represent a day's work.
headline: {'main': 'The Progress and Prospects of the New Atlantic Telegraph.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Progress and Prospects of the New Atlantic Telegraph.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Temperance Union Anniversary
snippet: Temperance Union Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The twenty-ninth anniversary of the American Temperance Union was celebrated at Irving Hall last evening. About one hundred persons were present, one-half of whom were ladies, Hon. WILLIAM A. BUCKINGHAM, Governor of Connecticut, presided. He said that the agitation for the abolition of slavery commenced about thirty years ago, and the temperance cause could date back about thirty five years. Slavery is now practically abolished, after thirty years' labor. This should encourage all to persevere in the crusade against intemperance. He admitted that the temperance cause had been retrograding lately, but this only made it the more necessary to take up the question anew and use more earnest efforts in its behalf.

abstract: Guizot's Meditations on Christianity
snippet: Guizot's Meditations on Christianity
lead_paragraph: In the evening of his days, a great statesman -- a great historian -- confessedly one of the first minds of the age -- dedicates the moments afforded by retirement from the active scenes of life to the defence of our common Christianity. That Christianity he sees -- with the clearness that marks the vision of the philosopher and sage -- now exposed to attacks, differing both in kind and degree, from all former assaults, against its supernatural claims. The crisis that now agitates Christendom, he views as one manifestation of the great intellectual and social revolution, that after the fermentation and preparation of centuries, has broken out, and is in course of accomplishment in our generation. But the capability of Christianity to adapt itself to all the different forms of human institutions, is a mere characteristic of its divine essence and origin, and he, therefore, looks forward with confidence to its emergence from the struggle, purified and exalted. To bring forward and illustrate the alliance that subsists between the truth of revelation and the inherent spiritual wants of man, is one object that M. GUIZOT has in view in his present work. It forms the first of an intended series of four parts, and is destined to explain and establish what it is that constitute, in the mind of the writer, the peculiar features of Christianity -- that is to say, what those natural problems are, that correspond with the fundamental doctrines of revelation, that furnish their solution, and the nature of the supernatural facts on which these doctrines are based -- creation, revelation, the inspiration of the Scriptures, the Divine Being as manifested in holy writ, and the character and work of Jesus as displayed in the Gospel narrative. The subjects are to led in the meditations that compose the volume. abstract: ANNIVERSARY OF THE JERSEY CITY SABBATH-SCHOOLS -- NEARLY FOUR THOUSAND CHILDREN IN PROCESSION. -- The tenth anniversary of the Jersey City Sabbath-School Association was celebrated on Monday afternoon by appropriate services in several of the churches and a grand procession, in which over 3,600 children and about 300 teachers took part. The schools assembled as follows: Tabernacle -- Schools -- First Presbyterian. Trinity Methodist, Congregational and First Reformed Dutch. Addresses were delivered by Rev. H.M. SCUDDER, Rev. Mr. MONROE and Rev. J. MILTON HOMES. Hedding Methodist -- Schools -- Hedding Methodist and South Seventh-street Mission. Addresses by Rev. J.M. FREEMAN, of Paterson, and A.C. SMITH, Esq. Wayne-street Reformed Dutch -- Schools -- Wayne-street Reformed Dutch and Morgan-street Mission. Addresses by Rev. Mr. STEWART, of Tarrytown, and Rev. Mr. DURYEA, of Lafayette, Union Baptist -- Union Baptist School. Addresses by Rev. Mr. PARMLEE, pastor, and Rev. Mr. WHITE, St. Paul's Methodist -- Schools -- St. Paul's Methodist, Third Presbyterian and German Lutheran. Addresses by Rev. Mr. BUTTS and Dr. HARKNESS. Second Presbyterian -- Schools -- Third Reformed Dutch and Second Presbyterian. Addresses by Rev. Dr. BERRY and Rev. Mr. STEVENSON. At the close of the services a procession was formed and marched in the following order with badges, banners and flags, each school with its number of children: Morgan-street Mission, 150; Second Reformed Dutch, 250; St. Paul's Methodist, 434; Third Presbyterian, 190; Third Reformed Dutch, 274; Second Presbyterian Mission 180; First Presbyterian, 155; Trinity Methodist, 240; First Reformed Dutch, 150; First Congregational, 350; South Seventh-street Mission, 304; Hedding Methodist, 400; Union Baptist, 550. Mr. A.S. JEWELL, acted as Grand-Marshal, and Messrs. T.H. PORTER and R.N. PERLEE, as Assistant Marshals. After passing through a number of streets, the procession marched around Van Vorst-square and were dismissed in front of the square on Jersey-avenue, where Helmsmuller's Band were stationed and discoursed some fine music. The children then repaired to their respective churches, where each one was supplied with a paper bag containing cake, oranges, candy, &c., and then went on their way rejoicing. The anniversary exercises of the Sunday School Association will be held in the First Presbyterian Church, Washington-street, on Wednesday evening, 10th inst.

snippet: Anniversary; Sunday-school Union, Anniversary
lead_paragraph: On the occasion of the forty-ninth anniversary of the New-York Sunday School Union a respectable audience assembled in Rev. Dr. RICE'S Church, in Fifth-avenue, corner of Nineteenth-street, and Rev. CHANCELLOR FERRIS, D.D., President of the Union, filled the chnir. The exercises of the evening were introduced with the hymn, "Joy to the world, the Lord has come," by the Thirteenth-street Presbyterian Sabbath School, under Prof. S. ROBERTS, and prayer by Rev. Dr. RICE.

abstract: The homeward march of our armies still continues. The advance of Gen. MEADE's forces was yesterday in the vicinity of Louisa Courthouse, and is expected to encamp near Alexandria by Saturday night. SHERMAN's troops are expected to pass through Richmond to-day. SHERIDAN's cavalry left Petersburgh on Monday last, to march overland to Alexandria. One brigade of cavalry will be stationed at Lynchburgh, another at Danville, and a third at Petersburgh, to patrol the country and preserve order.

abstract: Colonization Society, Anniversary
snippet: Colonization Society, Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The thirty-third annual meeting of this society took place yesterday morning at Room No. 22 BibleHouse building. After preliminary business, the society organized by JAMES W. BEEKMAN, Esq., taking the chair. A statement of the finances of the society was then read by the Corresponding Secretary, Rev. JOHN B. PINNEY, in the absence of JOSEPH B. COLLINS, Esq., the Secretary. Mr. PINNEY also read the annual report, in which the society gave an outline of Mr. LINCOLN's action in behalf of the colored race, and paid a tribute to the far-seeing policy of our lamented President.

abstract: Lincoln, President, Portrait Ordered of Mr. Carpenter by Chicago; London Times; Malevolence on President Johnson; Almaden Dispatch, (Cal.,) Suppressed for Exulting over President Lincoln's Death; Lincoln, President, Murder; Public Opinion on
snippet: Lincoln, President, Portrait Ordered of Mr. Carpenter by Chicago; London Times; Malevolence on President Johnson; Almaden Dispatch, (Cal.,) Suppressed for Exulting over President Lincoln's Death; Lincoln, President, Murder; Public Opinion on
lead_paragraph: The space which we give to-day to the reproduction of the sentiments of the British press on the murder of President LINCOLN is warranted -- if on no other ground -- by the insight which the various comments afford, into the exceedingly diverse character of the sympathy expressed. This diversity, which is one of motive and interest, was scarcely apparent in the telegraphic abstracts which have been heretofore given from the leading foreign journals. It will be seen to-day that, while the full bearing and gist of such sincere and eloquent tributes as Mr. LINCOLN's death called forth from the liberal press of England, might be given in a paragraph, the inspiration and the motive of whatever was uttered by the hostile journals could only be interpreted by looking to the tone of thought pervading what they had to say in its elaborated form. Applying this test, we discover in the spirit of the British pro-rebel journals precisely what we expected -- a species of eulogy upon the character and acts of the late President, employed to cover a bitter malevolence toward the people and government of the United States. The whole argument of the London Times, unless we greatly misapprehend it, is pointed to an illustration of the helpless, mierable state of anarchy into which this country has fallen by the death of a single one of its citizens. Hastening from insincere laudation of the dead, to contemptuous pity for the living, says this British oracle: "The too probable effect of the crime is an accession of madness and anger, rendering all schemes of reconstruction impossible." As if fearing that this might not fully convey an expression of its hopes for a revival of the Confederacy, the same journal proceeds to vilify President JOHNSON to the full bent of its desires, and brings itself to the conclusion that, whatever Mr. LINCOLN might have done to restore the Union, "it is morally certain Mr. JOHNSON cannot do it."
headline: {'main': 'The Assassination and British Public Opinion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Assassination and British Public Opinion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: VISITORS AT POLICE HEADQUARTERS. -- Yesterday the new Capital Police, consisting of Messrs. W.W.S. SHEPARD, THOMAS COLEMAN, NELSON DAVENPORT, FRANKLIN TOWNSEND and S.V. TRULL, accompanied by Mr. THORN, of the Troy Times, and other gentlemen, visited police headquarters, and were escorted thence by Superintendent KENNEDY to Precincts Nos. 7, 10, 13, 15 and 45. The object of these gentlemen's visit was to gain such information relative to the workings of the Metropolitan Police as may be useful in organizing a like system, covering a district which embraces Albany and Troy and surrounding villages.

abstract: In the House Commons, on the 28th, Mr. GLADSTONE made the annual financial statement, and entered at once into the prosperous condition of the country. The total revenue was over seventy and a quarter millions sterling, a surplus of over three millions above the estimates; while the expenditures was below the estimates, so that the estimated surplus for the current year exceeds four millions. His leading propositions are a reduction of 6d. per pound in the duty on tea, 2d. on the income tax, making it 4d. and reducing the fire insurance duty to 1s. 6d. per cent., which reduction will dispose of all of the four millions surplus, with the exception of one quarter of a million.
lead_paragraph: In the House Commons, on the 28th, Mr. GLADSTONE made the annual financial statement, and entered at once into the prosperous condition of the country. abstract: Appointed President Anti-Slavery Society, and Speech; Retires from Anti-Slavery Society; at Anti-Slavery Society Anniversary; Votes to Continue Existence
snippet: Appointed President Anti-Slavery Society, and Speech; Retires from Anti-Slavery Society; at Anti-Slavery Society Anniversary; Votes to Continue Existence
lead_paragraph: The second day of the Thirty-second Anniversary of the American Anti-Slavery Society found the spacious Church of the Puritans crowded at an early hour. Many prominent men and women, who, for thirty years or less, have worked in the ranks or on the forum, were present, while the audience presented, as a whole, an appearance of intelligence and culture so long a characteristic of these gatherings.

abstract: Rachel Unger vs. The Forty-second-street Railroad Company. -- On the evening of the 1st of January, 1864, the plaintiff was run over and very seriously injured by the horses of the defendants, which had become detached from a car near the corner of Avenue B. and Third-street. The plaintiff sought to recover $10,000 damages for the alleged negligence. The testimony given, tended to show that on the New Year's evening in question, a gang of ruffians tried to take possession of the car; that by reason of their acts the horses became frightened, detached themselves from the car in spite of the efforts of the driver, ran away, and in doing so, plaintiff, who was crossing the street, was injured as already stated.

abstract: Debt, Shall this Generation Pay It
snippet: Debt, Shall this Generation Pay It
lead_paragraph: The war will leave us a national debt of about three thousand millions. Shall the republic be relieved of this great burden by the people now on the stage, or shall the bulk of it be devolved upon succeeding generations? The answer to this general question must shape our entire financial policy, and should be determined only after the most thorough consideration.

abstract: Outlaws Should be Punished with Death
snippet: Outlaws Should be Punished with Death
lead_paragraph: The surrender of Gen. LEE put out of the field all the Confederate troops in the State of Virginia; the surrender of JOHNSTON put out of the field all the Confederate troops in the Carolinas and Georgia; the surrender of TAYLOR has put out of the field all the Confederate troops in the States of Alabama and Mississippi. In other words, in the whole of the vast territory from the Potomac to the Mississippi River, and embracing, beside the six States named, those of West Virginia, Tennessee and Kentucky -- all of which territory was but lately claimed by the Southern Confederacy -- there are now, by the terms of surrender, no Confederate troops, no armed men who have the right to claim the immunities of soldiers, or such belligerent rights as have for four years been conceded to the rebels fighting in the interest of the so-called Confederacy. The Generals controlling them, and commanding the respective armies and departments, have, on behalf of all in arms, agreed that they shall disarm, return to their homes, and maintain the public peace.

abstract: "Emigrants" from United States; Cautions to; Civil and Military Affairs
snippet: "Emigrants" from United States; Cautions to; Civil and Military Affairs
lead_paragraph: Although the news from Mexico given yesterday is not marked by more than the usual coherence, there are certain apparently trustworthy statements that may have some interest for those who contemplate military adventures in the interest of that republic. The military situation, so far as we can judge by a collation of the various fragments of intelligence, has not essentially changed for a great while. Now and again a detachment of Franco-Mexican troops is surprised and made prisoners, as they were at Tacambare (Michoacan) on the 19th of April. The Imperialists, anon, find compensation in dispossessing the Republicans of some town or fortress on the west coast, as they did on the 27th of March, when Guaymas fell into the hands of the French without resistance; the garrison betaking itself to the interior on the approach of four French men-of-war. Again, we read land without any surprise) that CORTINAS, who sold himself a few months ago to the Imperialists, has "repronounced" in favor of the Republic; and has gathered around him, in the districts bordering on the Rio Grande and near Matamoras, a force so considerable, that extra precautions have been instituted by the French garrison at the last-named place to protect the empire. Citizens not employed in the Imperial military service have been subjected to a general disarming process, and severe penalties are attached to the concealment of warlike implements of every kind.

abstract: The Trial and Secret Courts
snippet: The Trial and Secret Courts
lead_paragraph: It is very possible the publication of the evidence taken on the trial of the conspirators at Washington might prevent the arrest of some persons implicated in the crime of assassination who are now at large; but their arrest must be of very great importance indeed, if the fear of their escaping is sufficient to justify the profound secrecy with which it has been determined to surround the proceedings. The chief of BOOTH's accomplices, it is fair to conclude, are those for whose apprehension a reward has been offered -- DAVIS, TUCKER, SANDERS & CO. -- and it is not pretended that anything which may transpire at the trial at Washington, will, in the least degree, offset the chance of their escape. They and their friends have certainly been as much put on their guard by the President's proclamation as they are likely to be by anything else that can occur.

abstract: The International Congress of Delegates to the Suez Canal held their first meeting at the residence of DE LESSEPS, in Alexandria, April 5, and their last at the Hotel d'Orient, in Cairo on the 17th. Of eighty-five delegates, there the duly appointed representatives of ten governments, eight companies or societies, and sixty-two chambers of commerce, representing in all fourteen nations. Alter having carefully examined for several days the various works, and passing in boats from the Meditteranean to the Red Sea in twenty-seven hours, the delegates were of the unanimous opinion that the construction of the ship canal across the Isthmus of Suez, was proceeding with vigor and its completion only was a question of time and money. The company has made contracts with three parties for the completion of the ship canals, piers and harbors by the 1st of 1868.

abstract: Chamber of Commerce, Meeting on Confiscated Cotton; Confiscation, N. Y. Ch. of Com. Meeting on
snippet: Chamber of Commerce, Meeting on Confiscated Cotton; Confiscation, N. Y. Ch. of Com. Meeting on
lead_paragraph: The Chamber of Commerce held a special meeting yesterday afternoon, for the purpose of considering the report of a special committee on the confiscation of cotton by the government in the Southern States. This report, the substance of which has been published in the columns of the TIMES, was placed in the hands of the members. The attendance was large, and the proceedings were unusually spirited, the members taking much interest in the subject, many warm discussions having taken place between several gentlemen at former meetings of the chamber at which the confiscation question had been considered.

abstract: City Mission and Tract Society Anniversary
snippet: City Mission and Tract Society Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The first annual meeting of the above society was held last evening at Irving Hall. Owing to the inclemency of the weather the attendance was not large, but those who were present manifested great interest in the proceedings. While stating this to be the first annual meeting of the society, it is due to them to say that it is one of the oldest in the city, and well known under the name of the City Tract Society, but that having commenced an extension of their field of operations, the name has been changed to the City Mission and Tract Society, and the public meeting held last evening, was partially for the purpose of giving the society a place in the regular anniversaries, which they have now for the first time claimed.

abstract: Woodruff, Hiram, Testimonial; George Wilkes' Letter; Eoff, J. L., Challenge; Norfolk against Patchen
snippet: Woodruff, Hiram, Testimonial; George Wilkes' Letter; Eoff, J. L., Challenge; Norfolk against Patchen
lead_paragraph: Mr. JAMES L. EOFF, the well-known trainer and driver, who took the famous thoroughbred racer Norfolk over to San Francisco, after his victories in the Atlantic States, has, by the last steamer, sent over a trotting cartel to New-York, offering to trot the young stallion George M. Patchen. Jr., two races for $5,000 each, half forfeit, the first to be one mile heats, best three in five to sulky, and the second, two mile heats, the race to be either in New-York, on one of the Long Island courses, or in San Francisco. We are inclined to the belief that Mr. EOFF, having challenged all the trotting horses in the Atlantic States, can be readily accommodated, if he will bring the young Patchen stallion along, particularly if he will put an additional twenty on to the five thousand cartel he has already issued. There can be no difficulty about the matter, as a challenge has also been issued by the owner of the famous Gen. Butler to trot any horse, mare or gelding in the world, one, two or three-mile heats, for any amount of money the takers of the challenge may feel inclined to put up. Then there is that splendid stallion George Wilkes, who is open to anything that can be offered, in which his speed, courage and proverbial endurance can be proven. There is no doubt that Mr. EOFF can be accommodated, or that there will be exceedingly lively times in the trotting world this season.

abstract: Rebel Crucities to; Rev. J. J. Gear's Lecture
snippet: Rebel Crucities to; Rev. J. J. Gear's Lecture
lead_paragraph: Rev. Col. J.J. GEAR, of the One Hundred and Eighty-third Ohio Volunteers, addressed an appreciative audience, on Wednesday evening, at the Attorney-street M.E. Church, and narrated many of the hideous experiences of our soldiers while held as prisoners of war by the "Christian gentleman and scholar." Generalissimo ROBERT E. LEE. Many veteran soldiers were present. The speaker, having been introduced by Capt. STEERS, of the Thirteenth Ward Police, said that he had been four years and fourteen days a soldier of the United States, and passed through three rebel penitentiaries, and after having been chained and bayoneted, had attempted escape through a swamp of two hundred and fifty miles, fed by negroes and hunted by bloodhounds, and at length captured and returned to Georgia, there tried and sentenced to death. In the court before which he was arraigned the speaker and his companion, Col. COLLINS, made a clean breast, confessing themselves to be United States soldiers, and bade the rebels do their worst. The prisoners' truthful words won them friends in the court, and pending a decision of their fate, a sanguinary encounter occurred, many rebels urging their immediate execution and many others speaking in their defence, until, when the crowd had tired of fighting, the Sheriff -- a humane, and, as has since proved, a loyal man -- assumed the responsibility of removing their chains. Col. GEAR and Col. COLLINS subsequently came North with this excellent county official. In the Macon prison, to the floor of which their feet were chained for eighteen days, our dear prodigal brethren of the Southern chivalry fed them by tossing their food in through the iron grating of the door, as though the prisoners had been dogs. At Atlanta, on the very night when Col. GEAR broke from the jail of that town, seven Union prisoners were hanged. When he passed through Richmond, on his way to Libby Prison, just before the Presidential election, the multitudes who were shouting for JEFF. DAVIS said to him: "You'll go home soon, you prison-breaking Methodist preacher, for the North is about to vote with us, and the Northwest will join us outright." The newspapers of the South, wielded by JEFF. DAVIS, had made the people -- even many Union prisoners -- credit this falsehood; and to our heroes who were languishing in prison the prospect was appalling. The speaker was at Andersonville when 10,000 prisoners were held there, and of the number he counted 287 men who had no feet; and on the Cape Fear River, into a prison in which he was thrust, 555 men out of 5,000 died in one season. He had been asked how it occurred that our soldiers lost their feet. They were left without shelter, and to keep their blood warm were compelled to walk in the sand continually until the blood ceased to circulate in the feet, and they dropped off at the ankle. Forty-five of these men are now on David's Island. The speaker read several affidavits, one of which we quote as follows:

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Normal Club Grounds Opening
snippet: Normal Club Grounds Opening
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon there was quite a numerous gathering of the leading quoit-players of the metropolis and its vicinity, at the fine quoit grounds of the Normal Club of New-York, which are located at the rear of No. 744 Broadway, near the corner of Astorplace, the occasion being the opening games of the season. This locality wae, last season, the scene of some of the finest contests at quoits played in this country. This year the Normal Club of New-York have engaged it for the season, and in conjunction with the St. Andrew's and New-York Clubs, there will be games played on these grounds every fine day among the members of one or other of these organizations. The grounds are open from 6 A.M. to dark each day, and quoit-players in general are invited by the President of the Normal Club to drop in and join with their members in their games when opportunity offers.

abstract: OF THE COMMERCIAL BANK, PHILADELPHIA. -- CHAS. E. CLARK, the defaulting paying-teller of the Commercial Bank, of this city, who recently absconded after defrauding the bank out of a sum of money amounting to about $300,000, was arrested yesterday morning at Scranton, in this State. It is understood that information of his whereabouts became known to one of Mr. CLARK's personal friends in this city, who at once proceeded to Scranton under certain instructions from the chief of detectives of Philadelphia, and succeeded in finding the prisoner and bringing him to this city in safety. It is believed that Mr. CLARK will make a statement implicating a number of accomplices in the defalcation. -- Philadelphia Inquirer, May 9.

abstract: Labor Paid, and Southern Prejudice; Labor and Southern Prejudice
snippet: Labor Paid, and Southern Prejudice; Labor and Southern Prejudice
lead_paragraph: Southerners as well as Nottherners have learned a great many things during this war. They have learned, for instance, that commercial nations are not necessarily unwarlike; that man may be very successful and eager in making money, and yet make a good soldier; that it is an exceedingly exhausting and troublesome job for "one southerner to whip three Yankees;" that cotton is not king, and that slave society is not likely to spread itself over the earth; and though last not least, that negro troops do not run away, and howl when they hear a shot.

abstract: WINCHLSTER, Va., Saturday, May 6, 1865. Cheerful sounds of civil business preparation  have taken the place of the usual grim arrangements for civil war. The sweet May flowers fearlessly open to the warm sun and genial showers, no longer to be crushed by the tramp of hurrying squadrons, or stained with the life-blood of opposing armies.

abstract: Davis, Rear Admiral C. A., appointed Superintendent U. S. Naval Observatory
snippet: Davis, Rear Admiral C. A., appointed Superintendent U. S. Naval Observatory
lead_paragraph: IMPORTANT NAVAL COMMANDS. -- The following important naval commands have recently been assigned: Rear-Admiral Charles H. Davis, ordered from duty as Chief of the Bureau of Navigation, and appointed Superintendent of the U.S. Naval Observatory; Rear-Admiral David D. Porter, relieved from the command of the North Atlantic squadron, and waiting orders; Commodore James L. Lardner, from special duty at Philadelphia, and ordered to duty as a member of a Naval Board, of which Commodore Engle is President; Capt. Perceval Drayton, appointed Chief of the Bureau of Navigation; Capt. T.A. Kenkins has been appointed senior member of a board of officers to investigate and examine into the claims for local bounty preferred by men in the Mississippi Squadron, and ordered to report to Rear-Admiral Lee, Commodore F. Stanley and Paymaster A.H. Gilman are ordered to assist him; Commodore Wm. Radford appointed Acting Rear-Admiral and ordered to command the North Atlantic Squadron; Holmes Edward Offley, formerly in the Navy Department, has been appointed secretary to Rear-Admiral L.M. Goldsborough, rough, ordered to command the European Squadron.

abstract: Congregational Reunion
snippet: Congregational Reunion
lead_paragraph: The Twelfth American Congregational Reunion was held last evening at the Brooklyn Academy of Music. Notwithstanding the inclemency of the weather, the spacious edifice was densely crowded with a fashionable and intellectual audience, embracing the beauty and elite of that city. The speakers and principal clergy of the Congregational Church occupied the stage. An excellent brass band was in attendance, and the exercises were enlivened with vocal and instrumental music.

abstract: their Badges, >amp;c.
snippet: their Badges, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Mr. WILLETT J. HANFORD, of No. 271 West Twenty-seventh-street, expressman, made an affidavit against Officer ROBERT J. WILKINSON, of the City Half force for expelling him from the people's Line pies, near Canal-Street. The case is since it develops facts which are not generally known. Mr. HANFORD appeared on the pier within limits which the police had indicated by a chain, and the officer, having required him to show a badge, which he could not do, pushed him back to the line which was held by other expressmen and coachmen. It having been shown that Officer WILKINSON had acted is strict obedience to the rules of the department, President ACTON dismissed the complaint, and informed Mr. HANFORD, 1. That the pier whence he had been expelled was a private pier belonging to the People's Line, and that the superintendent thereof had instructed the police to admit no hackman or express man thereon without a proper badge; 9. That an officer has a right and is directed to require hackmen and others to exhibit their badges when on any pier, and, 3. That the law does not permit hackmen or expressmen to solicit passengers or luggage, but requires that they shall wait until regularly employed by the traveling public.

abstract: New-Jersey, Attempt to throw Washington Train Off Track
snippet: New-Jersey, Attempt to throw Washington Train Off Track
lead_paragraph: The express train for New-York, which left Washington at 11 A.M. on the 10th inst., and Philadelphia at 6 P.M. the same date, had a very narrow escape from utter destruction by a fiendish attempt on the part of some persons to hurl it from the track. About one mile north of New-Brunswick, a peculiar jerking motion of the train was perceptible, accompanied by the sharp whistle of the locomotive to "down brakes," three times repeated. It was then discovered that a large log had been wedged in at the switch between the two rails, so as to infallibly run any train off that should attempt to pass over it. As an additional proof that it was by design, an examination of the switch showed that the person or persons being unable to unlock it, had withdrawn the bolts in order the better to effect their purpose. The fore part of the engine alone was thrown off, owing to the care of the engineer, without which many lives must have been lost. This is the fourth time within four months that such an attempt has been made in the same vicinity.

abstract: Government worthy of Confidence
snippet: Government worthy of Confidence
lead_paragraph: The government has seen fit to order that those persons charred with having been implicated in the assassination of President LINCOLN, shall be tried by a military tribunal, -- and that this trial shall be secret, except so far as the government itself may publish its disclosures. This paper has already expressed its regret that such a course should have been deemed necessary. It would have been far better every way if these trials could have been held before the ordinary civil tribunals of the land, and in presence of the public. But we desire that the language used in discussing this subject in this journal yesterday, should not be understood as impeaching in any degree the motives of the government in the action it has taken.

abstract: The Flight of
snippet: The Flight of
lead_paragraph: -- The gallant cavalry of WILSON and STONEMAN, forming together a more numerous and powerful body of horsemen than the Confederacy ever boasted in its palmiest days, are now scouring the Gulf States high and low, far and wide, in search of that fugitive who once promised, by implication, to prolong the war of the rebellion in the State of Virginia for twenty years after the fall of Richmond. Twenty years! Within twenty days, not only the great Army of Northern Virginia was surrendered, but even the mountain guerrillas had come to our lines to lay down their arms. He, meanwhile, flying from sure-footed justice, escorted by a band of a couple of thousand horsemen, whose devotion is greatly dependent upon the specie train from which he pays them, seeks, as the consummation of his hopes, to pierce our wide-spread lines in some obscure point, to thread his way through a thousand dangers, and to escape with what booty he may. If it comes to the worst, he will abandon his escort to their fate, fling away the hampering plunder he took from the Richmond specie vaults, and be only too glad to escape with the suit he wears, or even the famous Georgia costume of a shirt collar and a pair of spurs.
headline: {'main': 'THE FLIGHT OF DAVIS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE FLIGHT OF DAVIS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: and Emigration from U. S. Scheme; Emigration Scheme in N. Y., Particulars of
snippet: and Emigration from U. S. Scheme; Emigration Scheme in N. Y., Particulars of
lead_paragraph: Several of our cotemporeries have been for a few days vigorously exploring a "Mexican Emigration" scheme, and giving somewhat indistinct accounts of one kind and another about it. There has been some excitement over it, also, among the more movable portion of our city population, and with them these reports have become quite circumstantial, inasmuch that it is roundly asserted that one shipload of emigrants to Mexico has already sailed from New-York -- a fact, if it be a fact, outside of Collector DRAPER's knowledge.

abstract: German School No. 55, Dedication
snippet: German School No. 55, Dedication
lead_paragraph: The old school, No. 45, Twenty-fourthstreet, having become crowded, it was resolved, long ago, to relieve it by the erection of another school edifice and the transfer thereto of the male pupils, leaving the old school to females exclusively. Accordingly, a fine, commodious structure was erected in Twentieth-street, between Sixth and Seventh avenues, and yesterday it was consecrated with appropriate exercises, in presence of a majority of the Board of Education. School Trustees of the Sixteenth Ward, citizens of that ward, and others, of both sexes, to the number of perhaps one thousand. In the unexpected absence of President MCLEAN, of the Board of Education, Commissioner SAMUEL B.H. VANCE was called to the chair, and after the reading of a selection from the Sacred Writ, by Rev. M.D.C. CRAWFORD, a fervent and patriotic prayer by Rev. H.D. GANSE, and a delightful solo by Miss MARY A. SIMMS, principal of Primary School No. 11, of the Sixteenth Ward, SAMUEL S. RANDALL, Esq., City Superintendent of Schools, a veteran who has had eleven years' experience in this responsible situation -- addressed the assembly. Mr. RANDALL said that the system of common school government under which we are now working, had been fifty-five years established, and within that time New-York had erected fifty-five stately school palaces like that in which he stood, and from the time, within his memory, when the Public School system of this city cost but a paltry $5,000 annually, for the instruction of 500 pupils, our free educational institutions had risen to the dignity of a cost exceeding two millions a year for the education of more than 200,000 of the city's children; and now every year we are compelled to erect vast and costly edifices for school purposes; yet our tax-ridden people never murmur at taxation for the support of our schools. Mr. RANDALL said that there are 50,000 children in New-York who are to be reared to a career of crime, and he held that the State should be empowered to take these children from the streets, and constrain them to attend the Public Schools.

abstract: Explaining the Rebel Murder
snippet: Explaining the Rebel Murder
lead_paragraph: The rebel MASON seems determined to "play the play out" for the benefit of his European audience. He has faith in the power of impudent lying -- such as he alone is capable of -- to the very end. He does not yet so far despair of the rebel cause as not to believe himself able to swagger it into respectability. His letter to the Index, the London organ of the refugee rebels, on the assassination of President LINCOLN, is the latest, though we presume not the last, of his performances in this line. But we doubt whether he can ever improve on it. There is a sublimity of arrogance and impudent falsehood in it which even MASON himself can never surpass.

abstract: National Academy of Design
snippet: National Academy of Design
lead_paragraph: Whatever may be the architectural faults of the building just dedicated to art, an the corner of East Twenty-third-street and Fourth-avenue--and they are said to be many and grave--there can be no doubt about its satisfying a popular craving for what is curious. It is unlike anything to be seeon on this side of the Atlantic, to say nothing of the other. Moreover, when the strong-hearted critic has had his say, the building will be allowed to speak for itself. It may teach us some important truths, and so lead us to desirable results. It is even now conceded that there are many meritorious features in Mr. WIGHT's desingn -- maugre the external steps, which are already sloppy and unpleasant, and which in Winter will be too slippery to stand on. The healthful influence of the Gothic style will not be injured by a too-exactly followed copy of the mediaeval masters, even if the proportions be diminutive. The impression on entering the building is fresh and novel. The staircases are large and imposing, and the color decorations impart a brilliant and gorgeous effect to the whole. We can easily imagine that an untraveled stranger must experience a warm and comfortable sensation of something new in examining this courageous copy of what is old.

abstract: The forty-seventh anniversary exhibition of the pupils of the Institution for the Deaf and Dumb, took place yesterday at Cooper Institute. A very large audience was present. Mr. H.P. PEET, the Vice-Principal, stated that the institution contained 360 pupils, ranging in age from 12 to 25 or 30 years. The pupils present were merely a delegation, consisting of about thirty lads and young men, and about twenty-five young ladies. On being received in the institution, the first thing was to teach them the sign language and the finger alphabet. The latter could be learned in a few months, pupils who had entered the institution last September being now able to converse by its aid with facility.

abstract: Morris Schlessinger was tried yesterday, for the crime of receiving stolen goods. The testimony showed that the goods had been stolen and sold to the prisoner, but there was no evidence that he knew them to have been stolen when he bought them. The case was, therefore, abandoned by the District Attorney.

abstract: Smith vs. Carver, Title to Island
snippet: Smith vs. Carver, Title to Island
lead_paragraph: Hugh C. Smith et al. vs. Phineas P. Carver et al. -- The plaintiffs brought this action to recover the proceeds of a cargo of guano, which was brought to this country and sold in the cities of New-York and Baltimore. The facts of the case, which are of considerable interest to the public, are substantially as follows: The testimony showed that the plaintiffs were connected with a Liverpool and Montevideo shipping house; that in the year 1857 they were owners of the northern half of a small island situated on the coast of Patagonia, which island was then, and is still, known by the name of the Island of Leon. At that time it was almost uninhabited. Owing to the enormous quantities of guano discovered there, it has since become partially settled in some parts of it. Exactly under what title or by what authority the plaintiffs claimed ownership to a portion of it, did not appear, but probably it was by virtue of the oldest and most original of all rights to real estate -- the right of discovery. However, the plaintiffs, whatever their right, and in the year 1857, a number of men engaged on the island in digging and piling up guano, with the intention of shipping it to the Northern ports. It had just been discovered that guano was a fertilizer, equal to, and for some soils, much superior to anything else known, and hence the demand for it was very great all over the civilized world. The men employed by the plaintiffs on the island were under the direction and control of a capitaz, or overseer, by the name of Meneles. The latter had exclusive control of and the power to ship guano in such vessels as were sent to the islands by the plaintiffs for the purpose. Accordingly, he did ship several cargoes in vessels chartered by the plaintiffs. In the latter part of the year 1857, a Capt. Neckel chartered the bark Trovatore, at Montevideo -- a port on the west coast of South America -- and in that vessel, with Carver, one of the defendants, as acting captain, they went to this island, took on board a large cargo of guano, which, it is alleged, was obtained for little or nothing, by means of the connivance of Meneles, the overseer, brought it to this country, and sold it at a high price. The overseer, it appears, came on in the Trovatore as far as Montevideo, where he died in 1860. Hence his testimony could not be obtained. It was further shown that the bark Trovatore tried to hide her name and character while roving around the island, by fastening a piece of canvas over her name on the stern, on which canvas was printed in large letters the name Winona. Also that the defendant Carver, while at the island of Leon, went by the name of Pillsbury. Furthermore, the plaintiffs showed that the overseer, Meneles, had no authority whatever to sell guano. In short, one of the principal grounds on which they relied to recover the amount of the cargo of guano, was that the defendant Carver, and those associated with him, were nothing more nor less than roving pirates, and that Meneles was an accomplice.

abstract: Brooklyn, Hooley's Minstrel Hall; Incendiary
snippet: Brooklyn, Hooley's Minstrel Hall; Incendiary
lead_paragraph: About 7 o'clock yesterday morning a fire broke out in the hall occupied by Hooley's Minstrels, on the corner of Court and Remsen streets. The flames originated on one corner of the stage, and soon enveloped the whole, destroying scenery, wardrobe and all the working machinery. A few articles of personal property were saved by Messrs. HUGHES, MUDGE and BLOODGOOD. The other minstrels lost all, valued in the aggregate at about $1,000. The loss sustained by the proprietor, Mr. R.M. HOOLEY, is estimated at $3,000, which is fully covered by insurance in the Nassau Company of Brooklyn. Mr. ROBERT VARICH, who keeps a saloon on the first floor, was damaged to the extent of $100, insured in the Firemen's Trust Company. The proprietor of the building is Mr. JAS. WEAVER. Loss about $1,000. Insured in the Brooklyn Company.

lead_paragraph: The American Anti-Slavery Society held its first meeting on the question of Negro Suffrage at the Cooper Institute last night. An immense audience literally filled the spacious hall, whose enthusiasm was unbounded, and delight undoubtable. On the platform sat WENDELL PHILLIPS, President of the society; Miss ANNA DICKINSON, THEODORE TILTON, of the Independent; GEORGE THOMPSON, of England; Rev. Mr. SARGEANT, of Boston; Mr. REMOND, of Salem, and other lights of the society, whose several entrances were greeted with applause.

abstract: Croton Aqueduct Commissioners, Injunction Refused
snippet: Croton Aqueduct Commissioners, Injunction Refused
lead_paragraph: In the TIMES of Friday we published the fact that an application had been made in the name of the People of the State of New-York on the relation of Mr. Thomas Stephens, in which Mr. Giles was made defendant, and a second proceeding in which Mr. Darragh was relator, had been taken against Mr. G.A. Jeremiah, both in the Supreme Court; the object being to restrain the two defendants named from exercising the duties of the office of Commissioners of the Croton Aqueduct Department. Yesterday, Mr. Justice SUTHERLAND decided to refuse the injunctions asked for in the petitions, on the ground mainly, that the relators had another and more appropriate legal remedy, if (which he did not undertake to decide) they had any remedy at all.

abstract: CHILDREN's ANNIVERSARY IN NEW-JERSEY. -- The anniversary of the Sabbath-schools of Hudson City and Bergen was celebrated on Wednesday. About 3,000 children were assembled, the rapid growth of the schools rendering it necessary to divide the juveniles in two divisions. The main division, convening at the Methodist Episcopal Church, Hudson City, was presided over by W.H. THOMAS, Esq., President, and was addressed by Rev. JAS. M. FREEMAN, of Patterson, and Rev. Mr. PARDEE, of New-York. The second division, in charge of H.A. LINDSLAY, Esq., aid, was addressed by Rev. Dr. THOMPSON and Mr. SLIGER, the Secretary of the County Association. After the addresses the divisions walked in procession from their respective churches, connecting at a convenient point, when they were dismissed.

abstract: World, New-York, on the Trial; Trade Combinations; Trial; Defence closed; And Secret Trial of the Assassins
snippet: World, New-York, on the Trial; Trade Combinations; Trial; Defence closed; And Secret Trial of the Assassins
lead_paragraph: The government, it seems, is to have no aid from the Press of this city in its effort to fathom the conspiracy which assassinated President LINCOLN, and attempted the assassination of every prominent member of the Administration. On the contrary, it is denounced and assailed with a degree of vehemence fully equal to that which was thought adequate for the condemnation of the crime itself. The World, perhaps, takes the lead in this crusade; but it only echoes the sentiments of other journals less openly committed to the defamation and overthrow of the present Administration. It does not, indeed, openly defend the alleged assassins from the charge brought against them,-- but it assails the authorities which have arraigned them, the court by which they are to be tried, and every official connected with the case, with a degree of zeal which would scarcely be deemed admissible in any professional lawyer retained and paid for the defence. It brands the military tribunal as a "Star Chamber court," -- claims for the assassins the right to be tried by a jury before a civil court, denounces Secretary STANTON as a despot for ordering the trial under martial law, and affects to believe that the prisoners are tortured by thumb-screws and the rack, for the purpose of extorting confession from their lips.
headline: {'main': 'The Trial of the Assassins--Action of the Government.; Prices of Things--Trade Combinations-- Systematic Extortion.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Trial of the Assassins--Action of the Government.; Prices of Things--Trade Combinations-- Systematic Extortion.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: the World too Friendly by Half
snippet: the World too Friendly by Half
lead_paragraph: In the interest and for the sake of Mr. OSBON, now on trial for publishing contraband information, we beg the World to suspend its championship of his case. That journal may possibly intend to aid him, but it is much more likely to damage and damn him. We understand its strong eagerness to denounce the Court and Judge-Advocate and everybody in any way representing the government in this or any other matter. But it is scarcely worth while to gratify this propensity at the risk of bringing upon a gentleman whom the World deems innocent, all the evils and calamities which, according to its predictions, now await him. Mr. OSBON is not "hounded to the gallows," and is not in the slightest danger of being "hung for a crime which he never committed." The court by which he is tried is certain to find him guilty of nothing which he has not done; and all the affected anxiety of the World on his account, in our judgment, utterly thrown away.

abstract: -The honorable earnings of the soldiers are expended in a manner worthy of their public spirit and domestic virtue. They are investing millions in the Government Loan, and it is significant that, while the sale of sewing-machines for manufacturing purposes has fallen off with the contracts for army clothing, the sale of the Wheeler & Wilson machine for family use shows that the gallant soldiers have not forgotten their duty to their wives. Orders are received, written, perhaps, in the field on a drum-head to "forward" machines to feminine relatives. This is a good investment. The manager of a large estate says "he has no fears of the rent if the wife has a Wheeler & Wilson sewing-machine." -- Evening Post.

abstract: The mails of the Asia reached this city at a late hour last night. The papers are filled with details of the assassination of President LINCOLN; and the tone of editorial comment on the great crime is in the main just and friendly. A special dispatch from Halifax, May 11, to the Philadelphia Ledger says: "Financial advices by the Asia announce a heavy surplus of money offering, with a very limited demand. Instances are noted where prime paper was discounted, at 3 1/2 per cent. per annum. In Consols there had been exceedingly large purchases, as they afforded for the time being the most lucrative investment that capitalists could make. The sales of 5-2Os in Germany are reported to be heavy. A meeting of the holders of the Confederate loan, had been agitated, with the object of changing their bonds for cotton, the day for the redemption of the bonds in coin being looked upon as past. The flour market is reported as unchanged since the previous Friday, but there was, perhaps, a little more tone.

abstract: Organization in New-York
snippet: Organization in New-York
lead_paragraph: AID FOR SOLDIERS AND SAILORS. -- A "committee " of gentlemen of this city was organized some time since, for the propose of aiding in the work of caring for our sick and wounded soldiers, by opening reading-rooms, and furnishing to the soldiers libraries of entertaining and instructive books, such as history, travels and voyages, poetry, and the standard romances. The committee have contributed in a very important manner to the welfare of the tens of thousands of men who have been at various times in our hospitals and at our military posts, their books having been accessible to over one hundred thousand soldiers during the past two years. Some of these libraries at permanent forts and posts, from long use, are nearly worn out, and need repairs. The committee also desire to furnish to each of the new squadrons about to sail for foreign stations a "library" of books adapted to the wants of sailors. To secure the necessary "fund" for the above purposes, the Committee offer to the public a "grand patriotic, vocal and instrumental concert," at the Cooper Institute, on Wednesday evening, May 17. The entertainment will consist of the new music of the day, popularly rendered by the "Union (Anderson's) Glee Club," assisted by eminent lady amateurs. We commend this entertainment, to the patronage of our friends and the public, and bespeak a large and appreciative audience.

abstract: Stonewall, the Pirate, at Nassau
snippet: Stonewall, the Pirate, at Nassau
lead_paragraph: The rebel ram Stonewall turns up, not unexpectedly, at Nassau. The last we heard of this craft she had sailed from Teneriffe on the 1st of April, having been allowed but twentyfour hours to coal at that point. The date of her arrival at Nassau, we find to be the 6th inst. Her cruise, therefore, which has been marked by the destruction of a Baltimore merchantman, has extended over six weeks. By this it is apparent that she must have dispensed, from necessity, with the use of coal for the greater part of the voyage.

abstract: The Second and Fifth Corps, Army of the Potomac, have arrived at Bailey's Cross Roads, near Alexandria, where the Ninth Corps has been for some time in camp. SHERMAN's men will be coming in early next week, led by SHERIDAN's cavalry and the corps forming the Army of Georgia. All of our men have received kind treatment from the people of Virginia while on this homeward march; they, in return, have refrained from foraging and the usual destruction of property accompanying the movement of large bodies of troops. The day for the grand review is not fixed, but the men will be on hand probaby by the close of next week. Four complete armies, including seven corps of infantry, one of cavalry, and a full complement of artillery, are expected to oppear on that occasion.

abstract: Actor, Appeal for
snippet: Actor, Appeal for
lead_paragraph: We have dates from Mexico to the 27th ult. and from Vera Cruz to the 2d inst. The occupation of Saltillo and Monterey by the Liberals is confirmed, and it was reported that JUAREZ was about to establish his capital at the former place. A forced loan of $100,000 was levied upon the French and Imperialists in these two towns. There is a report that Gen. NEGRETE has two hundred adventurers twin the United States in his army. The Emperor started on his excursion from Mexico the 18th, and on arriving at Orizaba the 29th ult., received the news of the fall of Richmond and the rumored capitulation of LEE. Immediately all was confusion. MAXIMILIAN hurried back to Mexico, and sent Mr. ELOIN, the chief of his Cabinet, to proceed with all possible haste to the United States. The Empress CHARLOTTE took charge of the government during the temporary absence of MAXIMILIAN. Don JOSE RAMON PACHECO died in the City of Mexico on the 19th inst. We get news from Tabasco and Isla de Carmen to the 8th ult. The Juarists of the former place had entered Palzado (Isla de Carmen) and taken from all the merchants their stocks of guns, sabres, ammunition, &c. One hundred and twenty-five officers that were at Oaxaca, have joined the Juarists at Tabasco. Among them are two Generals. Several of the Governors and officers appointed by MAXIMILIAN, have pronounced against him.

abstract: Police Composition, Laws, >amp;c.; Full Description; Composition, Laws, >amp;c., Full Description
snippet: Police Composition, Laws, >amp;c.; Full Description; Composition, Laws, >amp;c., Full Description
lead_paragraph: Now that the control of the Fire Department is to be intrusted to a commission of gentlemen who are appointed by the Governor of the State, and inasmuch as the law which thus brings this department under the control of the State Government has encountered fierce and persistent opposition, it may be well to take a rapid glance at the work that has been done by that other commission, namely, the Metropolitan Police commission, which, several years ago, was held to be a body wholly unwarranted by the State Constitution. The politicians who at the outset arrayed themselves in hostility to the Metropolitan Police, precisely as politicians have recently done in respect to the Paid Fire Department, asserted that no Board of Commissioners could effect a permanent improvement in the character of the city police, or secure greater vigilance in the prevention of crime or in us detection and punishment. They held that King Caucus was autocrat here, and that primary conventions were, and of necessity must be, omnipotent in matters pertaining to police duty; and they told us of police magistrates who -- themselves utter vassals under the thumbs of the wire-pulling politicians that had made them magistrates -- would nullify the labors of any Board of Police Commissioners that might essay the management of a police force in this city under the law of 1857, organizing the Department of Metropolitan Police. Time and trial, happily, have shown these gentlemen their error.

abstract: DEDICATION OF THE ROSS-STREET CHURCH. -- The dedication services in the Ross-street Church commence at 10 A.M., to-day, with a sermon by Rev. Dr. KREBS of New-York. The society, under whose auspices this building was erected, was organized in May, 1864, and at that time numbered only thirty-five members. Up to the present time they have been worshipping in the Chapel of Christ Church, Broadway, E.D., and have increased two-fold. By the munificence of S.M. BEARD, Esq., No. 9 Bedford-avenue, his brother ELI and Dr. WRIGHT, six lots were purchased on Ross-street, running through to Wilson-street, for the purpose of erecting a church worthy of the society. The main building contemplated on Ross-street has not yet been commenced, but the chapel in which the dedication service will be [???]ed to-morrow is finished, and is a source of pride to its originators and the public. It occupies two full lots, while the ground for the main church will occupy four. The entire cost of the church, chapel &c., will probably reach $100,000. In the afternoon, Rev. Dr. Simmons, of Brooklyn, will preach, and in the evening. Rev. CHAS. S. POMEROY, pastor. The society is on the Old School Presbyterian, under the jurisdiction of the Nassau Presbytery.
