abstract: Wise, Ex-Gov., and Fernando Wood, on John Brown's Execution; And Ex-Gov. Wise on John Brown's Execution; Ex-Gov. Wise on Executing
snippet: Wise, Ex-Gov., and Fernando Wood, on John Brown's Execution; And Ex-Gov. Wise on John Brown's Execution; Ex-Gov. Wise on Executing
lead_paragraph: The correspondence recently published, between ex-Gov. WISE and FERNANDO WOOD on the subject of JOHN BROWN's execution, is highly honorable to both parties. One hardly knows which to admire most, WOOD's humanity or WISE's firmness. And then it is exceedingly interesting to know how the "ultra friends of the South," of whom Mr. WOOD was one, according to his recent speeches, felt about JOHN BROWN and other people at that time. Mr. WOOD, it will be perceived, entirely agreed with Governor WISE in thinking that somebody ought to be hanged; but he differed with him as to who it ought to be. WOOD thought that it ought to be SEWARD, and announced that were he Governor of Virginia, and could catch him, he would hang him. The Secretary of State has long known that the slaveholders' hatred of him might some time or other find expression in acts of violence, but he little knew how near he stood to an untimely end in 1859. Only two little "if's" stood between him and the gallows. "If" FERNANDO WOOD had been Governor of "Virginia, and "if" he had been able "to catch him" it would have been all up with him. It is impossible, even at this distance of time, to read of such a hair-breadth escape without a shudder; and it is certainly reassuring to know that if troublous times should ever come upon us again, we have among us a man of such nerve, and such lofty ambition as this letter proves Mr. WOOD to be. The cause of the South, too, we may be sure, will be well taken care of so long as it has such "ultra friends" amongst us as he has shown himself. WISE, however, is such a fine fellow, and shows in this letter such a clear appreciation of the duties of a chief magistrate in certain trying positions, to which out of respect for his own position just now, we will not more particularly allude, that we cannot bear to have him leave the country. The loss of such a man at this crisis, would be a serious one for us all. We do not know whether he has been paroled, or whether he is within reach, or of how many leading rebels President JOHNSON intends to make an example; but we sincerely trust that in selecting candidates for such a fate, his claims may not be overlooked. So ardent a lover of strict justice, of the full vigor of the law, as he proved himself in the case of BROWN, would surely rejoice even in being himself executed for rebellion. It could hardly fail to be a satisfaction to him to illustrate his own doctrines on the scaffold. There has been no worse traitor than himself in the whole rebel army. The crimes deliberately done by him, to use his own language, "have been of the deepest and darkest kind that can be committed against our people." We propose "to allow him an excess of counsel and unusual freedom of speech," but we should like to have him "legally and fairly tried and convicted," as he describes JOHN BROWN to have been. Hanging would follow as a matter of course, but to this, unless we are greatly mistaken in him, he is not the man to object it may be said, that if he was hanged, it would make a martyr of him at the South, but to this he, himself, furnishes us with a full and conclusive reply:

abstract: "Historicus" on Democracy and the Rebellion
snippet: "Historicus" on Democracy and the Rebellion
lead_paragraph: The assassination of Mr. LINCOLN called forth an able letter from "Historicus" to the London Times, which we copy to-day, and in which, as our readers may see, there was no lack of just appreciation and kindly expression. After a paragraph or two about Mr. LINCOLN's character, however, the writer turns to consider the fact of the collapse of the rebellion, and the effect which it will have in England. He sees, apparently, that it is likely to have a political effect there, and that it may tend to shake the firmness of the political forms with which the British aristocracy has buttressed itself; and he hastens to argue that any effect of that kind will be an illogical one. "In my judgment," says he, "the war in America had nothing whatever to do with democracy. It arose from an irreconcilable opposition of interests, and from an irrepressible social conflict which might have equally broken out in a monarchical or in an aristocratical State." Possibly it might, but it would not follow that it would have nothing to do with democracy, even in that case. If it was a conflict which involved the success or the overthrow of democratic principles, it makes no difference what was the form of the government under which it arose. If we are right in our understanding, that the rebellion was in the interest of slavery, its overthrow is certainly for the interest of true democracy. If the principles which set it on foot and sustained it were anti-democratic, how could it have had "nothing whatever to do with democracy?"

abstract: The United States vs. The Steamer Blenheim, &c. -- This vessel was captured at Fort Fisher, after the taking of that fort by our forces, through the ruse of Lieutenant-Commander Cushing, who compelled the signal men to exhibit the usual blockade signals, in consequence of which the blockade-runner ran into the arms of the United States fleet. She was sold with her tackle for $55,778 22. On motion of Mr. H.H. Rice, Assistant District-Attorney, the decree for the distribution of the net proceeds, $52,122 45, have been entered, giving half to the United States, and distributing the other half between the Tristram Shandy, Lillian, Britannia, Osceola and Gettysburgh, under the command of Rear-Admiral Porter.

abstract: At a meeting of the Board of Education, last evening, was shown that the compensation of teachers of music, German and French, in the Ward Schools, is, in many instances, greater than that of the principals of the schools. Appropriations were made for school purposes to the amount of $413,000, and a requisition was ordered upon the Comptroller for $300,000 to meet current expenses.

abstract: Dunn and Davis Prize Fight
snippet: Dunn and Davis Prize Fight
lead_paragraph: The long-talked of prize fight between JAMES DUNN, of Brooklyn, and WILLIAM M. DAVIS, of California, for $4,000, came off on Tuesday morning, at Metamora, Pike County, Penn. The match was made on the 14th of February last. DUNN, the victor in the disgraceful contest, was born in the County of Kildare, Ireland, and came to this country when about six years of age. He is about 5 feet 11 inches in height, and his ordinary weight is about 180 pounds. DAVIS is also a native of Ireland, and, like DUNN, emigrated to this country at an early age. He is of about the same height as his antagonist, but weighs about 30 pounds heavier.

abstract: It will be seen by the advertisement that the fine steamship Guiding Star is to be sent to Europe by her owners, the New-York Mail Steamship Company, on the 15th of June. This will be good news to those contemplating a voyage to the Old World. The Guiding Star is a vessel of over 2,500 tons burden, is 315 feet long, and has accommodations for nearly 300 first-class passengers. Her spacious saloons are models of elegance and ease, and her state-rooms commodious and comfortable. She has a powerful engine and is a fast sailer. Her commander, Capt. W.R. BELL, will, no doubt, be equally popular on this steamer as on the Evening Star, on the New-Orleans route. The Guiding Star can be inspected by those desirous of seeing her, at the pier, No. 46, North River, after the 27th inst. Tickets can be obtained upon application at the office of the company, No. 10 Barclay-street.

abstract: The European journals wonder much at the equipoise maintained by our constitutional system after the assassination of President LINCOLN. They will wonder yet more at the height of our public spirit as indicated by the rapid fall of gold, and the immense subscriptions to our national loan. An end will incontinently be made of two points, which the London Times, as well as all the Tory journals, have been magnifying into great consequence. It has been insisted that even if the North should succeed, its preternatural efforts would leave it in a state of absolute exhaustion. Also, that it would find the task of reconstructing the South as formidable as the overcoming it by arms. Yet we have now exhibited our exhaustion by a week's subscription to the popular loan, running from six millions up to forty-two millions a day. The fall in the premium of gold nearly seventy per cent., since the week following the surrender of LEE, shows what is thought here of reconstruction, the so-called lion in our path. Two facts like these are worth volumes of a priori reasonings. They present the truth so perfectly, that even the dullest Englishman must be impressed by them. To these and other such developments let us trust for satisfaction of all the libels upon our government, during its late ordeal. Their silent eloquence is infinitely more effective than any answer in words.

abstract: We learn from Havana that the rebel ram Stoneman reached that port on the morning of the 11th inst. Her arrival caused considerable excitement. No salute was fired; but it is reported that the Admiral of the port immediately sent an officer on board, offering the courtesies of the station, and on the following day went himself.
lead_paragraph: We learn from Havana that the rebel ram Stoneman reached that port on the morning of the 11th inst. Her arrival caused considerable excitement. No salute was fired; but it is reported that the Admiral of the port immediately sent an officer on board, offering the courtesies of the station, and on the following day went himself. Our Consul at Havana, learning that the Stonewall might proceed to Key West, after some trouble with the authorities, found means to send the steamer Columbia with dispatches to Commodore STRIBLING. The frigate Po[???]hutton and the gunboat Aries were immediately dispatched to Havana, where they arrived on the 18th.

abstract: Yesterday morning, Mr. Dickinson, the United States District-Attorney, moved that the trial of Ex-Navy-Agent Henderson be set down for some early and convenient day. He said the case was one of great public interest, and importance to the accused, who was charged with a grave offence. In a cause of so much importance, in which witnesses would have to be called, who would be obliged to leave their official stations, it was eminently due to all the parties to fix a day for the trial. That course would be most convenient to all, as it would afford an opportunity for a free and impartial trial, and thus contribute to the ends of justice.

abstract: Military Trial was Necessary
snippet: Military Trial was Necessary
lead_paragraph: MILITARY TRIAL OF THE ASSASSINS. -- We publish an article in another column, from one of the ablest and most distinguished jurists in the country, upon the difficulties that would be encountered in attempting to try the conspirators by civil tribunals. A good many matters are suggested which have probably escaped the attention of those who are so clamorous in their denunciation of the government for trying these men by a military tribunal. It is quite clear that under the ordinary modes of trial by civil tribunals, there would have been scarcely a possibility of arriving at the truth in regard to their guilt.

abstract: Particulars of
snippet: Particulars of
lead_paragraph: Now that the blockade restrictions are being removed from the Southern ports throughout the revolted States, and the war has reached the culminating point toward peace, we find a growing interest in the reopening trade and travel that must ensue on the reestablishment of commercial relations between the North and South. Consequent upon this state of affairs in the commercial world, the shipping interest are busily engaged in looking out for advantageous employment for their steam marine, now left almost entirely idle in consequence of the government charters having been discontinued.

abstract: The Mobile News of the 6th inst. says that city was then in telegraphic communication with Columbus, Miss., and Gainesville, Ala., and the lines to New-Orleans were rapidly approaching completion. A dispatch to the News, dated Columbus, Miss., May 5, says: "The lines are working on the Mobile and Ohio Railroad as far north as Baldwyn, thirty-one miles south of Corinth. On the Southern Road, from Meridian to Clinton, thirty-five (35) miles from Vicksburgh. On the New-Orleans and Jackson Road, from Canton, Miss., to Amite, sixty-eight miles from New-Orleans. On the Mississippi Central Road, from Canton to Holly Springs. On the Grenada and Memphis Road, from Grenada to Senatobia, forty miles from Memphis. We also have a line from Osyka, Mississippi, to Clinton, Louisiana, and Woodville, Miss."

abstract: Trade, Revival of
snippet: Trade, Revival of
lead_paragraph: THE BLOCKADE-RUNNERS. -- The blockade-running business has had a hard time of it of late. But it appears by the news to-day to have still some attractions for a class of speculators in the neutral interest. There is no longer a market for foreign powder and shot down South; but there is a market for cotton in Liverpool, whether it is gotten in honest trade, or run out, like burglars' plunder, under cover of night. The Florida coast, it seems, still offers some facilities for this sort of adventure, as we presume does also that of Texas. The end of it, however, at the present rate of captures, can hardly be distant.

abstract: The Eight Ward street-walkers, whose name is legion, have recently made that port of the city a pandemonium. While they and their satellites, the Eighth Ward thieves and gamesters, kept within their dens, and committed their robberies and assaults within doors, the police were powerless; but when they became emboldened, and resorted to the street, there capturing and robbing every sailor or soldier who happened to wander into Greene, Mercer, Spring and other streets in that region, and annoying citizens who had business in either of those streets after nighfall, they rendered themselves liable to arrest. And they were arrested, on Wednesday night, by Capt. MILLS and a platoon of men, and held at the Eighth Ward Police-station until morning, when they were taken to court and committed for examination. The number of prisoners is fifty-five; and of the entire gang, perhaps three rendered their names truly. They are girls of 15, 18 and 20; hardened sinners of from 25 to 30; mothers of infants, and two of them claim to be married women. Several were committed to the workhouse, others were released on bail, and the residue were held for trial before the Court of Special Sessions.

abstract: Secret History of; Interior of the Late; Unpopularity of, Interior View of Confederacy
snippet: Secret History of; Interior of the Late; Unpopularity of, Interior View of Confederacy
lead_paragraph: The following letter was written by a gentleman who occupied the position of Private Secretary to one of the most influential members of JEFF. DAVIS' Cabinet throughout the rebellion. It comes, therefore, from one well qualified to set forth the actual condition of affairs in the rebel capital during the latter days of the rebellion. It gives an interior view of the movements and sentiments of the rebel government such an it has not been possible to obtain hitherto. R.D.F.

abstract: Length of Services and Reputation; Fire Departm't; Before Supreme Court
snippet: Length of Services and Reputation; Fire Departm't; Before Supreme Court
lead_paragraph: The question as to the constitutionality of the recent act of the Legislature of this State, creating a Metropolitan Fire Department for this city, was argued yesterday at much length before the General Term of the Supreme Court. The court was composed of presiding Justice INGRAHAM, and Justices CLERKE and BARNARD. Attorney-General JOHN COCHRANE, who represents the interests of the old Fire Department, presented an argument against the constitutionality of the new law, and Mr. WALDO HUTCHINS, who is one of the counsel for the new commissioners, contended that the late act is in every respect valid. The court reserved its decision. It is understood, however, that a decision will be given in time to bring the case before the Court of Appeals at the June Term, if it be deemed advisable by either side to refer the questions involved to the court of last resort.

abstract: THE TRIAL OF THE ASSASSINS. -- There are points of interest in the testimony taken yesterday. One refers to an alleged communication made by the witness, WHICHMAN, to an officer of the War Department respecting the plot, before the assassination. Another points directly to DAVIS, as having indorsed the "detached service" scheme in a note addressed to BENJAMIN, his Secretary of State. The note has been produced before the court, and the handwriting is sworn to.

abstract: We have long since learned to get along without the benefit of European critical appreciation of our military efforts, just as we wore forced, also, to get along, to a great extent, without European sympathy in our struggle with the rebellion.
lead_paragraph: We have long since learned to get along without the benefit of European critical appreciation of our military efforts, just as we wore forced, also, to get along, to a great extent, without European sympathy in our struggle with the rebellion. And yet it has been interesting to notice the praise recently accorded by the press of England and the Continent to the leading Union Generals -- praise which, though it "has come tardy off," is, nevertheless, unlisted, and not undiscrimination. This Transatlantic indorsement cannot add much to the prestige of our arms, and appears too into to exercise any influence whatever on the fortunes of war. But we are glad to receive it for the sake of the heroes it celebrates, so that they may see that it is not the partial reverence of grateful compatriots which has made them illustrations, but that their fame is world-wide and historic.

abstract: THE PAID FIRE DEPARTMENT. -- The matter of the constitutionality of the law passed by the late Legislature, creating a Metropolitan Fire Department, was argued yesterday before the general term of the Supreme Court. Attorney-General COCHRAN, on behalf of the Old Fire Department, contended that the act limited the territorial authority of the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners to the boundaries of the City of New-York, and therefore, the appointment of these gentlemen by the Governor was in direct violation of article 10, section 2, of the State Constitution, which provides that city officers shall be elected by their constituents, or be appointed by some of the city authorities. This point was argued at length, and formed the main ground of objection on the part of the plaintiffs. Per contra, it was urged by Mr. WALDO HUTCHINGS, on behalf of the commissioners, that the act of the Legislature created a new civil division of the State for certain purposes, which might be done without violating article 10, section 2, of the State Constitution, and that their offices are new offices, having new powers, created since the adoption of the constitution, and not affected by that instrument. Mr. HUTCHINGS also contended, in answer to the charge of intrusion by the defendants into the offices of the officers of the old department, that the latter were not public officers in any sense, nor were they city or county officers, but simply officers of a corporation which was abolished by a statute in a constitutional manner. The court reserved its decision; in any event the matter is likely to come before the Court of Appeals for adjudication at its June term.

The court reserved its decision; in any event the matter is likely to come before the Court of Appeals for adjudication at its June term.

abstract: Smith's, Kirby War and Last Ditch
snippet: Smith's, Kirby War and Last Ditch
lead_paragraph: KIRBY SMITH's WAR. -- That famous "last ditch" has born discovered again. It wasn't in Virginia. It wasn't in either Carolina. It wasn't in Georgia, or in any of the Gulf States. It was in none, of the Border States -- those Belgiums of the war. It was not even in "Maryland, my Maryland." It was lying perdu all the time that LEE and JOHNSTON and TAYLOR were sticking for it, and finding it not, on the other side of the Mississippi. KIRBY SMITH has brought it out, and with a great flourish of trumpets, he announces that he is bestriding the said ditch, and will defend it against all assailant.

abstract: The formidable iron-clad ram Dunderberg is now about approaching completion. Her keel being laid Oct. 4, 1862, it was expected that long since she would have participated in the splendid naval engagements that have marked the history of our navy during the rebellion; but owing to various causes, the delay in her machinery and the contemplated change by the government in her original design, the bright anticipations respecting her have not been realized.
lead_paragraph: The formidable iron-clad ram Dunderberg is now about approaching completion. Her keel being laid Oct. 4, 1862, it was expected that long since she would have participated in the splendid naval engagements that have marked the history of our navy during the rebellion; but owing to various causes, the delay in her machinery and the contemplated change by the government in her original design, the bright anticipations respecting her have not been realized. She is 5,090 tons burden, 378 feet long, 68 feet wide, and 32 feet deep; pierced for 18 guns, many of which will be 15-inch in calibre. In the original plan she was to have two turrets placed on the casemates, which were to be pierced for 8 guns only. The plan now being carried out is the entire removal of the turrets and the extension of the casemate the entire length of the vessel, showing on both sides 9 port-holes. Mr. WEBB is her builder, foot of Sixth-street. She will be launched probably in about one month or six weeks.

abstract: THE INTERIOR OF THE LATE CONFEDERACY. -- We have, this morning, a statement of a late Confederate official as to the military and financial condition of the Confederacy before its final dissolution, as to the jealousies and backbitings among the chief conspirators, as to DAVIS' influence or lack of influence, as to the condition of the rebel exchequer abroad, as to the appalling suddenness of the calamity which overtook the rebel cause, and as to sundry points of interest viewed from a Southern standpoint. The Confederate military strength (before the surrender of Richmond) east of the Mississippi was about 100,000 men, all told, according to this authority. DAVIS and his fellow fugitives had but $500,000 in their wallets on leaving the rebel capital, and this sum was mainly in silver, which, by this writer's showing, accounts for its bulk. The principal portion of the rebel treasure, it seems, was in foreign hands -- a fact which at least shows that, in spite of all the bluster and brag to the contrary, the necessity of an early flight had been anticipated, and in part provided for a considerable time before the military surrender.
lead_paragraph: THE INTERIOR OF THE LATE CONFEDERACY. -- We have, this morning, a statement of a late Confederate official as to the military and financial condition of the Confederacy before its final dissolution, as to the jealousies and backbitings among the chief conspirators, as to DAVIS' influence or lack of influence, as to the condition of the rebel exchequer abroad, as to the appalling suddenness of the calamity which overtook the rebel cause, and as to sundry points of interest viewed from a Southern standpoint. The Confederate military strength (before the surrender of Richmond) east of the Mississippi was about 100,000 men, all told, according to this authority. DAVIS and his fellow fugitives had but $500,000 in their wallets on leaving the rebel capital, and this sum was mainly in silver, which, by this writer's showing, accounts for its bulk. The principal portion of the rebel treasure, it seems, was in foreign hands -- a fact which at least shows that, in spite of all the bluster and brag to the contrary, the necessity of an early flight had been anticipated, and in part provided for a considerable time before the military surrender.

abstract: REVIVAL OF SOUTHERN TRADE. -- The effect of the President's proclamation of the 1st instant, reopening the Southern ports from the Chesapeake to the Mississippi, followed a few days later by the Treasury regulations respecting shipments to the States recently in rebellion, has been to infuse great activity into business circles generally. Our leading shipping-merchants have responded to the opportunity with enthusiastic alacrity, and that spirit of irresistible enterprise which must soon restore trade to the channels in which it ran so prosperously before the war. Already many of the old coasting lines of steamships have been reestablished and new lines organized or projected, with a good prospect of lucrative employment in both passenger and freighting business. Since the 1st inst., and up to the 17th, no less than twenty-one steamers, one ship, four barks, two brigs and twenty schooners have cleared at the Custom-house for Southern destinations, including not alone the larger ports like New-Orleans, Mobile, Charleston, Savannah and Richmond, but the smaller entrepots on the coast line in North Carolina and Florida. This commercial intercourse, prosecuted in a liberal spirit, will be one of the weightiest and most effective agents for promptly bringing about the coming era of material prosperity, and dispelling the last vestige of the unhappy condition of affairs which has disturbed the country during the past four years.
lead_paragraph: REVIVAL OF SOUTHERN TRADE. -- The effect of the President's proclamation of the 1st instant, reopening the Southern ports from the Chesapeake to the Mississippi, followed a few days later by the Treasury regulations respecting shipments to the States recently in rebellion, has been to infuse great activity into business circles generally. Our leading shipping-merchants have responded to the opportunity with enthusiastic alacrity, and that spirit of irresistible enterprise which must soon restore trade to the channels in which it ran so prosperously before the war. Already many of the old coasting lines of steamships have been reestablished and new lines organized or projected, with a good prospect of lucrative employment in both passenger and freighting business. Since the 1st inst., and up to the 17th, no less than twenty-one steamers, one ship, four barks, two brigs and twenty schooners have cleared at the Custom-house for Southern destinations, including not alone the larger ports like New-Orleans, Mobile, Charleston, Savannah and Richmond, but the smaller entrepots on the coast line in North Carolina and Florida. This commercial intercourse, prosecuted in a liberal spirit, will be one of the weightiest and most effective agents for promptly bringing about the coming era of material prosperity, and dispelling the last vestige of the unhappy condition of affairs which has disturbed the country during the past four years.

abstract: THE "MOURNING DRAPEBY" USED FOR DRESSES FOR SOLDIERS' WIDOWS. Much of the "mourning drapery" used for decoration at the funeral of our late President, in this city, has been collected by the NewYork State Agent, No. 50 Howard-street, for the widows and orphans of our soldiers.
lead_paragraph: THE "MOURNING DRAPEBY" USED FOR DRESSES FOR SOLDIERS' WIDOWS. -- Much of the "mourning drapery" used for decoration at the funeral of our late President, in this city, has been collected by the NewYork State Agent, No. 50 Howard-street, for the widows and orphans of our soldiers. An inspection of the goods obtained exhibits, in a marked manner, the disregard for cost animating the purchasers -- costly crape, bombazine, alapacea, and quantities of "solesia" are found. Over $1,000 worth has already been obtained. The Broadway Bank, New-York Club, Messrs. H.G. CLAFLIN & Co., and others are among the contributors. The goods have been packed in parcels containing enough for two or three dresses, and soldiers' widows can obtain them by applying to Mrs. WOOD, "Matron," at the above place.

abstract: Derby's, Earl, Eulogy of the Rebels
snippet: Derby's, Earl, Eulogy of the Rebels
lead_paragraph: The Earl of DERBY'S refusal to believe that "the late detestable act of assassination," can have been connived or concocted by the Confederates, because it is "so alien to the courageous, manly, and at the same time, forbearing course which they have adopted in the struggle for everything that is dear to them," reveals a most extraordinary determination to overlook or to pervert some of the most notorious facts of the war, and the interpolation of this passage in his speech on Mr. LINCOLN's death, deprives it of most of its value as an expression of sympathy, if, indeed, it was ever intended to bear that character. It would, in fact, be difficult to think of anything in worse taste than to insert a eulogy on the rebel mode of conducting hostilities in an address intended to offer Tory condolence to the people of the North.

abstract: London Times, the Teachings of
snippet: London Times, the Teachings of
lead_paragraph: A review of the teachings of the London Times on the subject of the rebellion, is being prepared in England, and will, we believe, be issued very shortly. It will be a singular and rather amusing pamphlet. In what manner it will be arranged, we do not know, but it ought to contain three divisions devoted to the letters of the New-York correspondents, the articles of the money editor, and the regular editorials respectively. The New-York correspondents showed twice a week for nearly two years that nobody at the North was in favor of the war, except the office-holders and contractors; and declared before the battle of Gettysburgh that every man, woman and child at the North, wished for LEE's success. He also proved regularly, that each levy of men was the last that could be raised, and that taxation was something to which Americans would never submit.

abstract: THE WALPOLE BANK ROBBERY. In November last, a party of burglars broke into the dwelling of the cashier of the Walpole Bank, at Walpole, N.H., and stole from that officer's pantaloons pocket the key to the safe, and with this entered the vault, stealing $45,000 worth of bank-notes, Treasury notes and United States bonds.
lead_paragraph: THE WALPOLE BANK ROBBERY. -- In November last, a party of burglars broke into the dwelling of the cashier of the Walpole Bank, at Walpole, N.H., and stole from that officer's pantaloons pocket the key to the safe, and with this entered the vault, stealing $45,000 worth of bank-notes, Treasury notes and United States bonds. They fled, and until recently baffled the police. But a day or two since, detectives GOLDEN, KELSO and RADFORD, of this city, to whom the "working up of the case" had been intrusted, stumbled upon information which led them to suspect one MAX SINBORN, a noted German burglar, residing near Saratoga. They accordingly went thither, and took him into custody, and on searching his palatial dwelling, found a complete set of burglar's tools, wax impressions, skeleton keys, &c., three thousand dollar United States bonds that had been stolen from the Walpole Bank, and a large number of coupons. Yesterday morning they brought the prisoner to this city, and last evening they started with him for Walpole.

abstract: Accomplices Fleeing to Europe
snippet: Accomplices Fleeing to Europe
lead_paragraph: FLEEING FROM JUSTICE. -- There is little room to doubt that two or more of the chief rebel conspirators-including BLACKBURN, of yellow fever notoriety-took ship for Europe in the steamship Peruvian, which sailed from Quebec on Saturday, the 13th inst. By this route it is just possible they may have a start of one or more days ahead of the reports of their complicity in the assassins' plot which went out by the City of London and the Suxonia on the 13th. There is a chance that a telegram from Queenstown might overtake them at Liverpool, unless they leave the Peruvian at Derry, her Irish calling port. It is of considerable consequence, especially if SURRATT is one of the fugitives, that the Extradition Treaty should be tested to secure, if possible, their surrender, or failing that, to show the world how the "Confederate" agencies abroad will identify themselves with the assassins, and how they will come to the rescue of these fugitives when their case appears before the British Courts. In the neighboring Provinces the rebel agents threaten with death any witness who shall venture to give testimony tending to eliminate the facts. In England, the agents will hardly show less anxiety in the promises.

lead_paragraph: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of all military movements in the different departments from the pens of our special correspondents. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest, and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents, in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest, financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: Trade Restrictions, Removal of
snippet: Trade Restrictions, Removal of
lead_paragraph: REMOVAL OF TRADE RESTRICTIONS. -- We have already referred to the activity prevailing in business circles in consequence of the partial removal of restrictions upon trade with the States lately in rebellion. From a circular of the Secretary of the Treasury, published yesterday, it appears that commercial intercourse with the States east of the Mississippi is absolutely as untrammeled as ever it was before the war. The Custom-house authorities have entirely dispensed with the requirement which made it necessary for persona intending to ship goods to the recently opened ports to first prove their loyalty, and will in future pay little heed to the fact whether merchandize so shipped is contraband of war. Questions that may arise in relation to the loyalty of consignees are to be determined by the officers of the government at the places to which the goods are forwarded. The rules respecting shipments to Bermuda, Nassau, and other so-called "neutral" ports, which were necessary to prevent those places from being channels of supply from the North to the rebels, and which have been heretofore stringently enforced, will also be materially relaxed; and limited shipments can now be made to the ports formerly classed as "contraband," excepting, perhaps, Matamoras and a few other places whence rebels west of the Mississippi might receive aid and comfort, without giving bonds or consular certificates as to how the goods are to be disposed of. Under these circumstances, the shipping interest and trade generally have received a further impetus.

abstract: In the Court of General Sessions yesterday, Judge RUSSEL discharged the Grand Jury for the term, after thanking them for the diligence and capacity displayed by them during their sessions. This Grand Jury, of which JAMES G. KING, Esq., was foreman, has accomplished more work in a shorter time than any preceding Grand Jury known to the Court. During the ten days of their session, they have carefully considered and disposed of one hundred and seventy criminal complaints, and having finished up all business before them, are now discharged two weeks before the end of the term. The fairness and justness of their examinations, as well as the promptness with which they dispatched business, has much facilitated the operations of the Court of Sessions.

abstract: Our Resentments against
snippet: Our Resentments against
lead_paragraph: Americans are asked to bury their resentments against England in the grave of ABRAHAM LINCOLN. The unparalleled emotion which his death has excited in all classes of the kingdom avouches anew, it is said, the brotherhood of the two great nations, and is nature's own protestation against the continuance of further estrangement.

abstract: OUR MEXICAN RELATIONS. -- It will be seen by a letter in another column, that the American public has been widely misled in regard to the action of the new Mexican Government. The Commissioner now in this country from the Emperor MAXIMILIAN denies, in the most explicit manner, the statement that any portion of the Mexican territory has been ceded to France, and asserts also that Dr. GWIN has neither received any cession of land, nor any title whatever, and that, in fact, he has never had any relations or interviews with the Emperor, or with the members of his government Upon the same high authority the more recent report of negotiations between MAXIMILIAN and the rebel General, KIRBY SMITH, is flatly and positively contradicted. These assurances are timely, and will aid in defeating the foolish attempts made in some quarters to excite popular hostility against nations with which we have thus far maintained pacific relations.

abstract: New-York, Sweet Robbed by Williams, Strange Conduct of Alderman; Trial, Motion to Dismiss Denied
snippet: New-York, Sweet Robbed by Williams, Strange Conduct of Alderman; Trial, Motion to Dismiss Denied
lead_paragraph: Yesterday another purloiner of public property was discovered by the energetic and vigilant Capt. WAUGH, Chief of Police at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. Portable articles picked up by unsuspected but dishonest workmen are carried off, and it is supposed the average loss by this petty thieving amount to many thousands or tens of thousands of dollars annually. This is one of the reasons why the rules requiring passes to be shown to Capt. WAUGH by every visitor, whether a foreign naval officer or American citizen, are so stringently carried out..... The following are the recent arrivals of men-of-war at the yard: The Daylight, May 15; Bigonia, May 16; Torpedo, Spuyten Tyful, May 17..... The following vessels are building at the yard: Madawaska, steamer; Kalamazoo, iron-clad monitor; Moshula, steamer; Quizizebaug, steamer; and Ontario, steamer, nearly ready to launch.... The Idaho is receiving Dickerson's engines at the Morgan Iron-Works; the sea monitor Puritan is lying at the Continental Iron-Works, Greenpoint, guarded by a single watchman, who has faithfully kept his post for about one year; the Modoe, light-draft iron-clad, is finished at Greenpoint, and will go to the Navy-yard next week; the Talahama, Wimcoska, P[???], and Wampahody are receiving boilers and machinery at New-York; the Cohocs, a light-draft monitor, at Greenpoint, will be launched about June 1.

abstract: Indorsement of Oldham's Incendiary Plan; captured; London Saturday Review on Assassination and War
snippet: Indorsement of Oldham's Incendiary Plan; captured; London Saturday Review on Assassination and War
lead_paragraph: The journals that have been, all along, most eager to palliate the rebellion, are now most concerned to discredit the evidence thus far brought against the chief conspirators. There is nothing unnatural in this. But one would suppose that even the readiest of DAVIS' apologists would hesitate to affirm that his formal indorsement of OLDHAM'S detailed plan for devastating the North, supplied no evidence of his approval of the "detached service." "There is nothing," says one eager advocate, "in that (the indorsement) to implicate DAVIS in the assassination plot." Again, says the same zealous pleader, "Even the indorsement is not an approval of the composition, but simply a request, as if in the ordinary routine of official business, that the Secretary of State should see Gen. HARRIS about it!" That, of course, was all. DAVIS himself certainly didn't formally approve of the phosphoric preparation for smothering Northern women and children in their beds. The "composition," whatever it was, had not been submitted to the rebel President. It had been put into the hands of a scientific agent of the Confederacy -- Prof. MCCULLOUGH -- and DAVIS himself is careful to note the fact that the secret of the preparation was known only to one person besides the Professor. So that his advocate wastes words in denying that the rebel President gave the "composition" his indorsement.
headline: {'main': 'A Plea for the Conspirators.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A Plea for the Conspirators.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: WHAT THE LADIES CAN DO. -- On Sunday the ladies of Trinity (Episcopal) Church, Hoboken, reported, through the rector, to the congregation, that their late Fancy Fair in aid of a fund for building a school-house and parsonage, had cleared $1,710, after paying all expenses. Considering they have raised upwards of $6,000 besides to pay off the ground debt in the last two years, the ladies, have done nobly.

abstract: Testimonial at Academy Music, N. Y.
snippet: Testimonial at Academy Music, N. Y.
lead_paragraph: The Academy of Musical last night was the scene of a large house and a very hearty welcome by the Free and Accepted Masons of New-York to R.W. ALBERT G. MACKEY, High Priest of the General Grand Chapter of the United States of America. The stage was handsomely arranged with the golden emblems of the order. At the back of the stage were the words "Welcome to Mackey," in lines of fire. The stage itself was filled with representatives from Grand Lodges through the country, and the gentlemen occupying the seats were richly dressed in the regalia of their rank and order.

abstract: at New-York State Agency; New-York State Agency, Gov. Fenton s Visit to
snippet: at New-York State Agency; New-York State Agency, Gov. Fenton s Visit to
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning Gov. FENTON visited the New-York State Agency for soldiers, corner of Howard and Mercer streets, and the occasion was one of considerable interest to those connected with that beneficent institution, the inmates and the visitors. Contrary to the usual custom in such cases, very little preparation was made for the tour of inspection and domiciliary visit of the worthy Governor, it being the object of Col. COLYER, the indefatigable Superintendent of the depot, to show the Governor the actual working of the institution and not to exhibit it in mere holiday dress.

abstract: The popular mind is greatly interested in the whereabouts of JEFF. DAVIS, and what the government proposes to the with him. Rumor, and rumor alone, as yet, designates Fort Lafayette as the place of his confinement prior to trial.
lead_paragraph: The popular mind is greatly interested in the whereabouts of JEFF. DAVIS, and what the government proposes to the with him. Rumor, and rumor alone, as yet, designates Fort Lafayette as the place of his confinement prior to trial. Gen. DIX, who, in his capacity of commander of this department, controls Fort Lafayette, as he does Fort Warren, at Boston Harbor, has received no official intimation of the coming of the distinguished rebel. All that is known even of the possibility of his coming, is that unusual activity is noticeable at the fort, and certain matters predicting the arrival of and preparation for somebody are in training. Fort Lafayette is the cleanest of all clean places, and the whitest washed of all whitewashed fortifications, and yet the scouring -- brush, the broom and the paint-pot were never in such brisk use as at this time. The rooms -- for it is a popular delusion that there are cells at the fort -- are in good order, safely barricaded and guarded. The smallest room is about thirteen feet wide and perhaps twenty-five feet long. In this were formerly lodged such men of note as the government wished to be kept from general intercourse. This room is very comfortable, light, airy, clean, and next to the guard-house. Neither BEALL nor KENNEDY were confined there, and it is not likely that JEFF. will be. The next room, No. 2, is somewhat larger, but equally comfortable and light. In this, after the State and a few prisoners of war were removed, BEALL, and subsequently KENNEDY, were kept. At that time fastenings of great security were put upon the door and windows, and it is now the most suitable place in which to keep the expected prisoner. The bounty-brokers who were confined in No. 3, (also a large and comfortable room,) were released some time since. Besides these, there are no rooms, properly speaking, on the ground floor. The large batteries in which stand the heavy guns, were partitioned off into pens large enough for the comfortable lodgment of thirty or forty men each. In these the bounty-jumpers were confined, and there too they probably spent the most miserable month of their swindling existence. As they were either thieves or soldiers, their detention was regarded as a matter in the hands of the War Department, and it had been determined to send them at once to the front as enlisted men, when the sudden break-up of the Southern armies rendered further addition to the army unnecessary, and they were dismissed.

abstract: Grand Review in Washington, the
snippet: Grand Review in Washington, the
lead_paragraph: On Tuesday next begins the Grand Review at Washington. That this will prove to be beyond all comparisons the grandest military spectacle, over witnessed in America, is quite evident. By as much as the war of 1861 surpassed in magnitude and intensity its predecessors of 1775, 1812, and 1846, by so much will this parade exceed in magnificence all former ones. And what, indeed, are the exploits of the past compared with the luster which has lately here been added to American arms? What, in the North, were Bunker Hill, or Bennington, or Stony Point, or Trenton, or Saratoga? What, in the South, were Cowpens, and Eutaw, King's Mountain and Yorktown? What in 1812 and 1815 were Chippewa, Lundy's Lane or New-Orleans? What, finally, in the Mexican war were Taylor's Palo Alto, and Resaca, Monterey and Buena Vista, or Scott's Cherubusco and Chepultepec? Formerly, an army of 50,000 men was an astonishing and apparently irresistible force. It is a handful now. The regular army, in camp and garrison, will certainly double that number, and probably treble it. The gallant American dead, now sleeping under the soil so stoutly contested through four years, are to be counted by hundreds of thousands. The living veterans, who have wounds to show or a story of death escaped to tell, are numbered by millions. It is the survivors of an unparalleled war, the flower of the grandest armies ever seen in America, who, 200,000 strong, will pass, on Tuesday and Wednesday, in farewell review.
headline: {'main': 'The Grand Military Review.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Grand Military Review.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Fractional Currency Dealer at Yorkville Arrested
snippet: Fractional Currency Dealer at Yorkville Arrested
lead_paragraph: The citizens of Yorkville have been sorely annoyed for a year or eighteen months past by an avalanche of spurious fractional currency, and recently, many counterfeits having been passed upon their children and servants, several gentlemen lodged information with Captain HUTCHINGS, with the request that he would take measures to fathom the mystery. The Twelfth Ward (Twenty-third Precinct) police, on making cautious inquiry, soon ascertained that nearly every resident of the village had taken counterfeit fifty-cent and twenty-five cent fractional notes at Frederick SCHROEDER's grocery, Second-avenue, corner of Eighty-fifth-street, but that SCHROEDER had always readily and with seeming innocence redeemed this currency, and this disarmed suspicion. Having learned these facts, the police kept strict watch over SCHROEDER's grocery, and on Thursday night detected him in the sale of a large quantity of the spurious notes; but, hoping to learn who his confederates were, the officers kept their own counsel, and permitted him to go on with his sales until Friday afternoon, when, having gathered such information as they desired, they entered the grocery and apprehended SCHROEDER and his wife and their clerk, one LOUIS STOCK, and took possession of the place. In the money-fill they found spurious fractional notes of various denominations representing $90, and on SCHROEDER's other spurious currency was found. The police held possession of the prisoner's place of business on Friday night and yesterday morning delivered the prisoners to U.S. Marshal MURRAY.
headline: {'main': 'Vender of Spurious Currency Arrested in Yorkville.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Vender of Spurious Currency Arrested in Yorkville.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Among the many discharged and disabled soldiers, constantly passing through this city on their way to their homes or the hospital, numerous cases have been known where unsuspecting and guileless soldiers have been shamefully misled and robbed. Sharpers abound in the vicinity of all railroad depots and steamboat landings, on the lookout for discharged soldiers who have their pay with them. Bogus ambulances tempt the bewildered veteran, and he is cheated into going to places that he would fain avoid, and persuaded into making purchases that prove worthless bargains. Soldiers have been gravely informed that the Treasury cheeks they held were not negotiable, and often these unsuspecting man have paid as high as ten per cent. to get the government checks cashed. In short, every sort of confidence game and mode of extortion is practiced upon them.

abstract: Feetless Men from Southern Prisons
snippet: Feetless Men from Southern Prisons
lead_paragraph: THE FEETLESS MEN. -- Capt. JOHN J. GEER, author of the celebrated book "A Yankee Prisoner Loose in Dixie," is now engaged in selling several photographs of those unfortunate men who have lost their feet by exposure in the Southern prisons of Georgia. The proceeds from the sale of these pictures are devoted to the benefit of these "feetless men." Nothing could give a more harrowing or realizing sense of the awful sufferings endured by our gallant volunteers in those diabolical prison pens of the Confederacy, than these photographs. Without any shelter against the inclemency of the weather, scarcely any clothing, very little food, and no fire, the prisoners were compelled to walk about to keep what little blood yet remained in their systems in circulation. Constant contact with the cold sand, caused the blood to stagnate, and the feet of 287 of these prisoners actually rotted off, and of this wretchedly stricken band only 45 survive. Capt. GEER has had these men confided to his care, and he now attends to their present welfare at David's Island, while at the same time he is making strenuous exertions to procure some permanent home of refuge for his interesting family.

abstract: The Senior Class of the University inaugurated on Thursday last a custom common to most of our principal colleges, that of celebrating the day on which they take final leave of their Alma Mater. At 9:30 A.M. the class assembled in the chapel for devotional exercises. Afterward they gathered in the hall and sang a farewell to the old university and their various processors. A procession was then formed, and the class prosecuted to the southwest corner of the building, where the "class-ivy" was to be planted. Mr. T. DURNET delivered an address inscribing, in appropriate language, the i[???]t of the ceremony. The ivy was then planted by the President of the class, Mr. D. HOPKINS. The class then [???]ting the "Ivy Song" and adjourned to the recent of the professors, where remarks were n[???] by these gentlemen, expressing their interest in the occasion and their wishes for the welfare of the cities.

abstract: Express, New-York, on Caesar's Speech on Executing Catiline
snippet: Express, New-York, on Caesar's Speech on Executing Catiline
lead_paragraph: -- The Express recommends all who go for hanging JEFF. DAVIS, to "read over and over again the speech of JULIUS CAESAR, who opposed CICERO upon the hanging or the strangling of the followers of CATILINE." The best historians have considered CAESAR as privy to the conspiracy. In invoking for JEFF. DAVIS CAESAR's arguments in behalf of the followers of CATILINE, is the Express moved by a like fellow feeling?

abstract: The dispostion to be made of JEFF. DAVIS is just now the absorbing popular question. Yesterday we had dispatches stating that himself family and staff officers, had arrived at Fortress Monroe, in the steamer Wm.H. Clyde, under...
lead_paragraph: The dispostion to be made of JEFF. DAVIS is just now the absorbing popular question. Yesterday we had dispatches stating that himself family and staff officers, had arrived at Fortress Monroe, in the steamer Wm.H. Clyde, under convoy of the gunboat Tus[???]rora. Col. PRITCHARD, with a detachment of his regiment, (the same that captured DAVIS,) acted as guard. Whether DAVIS was landed at the Fortress does not appear from this dispatch. The boat, after some queer movements, an hored in the roads, and it was surmised that DAVIS had been landed somewhere on the beach. But no communication was allowed with the vessel, and everything about the prisoners was left in uncertainty, so far as the public were concerned. A private letter from on heard the Tus[???]rora stated that the party of captives "consists of JEFFERSON DAVIS, his wife, and a small son and two daughters, together with ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS, C.C. CLAY, Col. WM. REAGAN, Gen. WHEELER, the rebel raider, and fifteen or sixteen others, whose names I have not ascertained."

abstract: The Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York held a grand celebration at the Acade  my of Music last night, on the occasion of giving  welcome to R.W. ALBERT G. MACKEY, who had, for the long and weary years of the war, remained in steadfast adherence to the Union while...
lead_paragraph: The Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York held a grand celebration at the Acade my of Music last night, on the occasion of giving welcome to R.W. ALBERT G. MACKEY, who had, for the long and weary years of the war, remained in steadfast adherence to the Union while living in the City of Charleston. The Academy was filled by a great gathering of Masons, their wives and daughters, and a more brilliant audience has seldom been seen within the walls of that edifice. In addition to a splendid concert, speeches were made by R.W. ROBERT D. HOLMES, D.G.M. Dr. MACKEY, and the Grand Master of the State.

abstract: Viguel and Mulligan, of New Bowery Saloon, Attack Officer Horbelt; Soldier in New-Bowery
snippet: Viguel and Mulligan, of New Bowery Saloon, Attack Officer Horbelt; Soldier in New-Bowery
lead_paragraph: On Friday afternoon Mr. JOHN MANGIN, of No. 94 Oak-street, appeared at the Fourth Ward Policestation, and stated that one CATHARINE SHEPPARD, Waiter in the "Old Salamander" concert den, in New Bowery, had robbed him of $47. Thereupon Captain THORNE sent Patrolman HORBELT to apprehend the accused, and the officer, on filtering the concert den, was attacked by JOHN VIGUEL, the keeper, and one ANTONIO MULLIGAN, his bartender, who had armed themselves with a revolver, a hammer and a bowie-knife. They first struck the officer on the back of the head with the hammer, knocking him senseless to the floor, and then rushed upon him with the bowie-knife, ripping open his clothing and narrowly escaping disemboweling him. A party of citizens fortunately entered and disarmed the ruffians in season to save Officer HORBELT's life. Mr. COOPER, of No. 68 Madison-street, and Patrolman MULLEN, of the Fourth Ward, subsequently disabled MULLIGAN and VIGUEL and took them to the Tombs, and they were committed, yesterday, for trial. The female, SHEPPARD, was also arrested and committed.

abstract: In Prison and his Old Boasts
snippet: In Prison and his Old Boasts
lead_paragraph: Many hopes have been disappointed by the arrival of a vessel carrying the Confederate Caesar and his fortunes, in Chesapeake Bay. Among the "unconditional surrender" party here, in all the circles wherein peace at any cost, has been preached during the past four years, the hope of DAVIS' escape has been anxiously cherished and fervently prayed for. This hope has now perished, and those who have prayed have not been answered. DAVIS, and along with him, it is said, C.C. CLAY, A.H. STEPHENS and other notable rebels, are in safe-keeping at Fortress Monroe, and speculation is at an end as to the possibility of their escape by flight, or we presume, by any other means.

abstract: Returning to Loyalty and the Plow; Reviving Loyalty in
snippet: Returning to Loyalty and the Plow; Reviving Loyalty in
lead_paragraph: -- The recent meetings at Raleigh in North Carolina, and Staunton, Virginia, convened with the object of looking the actual situation straight in the face, have an essentially healthy character. We class the two together, because, although the Staunton gathering (on the 8th) was composed of men who barely perceive the radical nature of the revolution which has overtaken the State as a member of the Union, those who participated in the meeting were evidently as desirous as the people of Raleigh to learn what their political status really is, and thereupon to accommodate themselves to the change with loyal submission. The resolutions passed were such as to command attention, if not entire assent, from those who take a thoughtful view of the question of the reestablishment of the civil power of the State. At Raleigh, on the 11th inst., a bolder tone evidently prevailed, and the temper of the resolutions indicate beyond a doubt that in the capital of North Carolina these is no misapprehension of the actual position of State affairs, and no desire to shirk the responsibility of finding some radical remedy, with as little delay as is consistent with a regard to great national interests involved. The meeting, by a perfectly unanimous vote, formally acknowledge "the necessity and good policy of retaining a military force in the State, until a State Government is put in operation." But they further resolve that an early convention of the people is desirable to take some steps for reestablishing the civil authority. And to make clear the loyalty of purpose in which this resolution originates, they declare their approval of "the policy of the President, as indicated in his recent addresses, and will aid him, as far as possible, in carrying it out in North Carolina, that rebellion may be made odious, a just and loyal tone of public sentiment established, and the legitimate authority of the government recognized and respected, as the only means of preserving our liberties, securing the general prosperity of the people, and perpetuating the inestimable rights and privileges so dearly purchased by the blood of our fathers, and handed down as a priceless inheritance to their children."

abstract: The General Term room of the Supreme Court was crowded yesterday morning, by something over one hundred newly-fledged lawyers, and many of their friends. The occasion was the taking of the usual oath prescribed by the constitution and laws of...
lead_paragraph: The General Term room of the Supreme Court was crowded yesterday morning, by something over one hundred newly-fledged lawyers, and many of their friends. The occasion was the taking of the usual oath prescribed by the constitution and laws of this State, and the rules of the Supreme Court, and which must be taken by all attorneys and counselors in this State before they can receive their diplomas admitting them to practice in Courts of Record. The oath was administered, according to the list, to sixty-six graduates of the Columbia College Law School, and to forty-eight others, who are admitted pursuant to the report of three examiners appointed by the Court. The names of the graduates were first called, and afterward the names of those as to whom a favorable report had been made to the Court by the Examiners. Inside the bar stood three or four court officers, each holding an open Bible, and as the candidates were called, they steeped within the railing, placed each his right hand or left (there were eight left-handed candidates) upon the open volume, and there these right and left hands remained while the Clerk, Mr. D.B. Taylor, in clear and sonorous voice, reputed the following oath: "You and each of you do solemnly swear that you will support the constitution of the United States and the constitution of the States of New-York, and that you will, to the best of your ability, discharge the duties of attorney and [???]ns [???] of the Supreme Court, so help you God." It may reasonably be inferred that each and every one of these one hundred and fourteen young men, just [???] the duties and responsibilities of the legal profession, are loyal at heart, after having taken the [???] above recited.

abstract: -- A man named JULIUS THAYER committed suicide in East Penfield, on Tuesday. He was a son of GIDEON THAYER, and resided for some years in Michigan. He had shown symstoms of insanity and was induced to dispose, of his property and return to Ponfield. He came back about a month since and continued to grow worse. On Tuesday he was about to enter a warm bath prepared for him by order of a physician, when he was discovered by his wife with a razor in his hand. His wife, fearing that he intended mischief, sought to obtain the razor. He pushed her violently away, seized his whiskers with his left hand, and, with his right, drew the razor across his throat, inflicting a horrid wound, causing death in a few moments.
lead_paragraph: -- A man named JULIUS THAYER committed suicide in East Penfield, on Tuesday. He was a son of GIDEON THAYER, and resided for some years in Michigan. abstract: Freedmen; The Education of
snippet: Freedmen; The Education of
lead_paragraph: The uproar made by the planters in North Carolina over the refusal of the negroes to work, and their disposition to flock into the towns, will, we predict, not last very long. Negroes have to learn their duties as freedmen just as while men who to learn them The first motive which impels white laborers to submit to daily toil, is the desire to save themselves and their families from starvation; it is only after this has had its due influence that the desire of rising in the world begins to operate. Now, the negroes hitherto have never learnt to connect idleness with bodily suffering or inconvenience. As slaves, they got the same amount of the pleasures of life whether they worked well or ill, and never knew what it was to feel any responsibility whatever about their own maintenance. They will now learn that there is a necessary connection between bread and labor, that the one cannot be had without the other, and it is a lesson which it does not take very long to acquire. We venture to assert that it will find its way through the thickest skull before many weeks. Hunger and nakedness are as disagreeable, and their wives and children as dear to negroes as to other people. There will doubtless be various degrees of industry witnessed amongst them always. Men who have never known what it was to pocket the fruits of their own toil, are not likely to be seized with a sudden passion for labor for its own sake all at once; and we believe that even among while men cases of dislike for steady work are occasionally discovered. So that we have no doubt whatever that before many weeks the negroes all over the South will be found doing the work of cultivation as well as they know how, or as the planters can expect. If they do not do it, we trust there will be men enough from the North to go down and take their places, and make them feel the sharp but invigorating pressure of competition.

abstract: THE DRAFT IN BROOKLYN. -- The returns of the Second Congressional District show that in the three calls for men by the President, there were exempted upon the first call, 2,295, of which 780 failed to report, making a total drawn of 3,075. In the second draft there were drawn 4,704, of which 623 failed to report, and 1,078 were exempted. On the third call 2,666 were exempted, and 1,827 failed to report. In the Third Congressional District, under the three call [???]5,170 men were examined by the Surgeon -- 122 were exempted for unsuitableness of ages 4,147 were exempted for disease, &c., and 2,193 were drafted and held for service, making a total of 11,932 men drawn.

abstract: On Saturday morning Gov. FENTON visited the New-York State Agency for soldiers, corner of Howard and Mercer streets, and the occasion was one of considerable interest to thosee connected with that beneficent institution, the inmates and the visitors.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday morning Gov. FENTON visited the New-York State Agency for soldiers, corner of Howard and Mercer streets, and the occasion was one of considerable interest to thosee connected with that beneficent institution, the inmates and the visitors. Contrary to the usual custom in such cases, very little preparation was made for the tour of inspection and domiciliary visit of the worthy Governor, it being the object of Col. COLYER, the indefatigable Superintendent of the depot, to show the Governor the actual working of the institution and not to exhibit it in more holiday dress.

abstract: By the arrival of the steamer Hansa at this port yesterday, we have three days later news from Europe. The London press comment with satisfaction on the speedy retribution which overtook the assassin of the President. The Empress EUGENIE has sent antograph letter of condolence to Mrs. LINCOLN. Address of sympathy continue to pour in to our ministers abroad from all parts of Europe. The Emperor of France has issued an address to the people of Algeria, and another to the Arabs of that province. He was still making excursions into the environs of the town of Algiers, and his health was excellent. A telegram from Brussels of May 8th says that a considerable improvement had taken place in the king's health.

abstract: It is desirable that as many of the people as possible should see the great military pageant to take place in Washington on Tuesday and Wednesday. It would surely be well, therefore, for the railroad companies of lines between cities within a twelve-hours' ride of Washington to show their patriotism and financial common sense by issuing excursion tickets between those cities, at such moderate price as would enable men of limited means to embrace the occasion for the gratification of a natural and laudable curiosity. This arrangement could be made early on Monday, and by the telegraph the terms could be stated in season for the Monday evening and Tuesday morning papers, thus letting people in towns not more distant than Boston know in season to get to Washington in time for Wednesday's display. Extra night trains, returning at close of the day, would obviate the difficulty of obtaining lodgings at Washington.

abstract: New Cardinal for England
snippet: New Cardinal for England
lead_paragraph: A pervert from the Anglican Church, Dr. MANNING, has been appointed successor to the late Cardinal WISEMAN, in the Sec of Westminister. It is possible that the Pope may have intended the appointment to be a compliment to the English people; but their leading organ fails to see it in that light, and throws all the discredit it can on the new Cardinal.

lead_paragraph: A novel and interesting exhibition of horsemanship took place yesterday afternoon, at 4 o'clock, on the Dubois Association Track, corner of Eigthavenue and One Hundred and Forty-eighth-street. Messrs. ROCKWELL and HURLBURT, the celebrated horse-trainers, exhibited five of the horses which they have trained. They showed fully the great ascendency of the mind over brute force. These horses are us docile and tractable as so many lambs, following after their master as a faithful hound.

abstract: Benjamin's Cypher; Good Effects of Military Investigation
snippet: Benjamin's Cypher; Good Effects of Military Investigation
lead_paragraph: The wisdom of the government in subjecting the parties to the assassination conspiracy to military instead of civil trial, is justified by the completeness of the exposures already obtained and insured. The broad range of evidence, unobstructed by any artificial checks, lets a flood of light across all the details and all the connections of the crime, and will enable the government to get an exact measure of the entire plot. Not only the guilt of the parties immediately arraigned is shown glaringly, so that no rational man can fail to see it, but also the guilt which lay beyond their direct participation, for which others are responsible. Thanks to the thorough work of this military tribunal, this infernal business will go into history in its veritable shape and true relations.
headline: {'main': 'The Fruits of Military Investigation.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Fruits of Military Investigation.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At 10 o'clock last evening a fire was discovered in the carpenter-shop and property-room of Niblo's Theatre. It was quite alarming at first; but the building was so constructed that the flames were confined to the room where the fire originated. The firemen and police were on the spot at once, and were successful in preventing the spread of the flames. The guests of the Metropolitan Hotel were somewhat alarmed, but the house was only slightly damaged by water.

abstract: History of Julius Caesar, vol. 1, 8vo, NewYork, HARPER  BROTHERS, is the simple title-page prefixed to a work that, whether regarded in its subject, or the source from whence it emanates, is bound to make some noise in the world.
lead_paragraph: -- History of Julius Caesar, vol. 1, 8vo, NewYork, HARPER BROTHERS, is the simple title-page prefixed to a work that, whether regarded in its subject, or the source from whence it emanates, is bound to make some noise in the world. Many will, perhaps, be disappointed to find it what it is -- a grave, earnest, scholarly and vigorously written view of the turning-point in the history of the world -- the era when, according to the aspect illustrated in the work, the imperial talents and energies of one man gave shape and color to the whole succeeding destinies of the human race. To prove that such men, when they appear -- whether called Caesar, Charlemagne or Napoleon, are to be accepted as raised up by Providence to point out to lesser minds the way wherein they shall go, to accomplish in a few years the ordinary work of centuries, and to stamp the seal of their individuality on their epoch, is the main object of the book. In it the lessons of history will be applied to the instruction of the present and future times, by deducing from them the immutable laws that they exemplify. The whole work is impressed with a remarkable idiosyncrasy that unmistakably denotes it as the production of a single mind. With every disposition to treat it severely the English critics have discovered few or no drawbacks to its substantial accuracy, and the work will infallibly take lasting rank as one, and not the least, among the remarkable deeds of its author. Much of the present volume is introductory; the active career of CAESAR being hardly yet reached, so that the interest will increase with the progress of the book. The translation has been made, under the Imperial auspices, by Mr. THOMAS WRIGHT, one of the most accomplished scholars of the day, and member of the French "Institut." The volume is a splendid specimen of bookmaking, being got up in a superb style, superior indeed to the English copy, and reflects the greatest credit on Messrs. HARPER's establishment.

lead_paragraph: The Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York held a celebration at the Academy of Music Saturday night, on the occasion of giving welcome to R.W. ALBERT G. MACKEY, who had, for the long and weary years of the war, remained in steadfast adherence to the Union while living in the City of Charleston. The Academy was filled by a great gathering of Masons, their wives and daughters, and a more brilliant audience has seldom been seen within the walls of that edifice. In addition to a splendid concert, speeches were made by R.W. ROBERT D. HOLMES, D.G.M. Dr. MACKEY, and the Grand Master of the State.

abstract: A notable portion of what once formed the contents of the rebel government archives has been found at Charlotte, N.C. The fugitives, before leaving Richmond, burned a considerable part of the records they were unable to carry off. They dropped five tons' weight, subsequently, in their flight. And all of this is now in safe keeping on its way to Washington. There will be fine materials for history found in the pile when it comes to be overhauled, and, doubtless, many interesting developments respecting the home policy and the foreign relations of DAVIS' government. SLIDELL's correspondence, if it should be included among the five tons, will be piquant, and full of instruction -- beyond all question.

abstract: An important link in the chain of evidence laid before the Washington Military Commission is BENJAMIN'S cipher, the identical instrument by means of which he carried on his correspondence with the rebel agents in the neighboring Provinces.
lead_paragraph: An important link in the chain of evidence laid before the Washington Military Commission is BENJAMIN'S cipher, the identical instrument by means of which he carried on his correspondence with the rebel agents in the neighboring Provinces. By the aid of this invention, and making use of such messengers as BOOTH and SURRATT, BENJAMIN, it seems, must have been able to keep up an important correspondence with SANDERS, THOMPSON and others, for many months before the collapse of the Confederacy. It does not exactly appear in the testimony at what date the "cipher" was first put into use in conducting the Canada business; but there is little doubt it was in full operation throughout the Niagara Falls peace negotiations. It will be remembered that the rebel diplomatists pledged themselves to get the necessary power from Richmond to treat with Mr. GREELEY, in the event of their overtures being entertained. This they could only have done by the double agency of BENJAMIN's "cipher," and the underground mail of which the SURRATTS and others seem to have had the running. The negotiations, however, having been prematurely broken off, the "cipher" was immediately put to other uses, as appeals by the deciphered letters laid before the commission on Saturday.

abstract: Del. to President, Object of
snippet: Del. to President, Object of
lead_paragraph: Dr. BLACKBURN, the gentle specimen of Southern chivalry, who is charged with trying to import yellow fever into the infant schools and orphan asylums of New-York, Philadelphia and other cities, in order to destroy as many of the Northern people as possible," has been suddenly transformed into a martyr by some of the Canadian papers. The tender solicitude for his health manifested by the Toronto Leader will be noted, while the denunciations of those who have endeavored to call him to account have satisfactorily settle the status of our particular friend, the editor of that sheet. The Montreal Minerca says; "Dr. BLACKBURN, for more than a year past a guest at the St. Lawrence Hall, and accused of forwarding from Bermuda bales of infected goods to spread the pest in Northern cities, has been arrested through a warrant issued in Toronto. Dr. BLACKBURN has become a Catholic, and received baptism the day before yesterday at St. Lawrence Hall."

abstract: Housekeeping in New-York
snippet: Housekeeping in New-York
lead_paragraph: There are probably dwellings enough in New-York to meet the necessities of a population of eight hundred thousand. The island to-day contains little short of a million inhabitants. There are thus two hundred thousand people crowded out, or what is even more pitiable, crowded in, where disease and pestilence find a ready and certain welcome, and whore the results of moral and physical contamination are daily visible in the mortality bills and criminal records of the city.

abstract: on the Right of Secession; Right of, Question Settled by the War
snippet: on the Right of Secession; Right of, Question Settled by the War
lead_paragraph: One of our Richmond correspondents reports a conversation with Mr. P.H. AYLETT, a distinguished lawyer of Virginia, concerning the causes and results of the war, which merits more than a casual attention. He thinks that in estimating the guilt of those who took part in the rebellion, it should not be forgotten that the right of a State to secede was held by a great portion of the Southern people just as firmly and just as conscientiously as it was denied by the people of the North. It was taught in their schools, in their families, and in every form of social and political teaching. Their schoolmasters were thus far more responsible for the ideas which lay at the bottom of the rebellion, than were the politicians and statesmen who took the lead in it. Mr. AYLETT thinks that this fact should have some weight in determining the degree of criminality which our government should impute to the active rebels of the South.
headline: {'main': 'Things Settled by the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Things Settled by the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The first annual meeting of the Hudson County Agricultural Society commences to-morrow, (Tuesday,) at their race grounds, Secaucus, a pleasant drive, some four or five miles west of Hoboken, readily accessible by any of the North River ferries, and by special trains on the Erie Railroad, for full particulars of which we refer our readers to the society's advertisements. This new and delighfully located race-course was inaugurated last Fall, and the liberality and energy displayed by the members of the association merited and received the unanimous praise of press and public. In the interim many improvements have been made on the track and its surroundings, and it new ranks with the best in the country. The [???]port on each of the three days to which the meeting extends will be of the most affluent description, and the quality of the horses engaged in the various stakes warrants the belief that the contests will be of the [???] description. As the majority of the stakes are play or pay, large fields of horses may be expected whilst, as these races come off rain or shine, there is no possibility of disappointment.
