abstract: Orton, Hon. W. Appointed Chief Revenue Bureau
snippet: Orton, Hon. W. Appointed Chief Revenue Bureau
lead_paragraph: -- That principle so happily illustrated in the elevation of Hon. HUGH McCULLOCH to the Head of the Department, with which he had been identified for so many years as a most efficient and accomplished officer, finds another most commendable application in the promotion of Hon. WILLIAM ORTON, Internal Revenue Collector for the Sixth District in this city, to the Head of the Bureau at Washington, just now made vacant by the resignation of Judge LEWIS. The expediency and wisdom, not less than the justice of promotion in civil as well as military life, for "meritorious-services," significant as it is of greater fitness and higher qualifications for advanced rank, are every day coming to be better understood, and their more general recognition and acknowledgment by the government and the people, cannot fail to result in great public advantage. In deference to this principle, the appointment of Mr. ORTON is everywhere received with special favor. By natural fitness, persevering study and large experience, it is not likely that any man can be found better furnished for the high position which has sought him, and which it is to be hoped he will feel constrained to accept. Collector of our of the most important districts of the whole country, helping to put in operation the original machinery of the internal revenue system, and, for most of the time since, the confidential agent, and in some sense, umpire and counselor of the deportment for the whole city, he has enjoyed remarkable facilities for making himself thoroughly familiar with the details and working of the law, through all its changes; of noting its defects as well as its excellencies; and preparing himself for the suggestion and elaboration of such reforms as could not fail to be felt in the general prosperity.
headline: {'main': 'HON. WILLIAM ORTON.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'HON. WILLIAM ORTON.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Mr. BAINES' Reform Bill, giving the franchise to Â£6 householders in town constituencies, has been defeated in the House of Commons by a vote of 288 to 214, although the government, in view of the general election now close at hand, gave it a certain sort of support. The present House was elected under Lord DERBY's engineering as Premier, and has been, all through its term, essentially Anti-Reform. The progress of events here will doubtless give a stimulus to the Liberal party in England, which it has long needed. The vote now taken, moreover, will bring pointedly before the great body of the people the fact that reform will only be granted when the question has been thoroughly agitated from one end of the kingdom to the other.

abstract: Veto of Underground Railroad
snippet: Veto of Underground Railroad
lead_paragraph: We are sorry that Gov. FENTON has refused his signature to the bill authorizing an underground railroad in this city. We have always regarded such a road as the only measure which would afford substantial relief to our overcrowded streets, and facilitate transit from one part of the city to another. It is perfectly certain that there is not room on the surface of the city to accommodate the traffic which its business requires. Being situated upon a long and narrow island, its surface is restricted and its streets are narrow. A careful calculation shows that, even with its present population, enough railroads cannot be placed in its streets to accommodate all who wish to ride, without absolutely stopping its business traffic. This evil, of necessity, increases from year to year, and will absolutely compel, sooner or later, resort to such a road as that which the Governor has just refused to permit. We think his action will be regretted by all classes of people in the city, except those who are interested in existing and prospective street railroads.

abstract: Order Repudiating Rebel Governors; Governors; Impudence of
snippet: Order Repudiating Rebel Governors; Governors; Impudence of
lead_paragraph: There ought to be some bounds to the impudence of rebel Governors in the late revolted States. But there are none. A full month after the evacuation of Richmond we find a proclamation from MCGRATH, of South Carolina, declaring that all subsistence stores "and the property of the Confederate States" within the limits of the State, shall be turned over to his agents. BROWN, of Georgia, with the same scornful indifference to the progress of events, had issued an order before his capture, for the assembling of the State Legislature on the 22d of May. And one ALLISON, who styles himself "Acting Governor of Florida," has a call out for an election for Governor of the State on the 7th of June.
headline: {'main': 'The Governors of Revolted States.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Governors of Revolted States.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: City Railroads; Superintendent of
snippet: City Railroads; Superintendent of
lead_paragraph: Probably nine-tenths of our people will be surprised to hear that there ever existed such an office as a Superintendent of City Railroads. But such a post was created four or five years ago, and filled successively by M.H. GREEN, Ex-Alderman BRADY, and Senator WOODRUFF. We never heard that either of these incumbents ever discharged a single duty in connection with their office, except to draw its salary of $3,000 a year. No one of them ever arraigned any city railroad for running dirty, ill-ventilated cars, for refusing to run cars enough to accommodate the public, for over-crowding their cars, for refusing to pay their licenses, or for any other broach of the duty they undertook to perform when they received their charters. The office was avowedly a sinecure. For some reason or other it was abolished last year. But an ordinance was introduced into the Common Council yesterday to revive it. Somebody is probably hungry, and wants $3,000 a-year for doing nothing.

abstract: Clemens, Hon. Jeremiah, ex United States Senator from Alabama
snippet: Clemens, Hon. Jeremiah, ex United States Senator from Alabama
lead_paragraph: The telegraph announces the death of Hon. JEREMIAH CLEMENS, of Alabama, formerly a man of political and literary note in the South. He was born at Huntsville, Ala., in 1814, educated at LaGrange College, studied law at Transylvania University, and was admitted to the bar in 1834. Subsequently he filled several important judicial and legislative positions in his State, and in 1842 raised a company of troops to go to Texas, and he subsequently became Lieutenant-Colonel in the volunteer and the regular army. In 1844 he served as Presidential elector on the Polk ticket. Afterward he was a sort of Military Governor over some portion of Mexico held by our army, and so remained until the close of the war. From 1848 to 1853 be was a Senator of the United States from Arkansas, and in 1856 was a Presidential elector, and assisted in casting the vote of Alabama for BUCHANAN. Mr. CLEMENS soon after disappeared from public life, and we have heard little of him in print. It is greatly to his honor, however, to add, that he never was in favor of the Davis rebellion, cut is understood to have steadily opposed the project throughout. Mr. CLEMENS has some reputation as an author, having published several works of fiction which have been favorably received; the first was Bernard Lile, in 1853; another was Mustang Gray, to 1857; and very recently he has sent to press (and we think issued) a novel founded upon scenes in the great rebellion. Mr. CLEMENS died of congestion of the lungs, at his native place, Huntsville, Ala.
headline: {'main': 'Obituary.; JEREMIAH CLEMENS.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Obituary.; JEREMIAH CLEMENS.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Riot at Memphis
snippet: Riot at Memphis
lead_paragraph: A NEGRO RIOT AT MEMPHIS. -- A negro riot is reported from Memphis. It appears to have grown out of the return of certain paroled rebel prisoners to that city. These released rebels were supposed to have been concerned in the Fort Pillow massacre. And the negro troops formed a conspiracy to avenge that bloody affair. The discovery of this conspiracy, and the orders issued to the loyal white troops to break it up, led to the outbreak. A number of negroes are reported killed, and a severe lesson in discipline appears to have been administered to the survivors. The matter is only noticeable as showing that, under passionate excitement, these negro troops conduct themselves no better than if they belonged to a race of another color.

abstract: Resignation for New Repub. Daily in Chicago
snippet: Resignation for New Repub. Daily in Chicago
lead_paragraph: Hon. C.A. DANA resigns the office of Assistant Secretary of War to return to his profession of journalism. He assumes the editorial conduct of a new daily Republican newspaper, to be established in Chicago by a joint-stock company, with $350,000 paid up capital. He has an interest in the concern and a handsome salary for editing the paper. His ability and experience in journalism will insure for the new enterprise a brilliant success.

abstract: TRANS-MISSISSIPPI AFFAIRS. -- If the report of the death of KIRBY SMITH -- said to have been killed by Major MCKEE in consequence of some difference about a cotton speculation -- should prove true, the occurrence will doubtless materially hasten the submission of the rebel forces west of the Mississippi. SMITH commanded the only organized army of the rebellion still in the field, and thus far had manifested little disposition to surrender. His position and force were so strong that the government deemed it judicious to send against him our gallant cavalry hero, Gen. SHERIDAN, who is already on his way to Texas to initiate active measures for finishing up the good work, and to crush the faintly wriggling tail of the serpent whose head he assisted GRANT in bruising in the grand contest with LEE in and out of the walls of Richmond.

abstract: CHARLES EATON, mate of the ship John Bright, lying in the harbor between Governor's and Bedloe's Islands, was brought before Justice DOWLING, at the Tombs Police Court yesterday, on a charge of causing the death of a seaman named MURPHY. It is alleged that about 7:30 o'clock yesterday morning MURPHY either fell or jumped overboard from the John Bright. JOHN QUINN and PETER GALLAGHER, boatmen, who happened to be near the ship in a small boat, rowed toward the man, for the purpose of rescuing him from drowning. As they neared him, EATON, it is alleged, appeared with a drawn revolver, and threatened to shoot them if they attempted to interfere to save the man's life. Deterred by EATON's threats, the men drew off and MURPHY was drowned. The boatmen immediately went ashore and notified Sergt. HOLLAND, of the Harbor Police, who boarded the vessel and arrested EATON. Justice DOWLING committed him to the Tombs for further examination.

abstract: HARNESS FOR PRESIDENT JOHNSON. Quite a crowd assembled on the corner of Broadway and Franklin-street, in front of the harness wareroom of Messrs. HOOVER, CALHOUN  CO., to witness the fitting ...
lead_paragraph: HARNESS FOR PRESIDENT JOHNSON. -- Quite a crowd assembled on the corner of Broadway and Franklin-street, in front of the harness wareroom of Messrs. HOOVER, CALHOUN & CO., to witness the fitting on of the harness manufactured by these gentlemen for the two horses recently presented, in conjunction with carriage, &c., to President JOHNSON. The harness is very heavy and richly ornamented with mountings of new and original designs, with a cipher in old English in the centre of a garter. In addition to the carriage-harness is a complete set of Winter, Summer and stable blankets, halters, whip, and a set of stable tools. The whole work is handsomely gotten up, and reflects much credit upon the skill and taste of the gentlemen who had it in charge.

abstract: THE DEAD-LOCK IN THE JERSEY CITY COMMON COUNCIL. -- An adjourned meeting of the Common Council of Jersey City was hold last evening, for the purpose of endeavoring to effect an organization. Alderman EARLE was elected chairman pro tempore. Eight ballots were had for President, without effecting a choice. Up to the present time the board have balloted about 350 times for President, which, in nearly every instance, has resulted in a tie vote. On Saturday night the board elected JOHN E. SCOTT, City Clerk; NATHANIEL ELLIS, City Marshal; and PETER D. VROOM, City Treasurer; but it is claimed that those elections are null and void on the ground that the board was not properly organized. The board adjourned until this (Tuesday) evening.

abstract: Trial of; Guilt of Leaders of Rebellion
snippet: Trial of; Guilt of Leaders of Rebellion
lead_paragraph: Elaborate arguments have appeared in the Saturday Review, and one or two other English journals, against the arraignment of JEFFERSON DAVIS for treason, on various grounds -- moral, political, historical and legal. It is said, in the first place, that their motives must always be taken into account in deciding upon the expediency of punishing offences committed by large bodies of men; that it is absurd to attempt to weigh the acts of whole communities in the same scale as the acts of individuals, or to suppose that a human tribunal is competent to deal out exact justice with regard to offences of which millions share the guilt, if guilt there be, and of which the conscience of a whole people approve; that many great revolutions, which the world now recognizes as justifiable in their origin and beneficent in their results, were hold in abhorrence by the best portion of the world at the time of their occurrence. This, it is admitted, proves nothing as to their real righteousness or unrighteousness, but it is maintained that it does prove that the opinions of cotemporaries, and especially of those who are themselves parties to the quarrel, can never furnish a standard of right and wrong sufficiently accurate to base a sentence of condemnation on it. An opinion is not necessarily right because large numbers hold and act on it; but the fact that large numbers do hold it does at least raise a doubt whether those who hold the opposite one have got the whole truth on their side.

abstract: Report on Southern Refugees; American Union Com. Report on; American Union Commission Report
snippet: Report on Southern Refugees; American Union Com. Report on; American Union Commission Report
lead_paragraph: Many people are apt to forget the constant and numerous demands made upon the government by the exigencies of the war, looking only at the great armies, the movements upon the field or wave, and the loud-sounding demonstrations, and failing to appreciate the ten thousand minor cares, just as necessary and often quite as perplexing, which occupy the time and weary the brain of the responsible authorities. The care of the freedmen has passed within the week into the hands of the Freedmens' Bureau, at whose head has been placed the gallant HOWARD, whose name is at once the exponent of a Christian and a soldier. Side by side with this great work stands the case of the poor whites -- the refugees, Union and rebel -- thousands of whom are here among us, while other thousands are at home, destitute of brains, money, or means of livelihood.

abstract: President Lincoln's Letter on Reorganization of; Banks, Gen., Letter to on Reorganizing Louisiana
snippet: President Lincoln's Letter on Reorganization of; Banks, Gen., Letter to on Reorganizing Louisiana
lead_paragraph: A great deal has been said, first and last, here and elsewhere, of an attempted forcible interference, on the part of the late President of the United States, In the reorganizing movement in Louisiana. In this State and the North, an impression has somehow been created that Mr. LINCOLN, from the start, adopted a dictatorial tone on this matter. We have been favored with an opportunity to copy from a letter written by Mr. LINCOLN in August, 1863, that, as well as anything from his pen or speeches, indicates what was his real feeling on the subject, and effectually answers the charge of unwarrantable and officious intermeddling concerning this portion of our State history.

abstract: CAPTURE OF EX-GOV. HARRIS. -- It is reported that ISHAM G. HARRIS, the late rebel Governor of Tennessee, has been captured. If so, the government have secured a scoundrel of some importance, not by reason of his mental strength, which is indifferent, but because he is the man who, more than all others, took Tennessee out of the Union when four-fifths of her white people, and all her blacks, deprecated, and many of them stoutly resisted, the wicked suicide. HARRIS is about as bad a specimen as treason can punish; he is as great a braggart as BEAUREGARD, and a coward in successful rivalry with JEFF. DAVIS of the petticoats. HARRIS is the individual for whom Parson-Governor BROWNLOW has been looking for some months, and whose personal history he sketched but a few days ago in his sledgehammer English. If ISHAM falls into the hands of the Parson, he will have urgent need of prayer, and that at very short notice. It is not unduly dignifying this malignant traitor to say that his violent efforts for the rebellion, in 1861, added, for a time, the States of Tennessee, Kentucky, Missouri, and probably Arkansas, to the Davis conspiracy.

abstract: Broadway Concert Saloons
snippet: Broadway Concert Saloons
lead_paragraph: THE BRODAWAY CONCERT SALOONS. -- We do not know that the City Government have ever been complained of for showing over-fastidiousness respecting the morals of their constituency and the fair fame of the municipality. The opinion, indeed, is very general that as a class, the members generally are somewhat careless in living up to the spirit, or even the letter of the decalogue. This being true, certainly more weight should attach to the proceedings of the Aldermen yesterday, referring to those numerous haunts of depravity and schools of vice known as "concert saloons," which blight Broadway with a moral leprosy from Canal to Fourteenth streets. Aldorman O'BRIEN, in a series of resolutions characterizing these places as public nuisances, offensive in the last degree to public decency, invokes the law for their suppression, and asks that at any rate the Police Department shall keep them under such strict surveillance, that the orgies therein held shall not be conducted in the open and shameless manner which immunity from official interference has given their proprietors and frequenters. Those resolutions were adopted by the board, and if the police choose to act in the premises, they will be sustained by the press and the public, to whom the evil has long been patent, and who are none the less grateful for official action, though it oftentimes is tardy in coming.

abstract: THE FRENCH ORGAN ON MILITARY USURPATION. -- It is instructive, as well as amusing, to note the perfect accord which exists between the Opposition press and the pro-rebel foreign journals published in New-York, touching what they call military usurpations. The French organ here has undertaken of late a defence of the United States Constitution against these usurpations. Or rather, having found out that the civil power of the States from New-York to California is overthrown, it sounds the alarm in the name, and for the interests of Liberty. Gen. DIX, it seems, is to all intents the governing power for this State. Gen. MCDOWELL stands in the same relation to the Pacific States. And all over the country civil authority has been overthrown, and a military despotism instated. Of course, there is no liberty of the press such as is established in France. And nothing like that perfect freedom of public opinion of which an exposition may be found any day in the Latin Quarter of Paris.

abstract: SEIZURE OF COUNTERFEIT UNITED STATES CURRENCY. -- For some time past the attention of the United States authorities has been directed to the large amount of counterfeit United States currency which has recently been put into circulation, and the utmost efforts were made to discover the parties who were manufacturing the stuff. Sunday, Marshal MURRAY, of New-York, succeeded in finding a carman who had carted a number of dies, &c., to a house on the corner of Sixteenth-street and Sixth-avenue, Brooklyn, and about 12 o'clock on Sunday night, United States Marshal CAMPBELL, with Capt. BROWN, and a number of officers of the Forty-eighth Precinct, made a descent on the house indicated, where they found about eighteen thousand dollars' worth of counterfeit United States currency, consisting of ten, twenty-five, and fifty cent stamps, all ready for circulation, together with a large quantity of dies, plates, presses, &c. Two men, named ANTONIO ROSA, and FRANCIS WHITE, were found on the premises, and taken into custody.

abstract: Harris, Ex-Gov., Capture of
snippet: Harris, Ex-Gov., Capture of
lead_paragraph: President JOHNSON has issued an important proclamation regulating trade to certain ports, and in the interior Southern States. He opens the ports closed some time since by President LINCOLN, except those of Texas; and he withdraws from this date, (May 22,) all pretence of belligerent rights, thus putting blockade-runners and contraband traders out of legal protection of any sort. He also removes pretty nearly all restrictions upon trade inland east of the Mississippi.

abstract: Insolence; Jacob Thompson's Letter and the Tribune; Thinks Jacob Thompson Letter in Very Bad Taste
snippet: Insolence; Jacob Thompson's Letter and the Tribune; Thinks Jacob Thompson Letter in Very Bad Taste
lead_paragraph: The Tribune publishes a long letter from JACOB THOMPSON, one of the rebel agents in Canada, devoted mainly to the proclamation of his own injured innocence, and largely to an argument intended to prove that ANDREW JOHNSON was an accomplice of BOOTH in the murder of Mr. LINCOLN. The Editor of the Tribune says he was authorized by Mr. THOMPSON to "suppress" this portion of his letter; but he "did not choose to do so." He did, however, venture to say that he thought "the remarks affecting President JOHNSON in very bad taste." We hope he did not think it necessary to apologize privately to THOMPSON for thus characterizing his effusion. But it would not be amiss, in our judgment, for him to give to the public some respectable reason, if he has any, for giving currency to so infamous a charge made upon such infamous authority.

abstract: MURDEROUS ASSAULT ON A SOLDIER. -- A man named FELIX DOYLE, arrested by Sergt. SPENCE, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, was taken before Justice DAILEY, of the Eastern District, yesterday, charged with having committed a murderous assault on a soldier named WHITLOCK, who resides at No. 177 North Eighth-street. The wife of the injured man states that on Sunday evening her husband got into an altercation with DOYLE, at the corner of North Eighth and Fifth streets, in consequence, as is alleged, DOYLE having spoken in a disrespectful manner of President LINCOLN. WHITLOCK, who is at home on sick leave, rebuked the accused, when, it is alleged, he turned on the soldier and beat him in a most cruel manner, and, it is thought, fractured his skull. DOYLE was committed to jail to await the result of the injuries. The accused is a member of Hose Co. No. 10, and is said to be one of the prominent parties in the attack on the police a week ago last Sunday.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday. A resolution was adopted tendering the hospitalities of the city to Gen. SHERIDAN. The Police Commissioners were requested to abate the concert-saloon nuisance, if possible. A rosolution was presented requesting the Mayor Council to convene the board if the Mayor declines to do so. The resolution was laid over.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen met yesterday. A resolution was adopted tendering the hospitalities of the city to Gen. SHERIDAN. The Police Commissioners were requested to abate the concert-saloon nuisance, if possible. A rosolution was presented requesting the Mayor Council to convene the board if the Mayor declines to do so. The resolution was laid over. A resolution was adopted instructing the City Inspector to have all paved streets south of Fifty-ninth-street swept twice a week from the 1st of June to the 1st of October. The Comptroller was authorized to issue $300,000 Central Park Improvement Fund Stock. A preamble and resolutions were adopted repudiating all connection with the action of the Street Cleaning Commission, and protesting against the making of any contract for cleaning the streets. The Board adjourned to Wednesday next.

abstract: Annexation Feeling Revived
snippet: Annexation Feeling Revived
lead_paragraph: There are unmistakable signs in the neighboring Provinces of a revival of the annexation feeling of 1849. The reaction caused by the failure of the scheme for uniting all the Provinces, has had its influence in this direction. The proposal to spend the trifle (50,000 sterling a year for four years) voted by the British Parliament, in forts at and around Quebec, while nothing has been voted for the West, has naturally provoked unaimable feelings in the peninsular districts of Upper Canada. The fear that no commensurate gain would accrue to the Western tax-payer -- who contributes three-fourths of the customs' dues -- for building a military railroad from Quebec to Halifax, has grown stronger every day as the prospect of a political union with the maritime Provinces has declined. And some of the local journals of the Upper Province are not backward in giving emphatic expression to sentiments strongly derogatory to the importance and value of continued British connexion. The industrial interests of the country, east and west, are in a more backward condition than they have been for many years. And there is a large and steady emigration both from Lower and Upper Canada to the United States. These are facts which we record with anything but pleasure. The people of this country were satisfied to see the colonists make an experiment in federation, either as a dependency of the mother country, or otherwise, as they might deem most profitable.

Since then the system of Sunday-School teaching has become universal throughout Christendom, and nowhere in the world is it more interwoven with social life than in this country. abstract: FOUND DROWNED. -- The body of a woman, apparently about 20 years of age, four feet ten inches in height, was found yesterday morning in the river near Atlantic dock. Deceased had on a calico skirt, dark delaine sack, no stockings and now shoes. There was very little hair left, but what remained was doubtless black some time. The features were so much decayed that it would be scarcely possible to identify the body. Coroner LYNCH took charge of it.

abstract: Whisky Tax--Ingenious Frauds to Evade; Whisky Tax Frauds on Government
snippet: Whisky Tax--Ingenious Frauds to Evade; Whisky Tax Frauds on Government
lead_paragraph: Very few of our citizens, outside of the government officers, have any conception of the means and devices resorted to, to evade the payment of duties under the Internal Revenue Act. In the manufacturing, income tax, stamps and licenses; in fact in every branch of business, frauds are perpetrated, but the grand eldorado is found in distillation. The recent seizures of whisky in this city, Chicago, Cincinnati and Boston, have fully proved that the saving of the heavy tax of two dollars per gallon is too great an inducement to resist, even for those who have heretofore occupied positions in the community as high minded and honorable merchants. Thousands of dollars have been saved to the government through the vigilance of its officers, but with all their vigilance, it is estimated by the Commissioner of Internal Revenue, that out of the one hundred millions of gallons annually manufactured, not more than twenty millions will pay the duty.

abstract: We have only time to say of the grand review yesterday at Washington that it was fully equal to public expectation.
lead_paragraph: We have only time to say of the grand review yesterday at Washington that it was fully equal to public expectation. The day was fair, the crowd more than immense, and as the various divisions and brigades marched through the grand street of the capitol, the memory was busy with their glorious history, and the heart was eloquent beyond the capacity of the tongue with their heroic deeds. Every "battle-field, from the first Bull Run to the surrender of LEE, was gloriously represented; the banners that went through fire to victory were there, and the noble men who survived the leaden storm were proudly marched under them. Now and then, as some gallant officer made a conspicuous part in the procession, the applause became vociferous, and wreaths of laurel and showers of flowers were lavished upon him. So far as our special and general accounts inform us, the first day of the grand review was all that could be expected of national glorification. Nearly 100,000 men honored the country by participating in the grand pageant, and received a mere shadowing of the grateful welcomes that await them at the homes for which they have so bravely and successfully fought.

abstract: Mrs. Lincoln, Presentation to by Treasury and Quartermaster' Clerks
snippet: Mrs. Lincoln, Presentation to by Treasury and Quartermaster' Clerks
lead_paragraph: Last week a portion of the clerks in the Treasury Department, uniting with the clerks in the Quartermaster-General's Bureau, presented Mrs. LINCOLN with a beautiful cross of wax japonicas, neatly encased in black walnut, as a tribute of their love and esteem for the late President LINCOLN, and as a parting gift to the bereaved widow of him who is so dear to the heart of every true patriot, with an intimation that its acceptance would confer all the honor its contributors desired, and that its preservation as a memento of the givers, whose sympathy will go with her into her retirement, or its deposit on the final resting-place of the immortal martyr, would give lasting gratification. abstract: The trial of Mr. ISAAC HENDERSON, late Navy Agent at this port, began yesterday, in the United States Circuit Court, Judges NELSON and BENEDICT on the bench.
lead_paragraph: The trial of Mr. ISAAC HENDERSON, late Navy Agent at this port, began yesterday, in the United States Circuit Court, Judges NELSON and BENEDICT on the bench. The government was represented by District-Attorney DICKINSON, Judge BOSWORTH and CALEB CUSHING. Mr. HENDERSON was defended by WILLIAM M. EVARTS, Judge PIERREPONT and Mr. BRADY. A jury was impanneled, when Mr. EVARTS moved to quash the indictment, and made an able speech in support of the motion. At the conclusion of his argument, a short rocess was had. On reassembling, Judge NELSON said the Judges had decided to order the trial to go on, and District-Attorney DICKINSON proceeded to open the case. The trial will be continued this morning.

abstract: SERIOUS ACCIDENT. -- A serious accident occurred this morning, as one of the Hoboken Ferry Boats was entering the Barclay-street slip at Hoboken. The tide was unusually high, and a portion of the woodwork of the pier projected over the bridge much lower than is generally the case. The deck hand, JOHN MULCAHEY, on jumping from the boat to the bridge, was struck by the timber and thrown back, and, falling upon the deck, with his leg over the edge of the boat, was fearfully crushed. The leg, below the knee, hung by the tendons only, and nearly the whole of the thigh completely mashed. The unfortunate man, who has been many years in the service of the company, and esteemed careful in the discharge of his duties, was conveyed to the New-York Hospital, by the advice of Dr. ELDER, of Hoboken, where he lies in a dangerous condition.

abstract: Trust vs. Trust; Remarkable Divorce Case
snippet: Trust vs. Trust; Remarkable Divorce Case
lead_paragraph: Mary F. Trust vs. Joseph W. Trust. -- This action is brought to obtain a decree of divorce on the ground of adultery. The plaintiff, Mrs. MARY F. TRUST, in her sworn complaint, alleges that on or about the 9th day of October, 1839, she was married to the defendant, JOSEPH W. TRUST, in the City of New-York; that six children were the result of the marriage -- two of whom are deceased, and four are still living. That from the time of their marriage up to the year 1856, the plaintiff and defendant lived together; that in the year last-named, the plaintiff was compelled to separate herself from her husband on account of his brutal and inhuman treatment toward her. Since that time she alleges that she has supported, not only herself, but her four children. It is alleged in the complaint, and to some extent it was proved by the witnesses of the plaintiff, that the adultery of the defendant was committed, in part, on the premises where he carried on business, and at the corner of Twenty-ninth-street and Ninth-avenue; also at No. 453 Broadway.

abstract: Decline in Price of
snippet: Decline in Price of
lead_paragraph: The great falling off in the consumption of coal by the government has already sensibly influenced the market. Consumers will learn, from a report of the sale yesterday of twenty thousand tons of Pittston at auction by the Pennsylvania Coal Company, that prices are fast coming down to a reasonable standard. There will be another heavy auction sale to-day, and from present indications we hazard the opinion that before the Summer is a few weeks old, the price of coal per ton at retail will not be higher than $6 or $7. Some of the small dealers are already advertising stove coal at $8 for family use.

abstract: Auction Sale of; Prices Falling
snippet: Auction Sale of; Prices Falling
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, by order of the Pennsylvania Coal Company, 20,000 tons of fresh-mined Pittston coal were sold at public auction, at the Exchange Salesroom, No. 111 Broadway. The coal is deliverable at Newburgh, pro rata, during the month of June. Mr. GEORGE A. HOYT, Treasurer of the company, stated that the company would, if desired, deliver the coal in New-York at a charge of seventy cents per ton; in Albany at fifty cents, and in Troy or West Troy at fifty-five cents.

abstract: Alabama, S. S., officers of; Tahoma, S. S., Officers of; Mohongo, S. S., Officers of
snippet: Alabama, S. S., officers of; Tahoma, S. S., Officers of; Mohongo, S. S., Officers of
lead_paragraph: The United States side-wheel steamer Mohongo, 10 guns, double-ender, was put in commission yesterday at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. About one year since this vessel burst her boiler off Castle Williams, since which time she has been receiving new machinery at the Morgan Iron-works. She was built by Messrs. SECOR, Jersey City, in 1863-4, and is 1,030 tons burden. The following is a list of her officers: Commander, J.W.A. NICHOLSON; Lieut.-Commander, Geo. C. Remy, Lieutenant, Sylvanus Backus; Ensign, Yates Sterling; Acting Ensigns, W.A. Daver, D.W. Mullan; Mates, F.H. Poole, A. Davis; Past Assistant-Surgeon, J.H. Clarke; A.A. Paymaster, T.S. Labney; First Assistant Engineer, E.M. Olsen; Second Assistants, B.F. Wood, J.A.B. Smith, E.D. Weems, Jas. Entwistle.

abstract: Castle Thunder, Russian Bloodhound guard of
snippet: Castle Thunder, Russian Bloodhound guard of
lead_paragraph: A huge Russian blood-hound, which for four years acted as the guard of Castle Thunder, has just been brought to this city by Mr. SIDNEY MUNN, who is now stopping at the Astor House. This hound is probably one of the finest specimens of the canine tribe that has ever been seen in this city. Jet black, standing over three feet in height, with a huge but well-proportioned head and body, and thews and sinews that might belong to a small bullock, he presents a very formidable appearance, and was doubtless an efficient guard to the rebel prison. His weight is said to be about 180 pounds. He was imported when quite young for the purpose of being trained to fight bears, in which amusement he soon became quite proficient. His owner states that within a year or two he has fought three pitched battles with full grown bears and came off victorious in each. He fomerly belonged to a Capt. ALEXANDER, who repeatedly refused $700 in gold for him, and matched him on one occasion in a bear-fight for $12,000. The animal is said to possess an amiable temper when not provoked. His appetite is good, six or seven pounds of meat forming an ordinary meal. He is certainly one of the greatest curiosities that has yet been imported from Richmond.

abstract: The Assembly met yesterday at the usual hour, 9 A.M. After the reading of the minutes, which were approved, the Secretary of the Ministerial Relief Fund Committee, Rev. CHARLES BROWN, read the report of the committee. The report was interesting.
lead_paragraph: The Assembly met yesterday at the usual hour, 9 A.M. After the reading of the minutes, which were approved, the Secretary of the Ministerial Relief Fund Committee, Rev. CHARLES BROWN, read the report of the committee. The report was interesting. The fund was organized for the purpose of giving relief to disabled ministers. The receipts had amounted to $3,638, and a portion given to applicants; assistance for over forty persons had been asked. The report closed with the hope that during the coming year the receipts would so far be increased as to allow the committee to carry out more fully the designs of the Assembly.

abstract: Ports, the Opening of
snippet: Ports, the Opening of
lead_paragraph: The proclamation of President LINCOLN, which immediately followed the surrender of LEE'S army, declaring the Southern ports temporarily closed to foreign trade, was an act dictated in the interests of international peace. It offered the readiest and most effective way of avoiding any possible complications, pending the adjustment of a local administration in the newly recovered districts. It gave our government time to establish a uniform system of regulations applicable to all the blockaded ports. It gave opportunity for the removal of the greater disabilities necessarily imposed upon the internal trade of insurgent districts. And, beyond all, it presented to the governments that had recognize the rebels as belligerents, the occasion for revising their policy in that regard, on the potential ground of self-interest.

abstract: Street-Cleaning; Commission
snippet: Street-Cleaning; Commission
lead_paragraph: We are glad to see that the commissioners appointed by the Legislature to make a contract for the cleaning of the streets, are evincing a determination to fulfill the purpose of the law and to secure for us the inestimable blessing of clean streets. At the meeting of the commission on Monday, in reference to this matter, it was stated by gentlemen of the commission that the specifications drawn up previously were defective. Very properly, therefore, the commission resolved to invite suggestions looking to a contract of unexceptionable merit, before awarding any contracts whatever.

abstract: Archives; The Capture of
snippet: Archives; The Capture of
lead_paragraph: Next in consequence to the surrender of the great rebel armies, is the surrender of the vast mass of the records of the rebel Government. We are not sure that the last event is not in fact of the greater importance. If LEE and JOHNSTON had not surrendered, their forces would soon have been overwhelmed and annihilated, and the same practical result would thus, at no distant time, have been realized But if these records of the rebellion had been destroyed, it would have been a loss for all time. There could have been no earthly possibility of supplying their places. The inner history of the rebellion would never have come to the clear knowledge of the world. It must have been the subject of endless speculation and controversy; and the judgment of future generations concerning the real character and motives of the founders and managers of the "Confederacy," would have been divided and equivocal.

abstract: First Anniversary Meeting New-York Association
snippet: First Anniversary Meeting New-York Association
lead_paragraph: The first annual meeting of the New-York Association of the New Church, took place at the New Jerusalem Church, in Thirty-fifth-street, on Thursday. This association comprises societies, ministers, and isolated members of the Church in New-York, New-Jersey and Connecticut, uniting for the purpose of promoting the spiritual and social unity of the Church; providing for the education of suitable persons for the ministry, and their authentication; for disseminating the doctrines by means of missionaries, and the publication and distribution of books and tracts; providing for the religious education of children; and performing such other services as may be desirable.

abstract: The General Assembly (New School) Presbyterian Church, held their usual daily sessions, yesterday, at Dr. CUYLER's Church, in Brooklyn. In the morning, the report of the Standing Committee on Home Missions was presented. The Treasurer's report exhibited a goodly balance on hand. The question of providing pastors for the freedmen was also discussed. Several speeches were made by the colored delegates on the subject. In the afternoon, the committee's proposition to provide lay helpers for the spreading of the Gospel was debated at length and adopted. The Assembly to-day lighten the severity of their labors by an excursion down the Bay.

abstract: a National Invalides Suggested; Grand Review, the; National Invalides an Appropriate Close
snippet: a National Invalides Suggested; Grand Review, the; National Invalides an Appropriate Close
lead_paragraph: The last great scene of the war has closed. It has been everything that could impress the senses and stir the imagination. Every American who has seen it, or even read of it, has rejoiced in its "pride, and pomp, and circumstance." His pulse has been quickened by all its heroic associations, and by all its suggestions of the might and majesty of the republic. As a mere military spectacle, its like, in all probability, will never hereafter be seen on this continent. It is not easy to conceive any occasion that will ever again bring together two hundred thousand American soldiers. So soon as order and security are fully reestablished, our armies will again be reduced to a handfull. This rebellion has had such a terrible overthrow, that it seems certain that no other will ever be attempted. It is likely enough that, at some future time, we shall become engaged in war with some Power across the ocean; but such a war would be almost exclusively maritime, and no extensive enlistments of soldiers would be required. We may declare almost positively that this American Republic will never again see such another array of armed men. That in itself would make this parade an occasion of transcendent mark. And yet how tame is the mere circumstance of numbers in this case. Who gives a thought to the bare fact that two hundred thousand soldiers have been reviewed in the National Capital? The thought that fills the mind is not how many soldiers; but what soldiers. Who would not rather see the three hundred of Thermopylae than all the millions of Xerxes? It is not because these two hundred thousand are men in uniform, but because they are heroes, and the savers of the republic, that this gathering of them so thrills! It is the matchless glory and worth of their deeds that makes this spectacle forever memorable.

abstract: Mlle. STELLA BONHEUR's concert, on Monday evening, was in every respect an agreeable entertainment. The programme was of judicious length; the artists were all present, (alas, that we should be compelled to refer to this as a creditable circumstance,) and their morceaux were rendered with taste and efficiency. Mr. EBEN, the flutist, who headed the programme, but did not commence it, played a couple of fantasias excellently; Mr. MILL, (piano,) and Mr. THOMAS, (violin,) gave us a duo concertante on themes from "Oberon" with great effect -- how, indeed, could they do otherwise? Mr. MILLS, in addition, played his admirable "Faust" arrangement -- playing it as he alone can play it. Signor MONGIARDINI, a pleasant concert singer, sang a couple of Verdian ditties with complete acceptance. Signor IPPOLITO also indulged in strains from the same maestro. We reserve for our last the pleasant duly of speaking of the lady. Mlle. BONHEUR has a charming voice, which a few years since would have been called a contrallo, but which at present it is the fashion to style a mezzo-soprano. In coloring it is still the former. Few singers possess a purer organ. It is large, flexible and sympathetic. The lady has vastly added to her control of it, and is, therefore, able to do some justice to her own conception of the music. We were both astonished and pleased at the notable progress in Mlle. BONHEUR's method. It is, we are informed, due to the skill of Signor ERRANI, a tenor of repute himself, and a teacher who knows the value of largeness and freedom of style. These he has imparted to his pupil. We shall be greatly mistaken if, under the gentleman's advice, Mlle. BONHEUR does not quickly attain a prominent position on the lyric stage. The indications are decidedly in that direction.

abstract: The news from Europe and Havana points with some distinctness to an early and final disposition of the "Confederate" pirates. At Havana, PAIGE, commanding the Stonewall, has shrewdly anticipated the action which would have been made incumbent on the Spanish Government, by making over his vessel to the local authorities.
lead_paragraph: The news from Europe and Havana points with some distinctness to an early and final disposition of the "Confederate" pirates. At Havana, PAIGE, commanding the Stonewall, has shrewdly anticipated the action which would have been made incumbent on the Spanish Government, by making over his vessel to the local authorities. What the precise form of the transaction has been, we do not precisely gather from the report. The "ram" in the first instance was put into the keeping of the Cuban officials unconditionally. On maturer thought, PAIGE seems to have sought to modify the assignment by stipulating that the craft should not be disposed of to the United States Government. These stipulations, it is said, were not agreed to by the Captain-General. But PAIGE, nevertheless, succeeded in making something out of that official in another way. The considerable sum of $25,000 was raised for the rebel Captain, to enable him to pay off his crew.

abstract: Letter to People of United States; Fate to be Determined by Policy
snippet: Letter to People of United States; Fate to be Determined by Policy
lead_paragraph: We regard the execution of DAVIS, in case of his conviction, as purely a matter of expediency. That he is actually guilty of treason no one doubts. The Constitution of the United States defines that crime, and the laws of the land prescribe death as its penalty. DAVIS has incurred that penalty beyond all doubt and in the ordinary course of justice the government must inflict it. If tried and convicted there is but one thing that can save him, and that is a pardon, conditional or otherwise, at the hands of the President. Whether the President shall grant that pardon or not is solely a matter of policy. He ought to decide it, after careful consideration of all the interests involved, upon his own candid and deliberate judgment as to the effect of his decision upon the peace, harmony and prosperity of the whole country.

abstract: Anson Livingston vs. The Eagle Fire Insurance Company. -- The plaintiff was insured in the sum of $8,000, by the defendants, upon his front and rear buildings, No. 75 Beekman-street. In his sworn preliminary proofs of loss he stated that the buildings were worth $13,000; that one was burnt down, and the other so injured by the fire (on the 1st of January, 1863,) that it had to be pulled down, and was ordered by the authorities to be pulled down as a dangerous building; and that it would cost $12,000 to rebuild the two structures. He therefore claimed that his loss exceeded his insurance by at least $4,000, and that he ought to be paid the whole sum insured as for a total loss. But the Insurance Company claimed that the front building was not so injured as to require it to be taken down; that in pulling it down the plaintiff had voluntarily increased his loss; and that they were liable to the plaintiff only for the value of the rear building, and the cost of repairing the front building, which they offered to pay. The jury found that there was no necessity for taking down the front building, and that the defendants were liable for only what it would cost to repair it and rebuild the rear building, viz.: $6,000; for which, with interest from the time the loss was payable, they rendered their verdict -- thus sustaining the single ground of the defence.

abstract: Letter to "Titus Oates Holt"
snippet: Letter to "Titus Oates Holt"
lead_paragraph: These two men again send to us, in print, in Montreal papers, certain statements which we presume they mean to have construed as exculpating the writers from all complicity with the assassination of President LINCOLN. Mr. TUCKER's letter "To the People of the United States," is a rare specimen of bedlamite raving, HO violent in tone and so foul in expression, that the Montreal Gazette, which gives it publicity, is moved from very shame to accompany it with an editorial lecture to the writer, telling him, in very plain English, that he has damaged himself and Lis cause irretrievably by his absurd violence. As a specimen of the two columns over TUCKER's signature, take this picture of Gen. HUNTER and Judge HOLT, the President and Judge-Advocate of the court for the trial of the alleged conspirators:

abstract: HIGHWAY ROBBERY. -- JAMES BURK and JOHN FAY were arrested yesterday morning about 2 o'clock, by Officer KING, of the Tenth Precinct, in Division, near Chatham-street, while in the act of perpetrating a robbery from the person of JEREMIAH FALVY. Mr. FALVY was sitting on a stoop at the time, and the above-named fellows were in the act of robbing him when Officer KING came up. They endeavored to escape, but were pursued and arrested. One of them dropped a pocket-book belonging to Mr. FALVY, containing $2,000, but with the assistance of Officer MEAD both the men and the money were secured. BURK and FAY have been committed without bail.

abstract: Belligerent Rights in British Parliament
snippet: Belligerent Rights in British Parliament
lead_paragraph: When Mr. WHITE gave notice of a question in Parliament as to the withdrawal of belligerent rights from the rebels, it is hardly probable that he expected an answer. He doubtless knew, unofficially, that the question was under discussion in the cabinet, pending which no positive information could be given. He must have known, too, that in the absence of Lord PALMERSTON, a formal statement of the case would hardly be made to the House of Commons. No one, therefore, was surprised that Mr. WHITE -- probably having been requested by the government to do so -- postponed his inquiry. This postponement, however, will not relieve the British Ministry from a strong pressure on their own side of the House, to hasten their decision, and prepare the way for an arbitration of the questions at issue between the two governments on various points of neutrality, the settlement of which are essential to a mutual good understanding.

snippet: Hoboken and Spring-street; Pac. M. S. S. Co. Endeavor to Prevent Reopening Fails; Pequot, S. S., History and officers of; Arbitration Committee Appointed; Hoboken Races, Second Day; Declines Present of Carriage and Horses from New-York Merchants
lead_paragraph: From the appearance of the racing grounds of the Hudson County Agricultural Association yesterday, there is evidently a disposition and a strong desire by the elite of the general public to support good and legitimate sport when an opportunity is afforded them. The executive of this association have provided good sport, and are deserving to reap their reward. The best racing horses in the country have been produced, excellent contests shown, and liberal premiums awarded. Doubtless the annual meetings at Secaucus will become, ere long, as popular as those of Saratoga and Paterson. This close proximity of the track to a city as large as New-York, the splendid scenery of the approaches thereto, the elegance of the whole, surrounding country at this season of the year, invites the earnest patronage of all the lovers of the true and beautiful. A large attendance of elegantly-appointed equipages were dotted within the inclosure, and the grand stand, dressed in Spring loveliness, by the youth and beauty of New-York, gave additional splendor to the scene. Several tandem turnouts were there, rivaling "the English Epsom Down on a Derby day." To-day is the last of the Spring meeting, when the most affluent sport is provided, as will be seen by reference to advertisement in another column. We append a return of yesterday's races:

KASA was committed without bail.

abstract: By the arrival of the Edinburgh and the Louisiana at this port, and of the China at Halifax, we are in receipt of four days' later news from Europe. A Melbourne dispatch of March 28 says that the pirate Shenandoah was cruising off that coast, but no captures were announced. FRANKLIN WEBSTER, American Consul at Munich, is dead. In the House of Commons, on the 11th inst., the question as to whether the government had resolved to withdraw belligerents rights from the South, of which notice had been given by Mr. WHITE, was not put. The relations between Great Britain and the United States were discussed by the London press, generally in a friendly spirit. Lord PALMERSTON's health is improving, but he continues weak, and abstains from parliamentary duties. It was expected that the Atlantic cable would be completed in a fortnight, and all alongside the Great Eastern by the 1st of May. The continental news is not important. It is stated that Austria has declined the propositions of Prussia, that both Powers should enter into separate negotiations with the Federal Diet on the Schleswig-Holstein question, and that the Duke of AGUSTENBURG should be removed from Kiel. Austria considered neither proposition admissible.

abstract: Hosmer, Miss, Debut of
snippet: Hosmer, Miss, Debut of
lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- A young artist of whom report speaks favorably, Miss. HOSMER, will make her first appearance here on Monday next. The present week will, therefore, be the last of the "Gray Lady of Penarvon." This drama has been somewhat abused by the press, even by that member of it, who, knowing what mental feebleness is himself, ought to have spared all comment on it in another -- we mean the "celebrated dramatist" of "Cartouche" -- but the fact remains that as an exceptional mystery, the "Gray Lady," in spite of these heavy circumstances, is excellent. No one can tell until the last act which is the poisoner, and in consequence the interest is maintained, and increases ad infinitum. We are willing to confess that the sombre hues of the story are rather overwhelming. They are not to our taste, but this is no argument against their judicious use. Some of GUSTAVE DORE's best productions are in black and white -- with very little white. So also are the works of the distinguished dramatist already referred to, with no white at all. It is nonsense to introduce a Maypole in a graveyard, and Mr. TAYLOR has felt, without doubt, the impossibility of relieving the intensity of the "Gray Lady" without disturbing the piquant apprehension of the audience, and so destroying a denouement which all must confess is impressive. However, the play, such as it in, will he given until Saturday, and on Monday, as we have before indicated, Miss HOSMER will appeal to the public.

abstract: Manliness in Surrendering
snippet: Manliness in Surrendering
lead_paragraph: CLEMENT C. CLAY, Jr., is the only man alleged to be implicated in the conspiracy which ended in the assassination of President LINCOLN, who has shown the least manliness, or acted as if he had faith in his own innocence. As soon as he saw that a reward was offered for him, he surrendered himself at once to a General of the United States Army, and declared his readiness to stand a trial. SANDERS, CLEARY, TUCKER and the rest of the refugees in Canada, have contented themselves with standing at a sale distance and howling about it. One or two of them have declared a willingness to be tried, if they could select the place of trial, designate the court, choose the jury, and be substantially guaranteed against conviction. But CLAY comes forward promptly and surrenders himself to the custody of the government. We begin to have faith in his innocence.

abstract: Affairs at Matamoras Critical
snippet: Affairs at Matamoras Critical
lead_paragraph: Perhaps the advocates of imperialism in Mexico can discredit, or explain away, the news from Matamoras. But if this cannot be done, we shall be forced to the conclusion that the Juarist forces on the Rio Grande are much more numerous and furmidable than the Franco-Mexican accounts represent. On the 29th of April there was was a Republican army of 4,000 men under Gen. NEGRETO, encamped within two leagues of the city. Judging by the wholesale emigration to the Texan side of the river, which the announcement of this fact seems to have caused, and judging also from the extreme measures taken by Gen. MEJIA to improvise a defensive army, the situation must have become to some extent critical for the Imperialists. It is clear at least that the work of subjugation is yet far from being completed.

abstract: United States vs. Isaac Henderson; Foreman Absent and Case Postponed to Next Day
snippet: United States vs. Isaac Henderson; Foreman Absent and Case Postponed to Next Day
lead_paragraph: The case of the United States vs. ISAAC HENDERSON, late Navy Agent, was continued yesterday, in the U.S. Circuit Court, before Judge NELSON and jury. The importance of the case, the professional position of the accused, and the standing of the several eminent counsel engaged, attracted a large number of public and distinguished men, WM. CULLEN BRYANT, the venerable JOSHUA LEAVITT, Judges WHITING, DEAN and BEBEE, Recorder HOFFMAN and JAMES T. BRADY sitting among them. A notable group sat around the lawyers' table at 11 o'clock. The long, white hair and genial countenance attracted the attention first to the District-Attorney, Mr. DICKINSON. At his side sat the subtle CALEB CUSHING, who, for more than half a century, has stood in the front rank of the best legal talent. His burly form is well preserved, and his hard head is well covered with hair. The thin, spare form of WM.M. EVARTS barely supports his forward bent head, although the clear blue eye and the pleasant smile indicatee good health and spirits. HENDERSON, the accused, sat just beyond. He is a man of medium height, with a small, round head, side whiskers, a prominent nose, thin lips and pleasant expression, seemingly self-possessed and unmoved. He refrained entirely from conversation, and recognized but few acquaintances. WILLIAM CULLEN BRYANT, the responsible editor of the Post, with well balanced head, entirely bald, and long whiskers of marvelous whiteness, looked a beau ideal of the successful poet; by his side was JOSHUA LEAVITT, the nestor of religious journalism in America; joining the legal group, with a huge pile of papers before him, was EDWARDS PIERREPONT, whose keen blade was flashed so unpleasantly before the eyes of Mayor OPDYKE a few months since; JAMES T. BRADY, browned and burnt by the hot sun of New-Orleans, was cordially greeted by his brethren of the bar, and sat not far from the jury-box. Beside these were two or three faces familiar at the Tombs Court, a great number of outsiders and several government contractors.

abstract: Stonewall, the; Surrender to Havana Authorities
snippet: Stonewall, the; Surrender to Havana Authorities
lead_paragraph: The privateer, Stonewall, has closed her uneventful and prosaic career as a rebel cruiser, leaving but one vessel afloat to carry the Confederate flag. Our letters and dispatches by the Morro Castle, from Havana, state that Capt. PAGE was summoned to surrender the Stonewall to Capt. BOGGS, of the Connecticut. This he declined to do, on the ground that he had received no instruct ions from Richmond. Subsequently, however, finding himself in a very tight place, he proposed to deliver his vessel to the Havana authorities, on condition that she should never be given up to the United States -- a proposal that was promptly and properly rejected. Capt. PAGE then concluded to make the bent of a bad case, and surrendered his vessel unconditionally to the authorities. His crew were landed and the Stonewall was placed in charge of a guard of Spanish soldiers. We are indebted to the Purser of the Morro Castle for the prompt delivery of our dispatches.

abstract: The aspect of affairs in Arkansas, as presented in the letter of our correspondent, and in the latest address of Gov. MURPHY to the people, is altogether hopeful. The work of reorganization, under the Free Constitution, bids fair to go on with less subsidiary aid in the form of military protection than in any other seceded State -- probably not even excepting Tennessee. The nucleus for a thoroughly free government for the whole State has been established with such general concurrence, outside of the districts subjected to guerrilla domination, that in the disbandment of the rebel armies the Governor finds his task lightened beyond all anticipation. He now recommends the citizens in the counties still disorganized, to meet and consult together, and to recommend for appointment such men as they wish to fill the several county offices. His policy generally appears to tend to conciliation.

abstract: Letter on being Relieved by Gen. Sheridan; Gen. Warren on Being Relieved by Gen. Sheridan

abstract: THE BROOKLYN SUNDAY-SCHOOLS. -- On Tuesday the children attached to the Sunday-Schools of the Orthodox churches celebrated their anniversary, and on Wednesday the schools of the Universalist and Unitarian churches turned out in parade, and marching through different streets presented a very pretty appearance. Each class carried one or more banners and flags, and every school was preceded by an instrumental band or drum corps. After the parade they proceeded to their school-rooms, where they were supplied with cakes, fruits, ice creams, &c., with which all were pleased. The day was fine, and everything passed off agreeable.
lead_paragraph: THE BROOKLYN SUNDAY-SCHOOLS. -- On Tuesday the children attached to the Sunday-Schools of the Orthodox churches celebrated their anniversary, and on Wednesday the schools of the Universalist and Unitarian churches turned out in parade, and marching through different streets presented a very pretty appearance. abstract: Atlantic Cable; Near Completion
snippet: Atlantic Cable; Near Completion
lead_paragraph: THE ATLANTIC TELEGRAPH. -- The manufacturers of the Atlantic telegraph cable repeat with great emphasis their promise to have their portion of the work done by the end of May. And the further conduct of the enterprise for some time thereafter will mainly devolve upon Capt. ANDERSON, of the Cunard steamship China, who takes command of the Great Eastern during the laying of the line. Capt. ANDERSON is to have a picked crew to man the vessel, on the management of which nearly everything would seem henceforth to depend. The paying-out apparatus is said to be as nearly perfect as may be. The cable and each separate wire and coating, of which it is composed, have been subjected to the most searching tests at every step as the work has progressed. And what is mainly wanted, in addition to these provisions against failure, we take it as a steady ship and a clear-headed and experienced commander. The public here would learn with satisfaction that one or more United States vessels had been ordered to participate in the enterprise as convoys to the Great Eastern.

abstract: Reply to Deputation on Negro Suffrage
snippet: Reply to Deputation on Negro Suffrage
lead_paragraph: The President is reported to have yesterday given an opinion, to a deputation, on the question of negro suffrage, to the effect that it is a matter that may be safely left in the hands of the loyal white residents of the South. It is certainly a question which, in its primary bearings, chiefly affects the loyal citizens who will be brought into most direct contact with the negro population; who will in a measure be responsible for giving a profitable direction to negro labor, and who, above all, will be charged with the responsibility of placing the means of education within the reach of the vast neglected community set free by the war.

abstract: For over a dozen years past the old Gotham Ball Ground, located in the northern section of the Elysian Fields, has been the scene of many a toughfought battle between the leading members of the rival clubs of New-York, who have there met, time and again, to decide the question of the supremacy for the season.
lead_paragraph: For over a dozen years past the old Gotham Ball Ground, located in the northern section of the Elysian Fields, has been the scene of many a toughfought battle between the leading members of the rival clubs of New-York, who have there met, time and again, to decide the question of the supremacy for the season. Though a favorite resort generally, and a very popular place of assemblage for ball players, it is only this Spring that it has been properly laid out for the purpose to which it has been devoted. Through the courtesy of EDWIN STEVENS, Esq., the Gotham, Mutual and Active Clubs, who are the occupants of the field, obtained permission to enlarge and improve the ground, cutting down several trees, remove ing rocks, and leveling and trufing, together with the privilege of creating rows of seats for the accommodation of spectators. Within the past mouth, under the able supervision of the President of the Mutual Club, JOHN WILDEY, those improvements have been made, and Monday last was set apart as a grand opening day of the new grounds. The races of that day, however, necessitated a postponement, and it was deferred until yesterday, the regular club-day, when the programme laid out for the occasion was the means of attracting a large crowd of spectators to the Fields, over a thousand being present during the playing of the game between the first nine of the club and a field side of fifteen.

abstract: Hoboken Races, Last Day
snippet: Hoboken Races, Last Day
lead_paragraph: Large as was the attendance on the two previous days, it was eclipsed by the brilliant array of fashionables and turfites, who mustered in fullest force on the final day of the meeting. The pleasurable drive from the New-York ferries invited a large attendance of elegantly-appointed equipages, and the field presented a most brilliant array, whilst the grand stand was crowded to its fullest capacity. The ladies have evidently taken racing in hand, and evince a determination to support the legitimate pastimes of the turf, aa in France and England -- a resolution at which we rejoice, as the presence of the fairer portion of creation exercises a humanizing influence on all present, and the stigma once attached to the turf is by their bright patronage effaced. Henceforth at all our local race-courses we anticipate seeing a brilliant array of beauty and fashion, such as we had at Paterson, and again at Saratoga. The society have been favored with three beautiful days for the pleasures of the turf as far as weather has been concerned. All their arrangements, too, have been unexceptionable, the utmost attention having been given to the comfort and enjoyment of all present, and an earnest desire manifested to contribute to the gratification of every patron of the meeting. We cannot conclude our notice without bearing witness to the efficient services of Mr. JOHN M. FRANCIS, the superintendant of the course, by whom, by the way, it was laid out originally. The judges did their duty faithfully and impartially. The police arrangements were of the most admirable description, and there was not a single complaint of a wrong done to any one throughout the meeting. The Hoboken races will henceforth be a recognized and well-patronized permanent institution, and their Fall meeting cannot fail in being a brilliant success.

abstract: All the business connected with the issue and renewal of licenses, a labor which was formerly divided between the Clerk of the Common Council and the Mayor's Marshal, is now performed entirely by the latter officer. Business is thus greatly expedited, and parties who desire to get out licenses are not kept running about from one office to the other.
lead_paragraph: All the business connected with the issue and renewal of licenses, a labor which was formerly divided between the Clerk of the Common Council and the Mayor's Marshal, is now performed entirely by the latter officer. Business is thus greatly expedited, and parties who desire to get out licenses are not kept running about from one office to the other. Formerly it was no uncommon thing to see a file of twenty or thirty persons waiting their turn to pay the fees and get out their papers. Now none are detained more than a few minutes. As all the books and documents are kept in one department, all references are quickly made, and information given without delay.

abstract: PRIZE FIGHT IN OLIVER-STREET. At about 6 o'clock on Wednesday morning a prize fight came off in the yard of premises No. 70 Oliver-street, between WILLIAM JOICE alias Williams, an Irish seaman, and WM. FURLONG, an English sailor.
lead_paragraph: PRIZE FIGHT IN OLIVER-STREET. -- At about 6 o'clock on Wednesday morning a prize fight came off in the yard of premises No. 70 Oliver-street, between WILLIAM JOICE alias Williams, an Irish seaman, and WM. FURLONG, an English sailor. The arrangements for the fight were kept very secret, and the contest was witnessed by a gathering of bounty-jumpers, thieves, and loafers generally. Thirteen rounds were fought in forty minutes, and the fight ended in a "draw," both men being severely punished. Some hours afterward Capt. THORNE, of the Fourth Precinct, received information of the affair, and immediately Officers HORBELT and MULLEN were sent to arrest the principals, which they did. They were arraigned before Justice DOWLING and committed for examination.

abstract: Dictator, monitor, officers of
snippet: Dictator, monitor, officers of
lead_paragraph: Yesterday, at 1 P.M., the United States frigate Colorado, 52 guns, 3,425 tons burden, was put in commission at the Brooklyn Navy-yard. This splendid vessel, which has been undergoing a thorough overhauling at the yard since its last engagement at Fort Fisher, is the flagship of Admiral GOLDSBOROUGH, who will command the squadron in the Mediterranean. Part of her crew, 247 men, were transferred to her yesterday from the North Carolina. The tender of the flagship is being fitted up as rapidly as possible. The Colorado is already in the stream. Most of the fleet will sail from this and other ports during the Summer. The following is list of her officers: Commander, ROBT. H. WYMAN; Lieut.-Com. Lewis A. Kimberly; Flag Lieutenant, R.A. Sampson; Lieutenants, J.C. Watson, Jas. H. Robertson, H.B. Robertson, S.D. Ames, Wm.T. Sampsons; Paymaster, J.S. Cunningham; Past Assistant Surgeons, Jas. H. Tinkham, R.T. Edes; Ensigns, Chas. H. Craven, Ira Harris; Acting Ensign, Chas. H. Pendleton; Captain of Marines, C.D. Hebb; Lieutenant Marines, E.P. Meeker; Chaplain, Chas. R. Hale; Gunner, J. Webber: First Assistant Engineers, G.D. Emmons, Henry Brown; Second Assistants, H. Missin[???]r, Guy Samson; Acting Third Assistant, Fred. H. Morton; Midshipmen, C.T. Schmitz, Geo. W. Flagg, C.J. Train, C.H. Davis, Jr., C.F. Goodrick, O.F. Heyerman, Geo. W. Armentrout, A.G. Caldwell, G.V. Menzies, F.W. Dickens, Edwin White, T.F. Jewett, Jas. P. Weaver, Jno. Schouler; Fleet Surgeon, W.S.W. Ruschenberger; Fleet Captain, Capt. abstract: Morris vs. Goddard, Parkhurst's Cotton Gin; United States vs. Collins; Mail Contract
snippet: Morris vs. Goddard, Parkhurst's Cotton Gin; United States vs. Collins; Mail Contract
lead_paragraph: Francis Morris et al. vs. Calvin A. Goddard et al. -- NELSON, C.J. -- This is a bill filed to restrain the defendants from infringing the patent of S.B. Parkburst, of 12th February, 1861, for an improvement on machines, for ginning cotton and burring wool, and for damages. The proofs are voluminous. The case has been well argued on both sides, and we have looked into it with all the care that time has permitted. There may be some doubts, upon the proofs, whether or not the claim for the cylinder, which is the first claim on the patent, is well founded; but we are satisfied the remaining three claims embrace improvements which belong to the patentee. The fourth, which combines the improvements with carding machines, is very meritorious.

abstract: AMENDE. -- Commenting a day or two since upon the tolerance exhibited by our government toward those opposition journals in our midst whose aim and spirit is really, if not avowedly, antagonistic to republican institutions, we drew attention especially to the Courrier des Etats Unis, which recently, under the pretence of deploring the assumed ascendency of military over civil power in adjudicating matters growing out of the rebellion, has been daily filled with diatribes against the Administration. To the most casual reader of that journal, the very fact of its undisturbed existence must be sufficient proof that its alleged fears are utterly groundless. Inadvertently we alluded to the Courrier as the French organ. We should have qualfiied the expression by saying the organ of imperialism and LOUIS NAPOLEON. The exponent of the opinions of the majority of Frenchmen in this city, and perhaps in the Northern States, is Le Messager, a journal conducted with ability, and whose course throughout the rebellion has been in hearty support of the government. Its efforts have been constantly to set before the French population of this country and Europe the true bearings and issues of the late struggle against the slave oligarchy, and we are glad to believe that this journal is the recognized organ of the loyal French people who have become ciitizens of the United States.

abstract: Testimonial, Decline of by; Suffrage; President Johnson on; Testimonials to Public Officials
snippet: Testimonial, Decline of by; Suffrage; President Johnson on; Testimonials to Public Officials
lead_paragraph: "In a republic," says MONTESQUIEU, "presents to public men are odious, because virtue has no need of them. In a monarchy, honor is a motive stronger than presents. But in a despotism, wherein the ruler has neither honor nor virtue, such stimulants may be needful." PLATO, in his ideal republic, made the acceptance of any reward by a public man for doing his duty punishable with death. The old Romans, in the pure and palmy days of their republic, were so careful about this that they enacted a law expressly limiting all such rewards to those of the most diminutive intrinsic value. Our own republican fathers were so jealous of this influence that they conceived the necessity of incorporating in the constitution itself a clause interdicting the reception of presents by any public official from any foreign quarter, and finally made it statute? aw, which still stands. WASHINGTON, it is well known, could never be induced to take any reward beyond his legal stipend; and not even that for his revolutionary services.
headline: {'main': 'Private Testimonials to Public Officials.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Private Testimonials to Public Officials.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Water-street, Brink; $30,000
snippet: Water-street, Brink; $30,000
lead_paragraph: At about 11 o'clock on Wednesday night a fire broke out on the fourth floor of the five-story building No. 101 Water-street, in that portion of the premises occupied for storage purposes by BRINK MEHLEN, commission merchants. By the prompt arrival of the firemen, the flames were confined to the floor on which they had originated. Considerable damage was sustained by the occupants of the premises. The first floor and basement are occupied by S.D. SKILLER, dealer in crockeryware; damage by water, about $700; insured for $2,100 in the New-York Fire and Marine Insurance Company. The second and third floors are occupied by Messrs. GIRO & FRANCIA, importers of liquorice, corks, &c. Their loss is estimated at about $10,000; insured for $12,000 each in the Washington and Security, and $5,000 each in the Fulton, Brevoort, and Relief Insurance Companies.
headline: {'main': 'Large Fire in Water-street.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Large Fire in Water-street.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: And the Great Review
snippet: And the Great Review
lead_paragraph: THE REVIEW AND THE COLORED TROOPS. -- It has been hinted, by some over-zealous friends of the colored race, that the absence of negro troops from the grand parade at Washington was owing to a desire, on the part of the government, to spare the sensitive feelings of the rebels, which might have been wounded by such an exhibition. This is very silly, and scarcely worthy of notice. The government had no thought of sparing rebel sensitiveness, nor of casting a slight on the gallant soldiers who, on so many battle-fields, have displayed such signal courage and devotion. They were not excluded from the review any more than the white troops who were not present on that occasion. They were required to garrison various important stations in the South, and certainly no higher compliment could have been paid to their bravery, their good discipline, and their devotion to their country, than their selection for this service. For this emphatic indorsement of their soldierly qualities, by the government and the Lieutenant-General, they could well afford to sacrifice the momentary triumphs of the grand review.
