abstract: THE NEW FIRE DEPARTMENT BILL. -- The decision of the Supreme Court on the new Fire Department Bill has been given. It declares the bill unconstitutional. Until the judgment of the Court of Appeals is given, therefore, the organization of the department remains as it was, or rather as it has been for the two months past. That is, there is an absence, all but complete, of any organization. This is a disagreeable enough fact, certainly. The fire-alarms, too, are of suspicious frequency. But those who have an interest in preventing the organization of the new department are perfectly indifferent to any contingencies, however serious, that may arise. They want to live and fructify under the old system, at whatever cost to the taxpayers in the form of legal obstructions, or at whatever risk to property in the city. We see no immediate remedy for this dangerous state of things. But surely every citizen who has any property to lose should be urged to extra precautions against incendiaries. Accidental fires cause but a small proportion of the losses; and only vigilant volunteer efforts can save the city from serious calamity while the management of the Fire Department remains in its present disorganized condition.

abstract: Monument Fund; F. A. W.'s Suggestion
snippet: Monument Fund; F. A. W.'s Suggestion
lead_paragraph: THE MONUMENT FUND. -- We print elsewhere an excellent suggestion and example by "F.A.W." As the subscriptions to the Lincoln Monument Fund are limited to one dollar for each person or name, our correspondent suggests that those who can afford it shall subscribe in the names of the gallant martyrs who have fallen in defence of their country. He illustrates his idea by sending us $2, one in the name of RICHARD WYATT CHASE, killed at the battle of Stone River, and the other to represent his brother, W. BEVERLY CHASE, "starved at Andersonville prison-pen." We commend this praiseworthy example to the people.

lead_paragraph: The attendance yesterday morning at the United States Court rooms was hardly as numerous at the opening as on the morning before; but before noon every available spot of standing-room was taken. The juror, on account of whose absence on Wednesday the Court adjourned, made his appearance, and explained as the cause of his previous delinquency a sudden attack of illness, which rendered him entirely unable to attend. His excuse was accepted, and he again took his seat.

Resigned Commission in Vol. Service; Reply to Rebel Gov Brown, of Georgia, through Gen Wilson; Spalding,Dr. Mathias, of Amherst, N.H.; Resigned Commission in Vol. Service; Pres. Johnson's Reply to through Gen. Wilson; Resigned Com. in Vol. Service
snippet: Resigns Commission in Volunteer Service; Burnside Major-Gen. Resigned Commission in Vol. Service; Reply to Rebel Gov Brown, of Georgia, through Gen Wilson; Spalding,Dr. Mathias, of Amherst, N.H.; Resigned Commission in Vol. Service; Pres. Johnson'...
lead_paragraph: Gen. WILSON, in a letter to Gov. BROWN, of Georgia, who had complained of the collapse of the currency, and great destitution of provisions among the people, says he is instructed by the President to say to him that these evils "were caused by treason, insurrection, and rebellion against the laws of the United States, incited and carried on during the last four years by you and your confederate rebels and traitors, and who alone are responsible for all the waste, destitution and want now existing in that State, and what you call the results which the fortunes of war have imposed upon the people of Georgia, and all the loss and woe they have suffered are charged upon you and your confederate rebels, who, usurping authority, provoked war to the extremity until compelled to lay down your arms and accept the just penalty of your crimes of treason and rebellion. That the restoration of peace and order cannot be entrusted to the rebels and traitors, that the persons who incited the war and carried it on will not be allowed to assemble at the call of their accomplice, to act again as a Legislature of the State, and again usurp its authority and franchises. Men who have caused so much woe will not be allowed over again to set on foot fresh acts of treason and rebellion. In calling the Legislature together again, without the permission of the President, you have perpetrated a fresh crime that will be dealt with accordingly, and if any person presumes to acknowledge your call he will immediately be arrested."

abstract: Fire Department; Bill Declared Unconstitutional
snippet: Fire Department; Bill Declared Unconstitutional
lead_paragraph: The trial of ISAAC HENDERSON was continued before Judge NELSON and a jury yesterday. The missing foreman, Mr. CLAPP, found himself, and said that having been seriously indisposed, he could not attend on Wednesday. The case then proceeded, a full report of which will be found in another column. The testimony of Mr. H.D. STOVER, the well-known machinist, caused a lively breeze, pending which, the court adjourned until to-day, at 11 A.M. Mr. STOVER testified that from all his bills Mr. HENDERSON made deductions. he (STOVER) giving receipts for the full amount, but receiving only a part.

abstract: THE STATE OF THE STREETS. -- Only the moderate heat of the season prevents the spread of pestilence from one end of the city to the other. The City Inspector may or may not be justified in invoking, as he did yesterday, the intervention of the Board of Health. Three weeks hence, which is the time named by the Inspector for the board to convene, will either find the city in a cleaner condition, or the evil resulting from the present all-prevalent filth beyond remedy by the Board of Health or any other board. The neighborhood of the slaughter-houses on First-avenue already suffers from a combination of pestilential stinks, beyond human endurance.

abstract: the Advance in Price of
snippet: the Advance in Price of
lead_paragraph: Of late, we have been importing foreign goods much more freely than we have been exporting domestic produce. As the inevitable result of this course, we have been accumulating indebtedness against us in foreign countries. To adjust the adverse balance of trade, we have been forced to make heavy remittances in "hard cash," in the absence of an active foreign demand for American stocks, or such advices from the Old World as would authorize speculative shipments of our government bonds and railway shares.

abstract: Defacement of Natural Scenery
snippet: Defacement of Natural Scenery
lead_paragraph: DEFACING NATURAL SCENERY. -- We have before called attention to the passage by the Legislature of this State of an act to prevent the defacement of rocks, trees and fences by advertisers of quack nostrums and disguised intoxicants. We publish the act in full this morning for the benefit of the Legislatures of other States, which could not do better than follow the example of New-York and New-Hampshire, in their determination to keep the face of nature clean within their borders. This law should not be allowed to remain a dead-letter on the statute book, but should be rigidly enforced in every part of the State. The vandals who would desecrate the grandeur of Niagara, or make the silver mirror of Lake George reflect obscene pictorial "appeals to the unfortunate," are the personal enemies of people of taste, and lovers of nature should do as much to prevent the defacement of natural scenery everywhere, as they would to punish an injury to their private grounds.

abstract: The Grand Army in Camp
snippet: The Grand Army in Camp
lead_paragraph: THE GRAND ARMIES IN CAMP. -- Those who had not the opportunity to witness the magnificent display of the armies in Washington on Tuesday and Wednesday last, and who are sorry that the war has passed away without their having seen anything of the wonderful military life and military heroes about which and whom they have read and heard so much during the four years past, need not be hopeless for some time yet. The army of Gen. SHERMAN, when it had filed through Pennsylvania-avenue on Wednesday, did not by any means file into chaos; nor was the Army of the Potomac dissolved after Tuesday's review. The army of SHERMAN passed just outside of the limits of the National Capital, and encamped in the fields and forests east of the city, near the line of the Baltimore Railroad, while the Army of the Potomac went into camp on the other side of the river, whose name it bears. Both of the armies are within short distance of the city; and the visitor has at this moment facilities for observing camp and army life in all its wonderful and picturesque aspects, such as have never before been enjoyed during the war.

abstract: Sensation Reports on Harshness to Davis
snippet: Sensation Reports on Harshness to Davis
lead_paragraph: VICIOUS SENSATION REPORTS. -- The public may properly be warned against giving credit to the report of a Baltimore news-monger relative to the treatment of JEFF. DAVIS at Fortress Monroe. The story is permitted to circulate by telegraph, and we print it to show what is considered essential food for the prevailing vicious appetite for sensations. If the government have found it necessary to adopt extra precautions in the case of the prisoner, we are satisfied that no unnecessary harshness has marked the treatment he has received. And the story in the shape in which it appears is either an emanation from some rebel sympathizer, intended to create a feeling of commiseration for DAVIS, or it has been concocted to supply the lack of truthful intelligence on the subject of that individual's incarceration. If a censorship is of use at all, surely this is a case wherein it might be applied with some advantage. The Memphis "negro plot" belongs to the same category of mendacious sensation rumors. The fabricators invite summary and severe punishment.

abstract: A PREGNANT REMARK. -- A gentleman who visited Gen. JOE JOHNSTON, at his home in Charlotte (N.C.,) last week, reports that he asked JOHNSTON if he had seen the proclamation offering a reward for the capture of DAVIS, SANDERS and others? "Yes," he replied; "and knowing, as I do thoroughly well, the character of CLEMENT C. CLAY, I do not believe that he was in any manner concerned in or privy to the assassination."

abstract: United States vs. Isaac Henderson; Close of Trial; Acquittal
snippet: United States vs. Isaac Henderson; Close of Trial; Acquittal
lead_paragraph: James T. Brady appeared, with Judge Edwards Pierrepont and Wm. M. Evarts, Esq., for the accused; and the District-Attorney, Mr. Dickinson, assisted by Hon. Caleb Cushing, of Massachusetts, Judge Bosworth, and Mr. Andrews, the Assistant District-Attorney. The case rested entirely upon the testimony of Mr. H.D. Stover, a prominent machinist and naval contractor, and his chief clerk, Mr. Brown; by them the government proposed to prove that during a long series of transactions between Mr. Stover and Mr. Henderson, on the part of the government, the latter had systematically withheld from the former from eight to ten per cent. of the amounts due him from the government for naval and other supplies. It was found, upon examination, that the business of Mr. Stover was conducted entirely by himself and his chief clerk, Mr. Brown, the one and the other alternating in receiving and depositing the moneys received from Mr. Henderson and others. The magnitude of the business was such, and the frequency of the transactions so confusing, that when the witnesses were placed upon the stand they were unable to identify or swear to any individual transaction, knowing about it and all only such details as appeared upon the books. Judge Nelson permitted the witnesses to refresh their memory by reference to the books, but insisted upon their testifying simply to what they knew of their own knowledge.

abstract: The body of a female, apparently about 50 years of age, dark hair, of medium size, was found on Coney Island beach, on the 24th inst., where it had been driven by the tide. Deceased had no clothing except a nightdress. An inquest was held by Justice S.J. VOORHELS, of Gravesend, L.I., and a verdict of death by drowning was rendered. Further information can be had by calling upon Justice VOORHEES.
lead_paragraph: FIRE ALARMS. -- There was an alarm of are in the Seventh District about 7 o'clock last evening, caused by the burning of some rubbish in Franklin-avenue. abstract: The above is the medical or surgical name of a new system discovered by Doctor E.B. LIGHTHILL, the eminent aurist, for the treatment of diseases of the throat, Catarrh, Asthma, Affections of the Voice, Laryngeal, Bronchial and Pulmonary Complaints, and the diseases of the Respiratory Organs. A correspondent sends us the following account of the application of the above new remedy: -- "I was seriously afflicted with a sore throat -- diphtheria and all its fatal consequences were ever before my mind, when I first heard of Dr. LIGHTHILL's new system -- Nephotherapy. A friend assured me that it was painless and most efficacious, and so I made up my mind I would try it. When first introduced into the doctor's study, I saw a formidable-looking combination of brass instruments, and an air-pump, which a gentleman of color was working assiduously. Somewhat frightened by this array -- I am a very nervous person -- I hesitatingly took the seat the doctor pointed out, and as he approached me with a lot of bright silver things in his hand, my heart came into my throat. These turned out, however, to be merely a series of little mirrors, by an ingenious use of which the doctor took an accurate survey of my throat. I was put into another chair, and was informed that I should undergo Nephotherapy. 'It is quite painless,' said the doctor; but I confess I did not believe him. At that moment, the gentleman of color pumped harder, and suddenly turned a screw of the brass machine. A mist or fog, (almost invisible, it was so fine,) issued from a tube directed toward my face. I breathed this mist a moment or two, and then, to my surprise, the doctor said, 'That will do.' And this was Nephotherapy. Two applications cured my throat. The fine mist settled upon its inflamed parts like a dew upon the grass, caused no irritation, and removed the disease. For the especial benefit of those who, like myself, are nervous, and for little children who may be afflicted with diseases of the ear, the eye, the throat, or the respiratory organs, I relate my experience of the new system." Dr. LIGHTHILL, who is known as a medical writer, has published a work on the above subject, of which we shall speak in another number. -- Home Journal, May 27.

abstract: Richmond and New-York Price of Provisions
snippet: Richmond and New-York Price of Provisions
lead_paragraph: A BETTER TIME FOR CONSUMERS. -- The cost of ordinary provisions in Richmond is less than half what it is in New-York. Good joints of meat can be had for ten cents a pound. The same could hardly be bought here for two shillings. Eggs are quoted at 15 cents a dozen, and butter at 25 cents. The extortion to which we patiently submit here cannot last much longer in the face of those facts. The difference does not apply alone to necessaries, but to luxuries as well. At Charlotte, N.C., you may buy as much tobacco for twenty-five cents as you can buy in New-York for a dollar. A little while and the tumble in prices here will startle those who have traded on the faith that war prices should rule permanently. Like other delusions, we shall see this exploded anon.

abstract: The Grand Jury of the District of Columbia yesterday found a bill of indictment against JEFF. DAVIS and JOHN C. BRECKINRIDGE for high treason. They are indicted separately. The overt act was the raid in July last within the District of Columbia and the jurisdiction of the court, the killing of citizens and the destroying ...
lead_paragraph: of property, BRECKINRIDGE being present in person and JEFF. DAVIS constructively. District-Attorney CARRINGTON announced the fact to the Court, and asked for a bench warrant in the case of BRECKINRIDGE, who is still at large. He also asked that such steps may be taken as will bring JEFF. DAVIS before the court for trial.

abstract: Men in the South not all Killed
snippet: Men in the South not all Killed
lead_paragraph: High officers of the Confederate army say that JEFF. DAVIS told the truth literally last Winter when he proclaimed in a public speech in Georgia that two-thirds of the Southern conscripts had deserted from his army. The rebel Chief declared that this immense proportion of his troops were absent from the ranks without leave; in other words, they had escaped to their homes, and were determined to stay at home. The Confederate military authorities could not spare from active duty the heavy details of men and officers that would have been required to traverse the vast and thinly settled regions of the South for the purpose of hunting up and hunting down these fugitives. And consequently tens of thousands and hundreds of thousands of men were enabled to escape a hatred service, though many of them had from time to time to conceal themselves, or resort to evasion or flight.

abstract: New-York vs. Newark, Match
snippet: New-York vs. Newark, Match
lead_paragraph: At the corner of Broadway and Astor-place no less than three regular organized clubs meet on alternate days for practice. Almost every State has its champion, especially in the northern district. The champions of New-York and New-Jersey have had several contests for supremacy. On Thursday last two of the best players of the most prominent clubs of Newark and New-York competed for a prize of $200. Messrs. MCLEARAN and MCGREGOR represented Newark, and Messrs. GIBSON and FERGUSON, New-York. The Newarkers won by a score of 41 to 31 for New-York. At the start, and up to the thirteenth end, the New-Yorkers took the lead, the score standing 13 to 4. The Newarkers then opened their shoulders, and at the end were ten points ahead. A large company was present to witness the match, and a vast amount of speculation depended upon the result. The parties were looked upon as evenly matched at the start. Out of this another match is likely to come off shortly between four selected players of New-York and four picked from the clubs of New-Jersey.

abstract: JEFFERSON DAVIS attracts the attention of the country and the world no less at this time than at any other time during the last four years. The ruined leader of an irretrievably ruined cause, his character and career mark him as one destined to retain for ages a bad eminence in the history of the American Republic.
lead_paragraph: JEFFERSON DAVIS attracts the attention of the country and the world no less at this time than at any other time during the last four years. The ruined leader of an irretrievably ruined cause, his character and career mark him as one destined to retain for ages a bad eminence in the history of the American Republic. The audacious yet self-possessed revolutionary leader -- the plotter, organizer and executive agent of secession -- the President of the Southern Confederacy, the author of its policy, the director of its powerful armies, and, in great measure, the cause of its ruin -- the fugitive from his capital and from justice, the outlaw, the caught and imprisoned culprit -- DAVIS has in every position and condition stood as the central figure in the world's history since 1860.

abstract: Mr. Christian's Report; Boutet's Safety Apparatus; Paris Dog Show; the Original of in Nicholas Nickleby; Golden Rose, the, at Rome
snippet: Mr. Christian's Report; Boutet's Safety Apparatus; Paris Dog Show; the Original of in Nicholas Nickleby; Golden Rose, the, at Rome
lead_paragraph: Mr. ALFRED CHRISTIAN, President of the Chamber of Commerce of Malta, delegated by the Chamber to represent the commercial community of this island at the congress of delegates invited by M.F. DE LESSEPS, to inspect the works of the Isthmus of Suez Canal, has just returned to Malta. The journey through the isthmus occupied about ten days, during which time the delegates had every opportunity of inspecting the works in progress, and of conferring with the engineers and other officers belonging to the company. The conclusion Mr. CHRISTIAN arrives at is that the completion of the ship canal is only a question of time and money, and that in a very few years the communication from sea to sea for vessels of large tonnage will be established, thus uniting the West with the East by an uninterrupted water route, and shortening the sea voyage from Europe to India for steamers by fully one-half. It still, of course, remains an open question, how far the canal will be useful to our sailing Indiamen, owing to the prevalent winds in the Red Sea. About 80 delegates, representatives of the various States and commercial communities of Europe, Asia and America, performed the journey through the isthmus, accompanied by M. DE LESSETS and the principal officers of the company, to whom, we are informed, the delegates are greatly indebted for the courtesy invariably shown them, and for the readiness with which all their inquiries were answered. It is to be regretted that England was not represented at this very interesting meeting, Mr. CHRISTIAN, as representative of Malta, being the only English commercial delegate present. The delegates performed the journey from the Nile to Ismaila by the freshwater canal, and from Ismaila to Port Said by the maritime (saltwater) canal. The boats were towed by camels, and horses, and for a distance also on the maritime canal by steamers. After inspecting the works in progress at Port Said the delegates returned again south, sailing back to Ismaila with a fresh northerly wind. The maritime canal is not at present navigable for boats beyond Ismaila; the remainder of the journey, therefore, to the Red Sea, had to be performed by the freshwater canal. This latter canal takes its source at the Nile, close to the town of Zagazig, and runs nearly due east through the once for the land of Goshen until it reaches Is[???]a; at about two miles from the latter town it branches off to the southward, leaving Lake Timsah and the Bitter Lakes on the east, and joins the Red Sea at Suez. Ismaila is a flourishing and picturesque little town of three thousand inhabitants, situated in the centre of the isthmus, seventy-five kilometres from Port Said, midway between the two seas at the north end of Lake Timsah, and owes its existence to the works of the canal. The width of the maritime canal varies at present, according to localities, from about sixteen to fifty-eight metres, except in the immediate vicinity of Port Said, where it attains eighty-four metres. Its average depth at present is not more than two to three feet. The depth of the freshwater canal is much the same at present as that of the maritime canal, but, of course, it is deeper during high Nile; its width varies from about sixteen to twenty-five metres. The company, we understand, have contracted with various French firms for the completion of the whole of the works from the Mediterranean to the Red Sea by the 1st of July, 1868, at which date the company expect that the canal will be opened to navigation, at a cost to the shareholders not exceeding the subscribed capital of eight millions sterling. On these points, however, Mr. CHRISTIAN had not sufficient data to enable him to form an accurate opinion. -- Malta Times, May 4.

abstract: Mr. BEECHER was well chosen as the national orator at Fort Sumter. He is eloquent and enthusiastic, and he represents, too, exactly that element in the civil strife which has predominated and triumphed. One thing beyond all doubt has been decided by the American war, and that is the fate of slavery.

abstract: Secretary STANTON gives official information that Gen. CANBY has completed arrangements (with KIRBY SMITH) for the entire surrender of all the rebel forces, land and naval, in the Trans-Mississippi Department. This is the final official act of the expiring rebellion -- the last vestige of its pretended authority has passed away, and THE WAR IS OVER. Those who have entertained the opinion -- and there have been many such -- that there would or might be serious trouble with the rebels in the West, may now dismiss their fears. The fact is, the forces under Gen. SMITH's control were much weaker in numbers and much more disorganized than was generally believed; and doubtless the news that PHIL. SHERIDAN was about to take his case in hand, decided the rebel commander to imitate Capt. SCOTT's coon, and "come down." But details are comparatively unimportant. The Rebellion is officially ended -- THE WAR IS OVER -- PEACE ONCE MORE REIGNS from the Atlantic to the Pacific, from the Lakes to the Gulf. over every acre of our reunited country. Thanks be to GOD! and all honor to the loyal hearts and stout hands that have been His instruments in giving the victory!

abstract: Nelson, A., Garroted in Nineteenth-street; Mattalessett, S. S., Officers of
snippet: Nelson, A., Garroted in Nineteenth-street; Mattalessett, S. S., Officers of
lead_paragraph: Mr. ALFRED NELSON, of No. 295 Avenue A, was garroted and robbed by three footpads, who attacked him while he was standing at the intersection of Avenue A and Nineteenth-street, at about 3 o'clock yesterday morning. Policeman MOSEBACK, of the Eighteenth Ward, hearing Mr. NELSON's cries while he was struggling with the thieves, reached the scene in season to capture one of the outlaws -- THOMAS MURPHY by name; and the fellow, having been fully identified by Mr. NELSON, was committed in default of $2,500 bail.

abstract: Messrs. MASON  CO.'S extensive chair manufactory, at Nos. 186, 188 and 190 Avenue C, was totally consumed, and several tenement dwellings and other buildings in the immediate neighborhood were very seriously damaged by fire and water, at about noon yesterday. The flames were first observed in the fireroom of the chair factory; but they sped upward ...
lead_paragraph: Messrs. MASON & CO.'S extensive chair manufactory, at Nos. 186, 188 and 190 Avenue C, was totally consumed, and several tenement dwellings and other buildings in the immediate neighborhood were very seriously damaged by fire and water, at about noon yesterday. The flames were first observed in the fireroom of the chair factory; but they sped upward with such velocity through the inflammable stock and machinery with which the building was filled, that there was literally no time for the escape of the occupants of the upper stories; and had it not been the dinner hour, when nearly all of the workmen were absent, the loss of life must have been appalling. The occupants of the fifth story -- that story having been occupied by families -- were within the building, and they escaped only by pressing into service a rope which had been used in hoisting furniture outside on the front. Two of their number, however, in their eagerness to make their exit, flew to the windows, and, attempting to get thence to the pavement, fell, and were mortally injured. The name of one of these -- a French workman in the factory -- who undertook to descend from the fifth story by hanging on the outer wall, and retaining a hold on the window-sill until the firemen could raise a ladder to rescue him, has not been reported. The volumes of smoke from a fourth story window beneath suffocated him, and he fell while the firemen were preparing, under intense and almost overpowering heat, to take him from the vast, consuming furnace. FRANK STIVER, one of the workmen, who was employed on the third floor, leaped from a window, and was mortally injured. Both men were taken to Bellevue Hospital. Several occupants of the upper floors narrowly escaped death; but the two men above reported are all that are known to have been injured beyond hope of recovery.

abstract: I have received several letters from the North asking for information respecting the graves of relatives and friends who have died in the hospitals at Richmond. All Union soldiers who died in Richmond during the war have been buried in Oakwood Cemetery, and from the Summer of 1863 up to the time of our occupation in April last, there have been buried them two thousand six hundred and thirty-six.
lead_paragraph: RICHMOND, Sunday, May 21, 1865.

abstract: Central Park, Beauties, >amp;c., of
snippet: Central Park, Beauties, >amp;c., of
lead_paragraph: Now that Spring, with all its gushing life and beauty, is throwing rich treasures into the lap of nature, and dressing this goodly earth of ours with her own fresh mantle, a visit to Central Park will repay the expenditure of time or trouble in getting there. The tide of visitors seems already to flow thitherward rapidly, for we learn that during the month of April, there were 188,019 pedestrians, 11,344 equestrians, and 125,864 vehicles that entered the Park at the several gates. But on Sunday, the last day of April, the first great crowd for this year was witnessed. On that day 37,581 pedestrians, 602 equestrians, and 8,349 vehicles visited the Park; making in all nearly 60,000 persons in twenty-four hours.

abstract: Stonewall, the, and the Cuban Authorities; Debt, Scheme to Liquidate; Soldiers should be Allowed to Preserve
snippet: Stonewall, the, and the Cuban Authorities; Debt, Scheme to Liquidate; Soldiers should be Allowed to Preserve
lead_paragraph: There are few persons, we trust, likely to be deceived by a sensational scheme which has been set afloat for paying off the national debt. There is, at first glance, an appearance of patriotism in the proposal of two or three individuals to form so many in a band of 150,000, to cancel the public debt by individual donations of $20,000 to the Treasury. Looked at casually the thing seems fair enough. There are two considerations, however, which (reflection will show) not only stamp the project us impracticable, but tend to throw a sort of doubt on the bona fides of the prime movers.

abstract: Trial Postponed to May 30; Trial; Difficulties of
snippet: Trial Postponed to May 30; Trial; Difficulties of
lead_paragraph: The certainty that JEFF. DAVIS is to be brought before the bar of a court and put upon his trial for treason, naturally calls the public attention to what may possibly occur and what questions may possibly arise upon that trial. We have had prosecutions for treason before, though, happily, but few. Most prominent among them was the case of AARON BURR; but others arose out of the Western Insurrection of 1794 and the Northampton Insurrection of 1799; out of a controversy about a raft of timber in Vermont in 1803; and out of the Gorsuch murder in Pennsylvania, in 1851. The questions which were of difficulty in those latter cases, however, will hardly arise here. They were mainly, whether the facts proved constituted the offence of treason. But it will not be possible to bring any definition of treason which will not cover what can be proved to have been done by DAVIS.

abstract: Major-General JOHN A. DIX, commanding the Department of the East, has returned from Boston, and Major-Gen. PECK, who acted during his absence, has resumed his duties at the upper office.
lead_paragraph: Major-General JOHN A. DIX, commanding the Department of the East, has returned from Boston, and Major-Gen. PECK, who acted during his absence, has resumed his duties at the upper office. Gen. DIX went to Boston on Tuesday last, in pursuance of orders from the War Department, to make arrangements for the reception and custody of "Vice-President" STEPHENS and "Postmaster" REAGAN, of the late Southern Confederacy. The steamer Tuscarora, having on board the distinguished rebels, reached that port on Wednesday night, and anchored in the harbor. On Thursday morning Gen. DIX sent Col. MCMAHON, of his staff, in a tug to the Tuscarora, charged with the duty of removing the prisoners to the fort. Mr. STEPHENS was taken first. He looked as he always has done, a mere shadow of a skeleton, but was by no means moody or discourteous in manner. Physically he is in ordinary health, and rather enjoyed the bracing air of the harbor. Mr. REAGAN was subsequently taken by the same officer.

abstract: The General Assembly of the New-School Presbyterian Church, held their usual session yesterday. It being Saturday tho morning was prolonged and no afternoon session was held.
lead_paragraph: The General Assembly of the New-School Presbyterian Church, held their usual session yesterday. It being Saturday tho morning was prolonged and no afternoon session was held. The principal business before the Assembly was the reading and consideration of a report from a Special Committee on the State of the Country, read by Dr. FISHER. This document exhausted the subject, and set forth the past conduct of the church and its proposed line of conduct in the future, and claimed that the church must be ready to exercise due vigilance in politics as well as in religion. A memorial was also presented by Dr. SPEAKS demanding the right of franchise for the colored man, contending that the freedmen would be necessary to reorganize the South. Both papers were unanimously adopted. The commmittee on overtures reported upon several submitted to them, on the proposed union of the two branches of the church, and upon theatres and card playing. On the first they advised postponing action, and on the others they recommended careful watchfulness among the churches. Pending the consideration of the report of the committee on Church Polity, the assembly adjourned until Monday morning.

abstract: Union, S. S., Officers of
snippet: Union, S. S., Officers of
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Union, Acting Volunteer Lieutenant-Commander, EDWARD CONROY, commanding, arrived here yesterday morning from the East and West Gulf Squadrons, bringing the mails and 13 officers and 28 sick and discharged men. The Union left this port on the 29th of April with supplies for the above-named squadron, and reports fine and healthy weather. Official dispatches have been received of the surrender of the rebel ram Stonewall to the Spanish authorities at Havana on the 20th inst.

abstract: MYSTERIOUS MURDER IN BROOKLYN.--A man supposed to be an Italian, named D. ANTONI, was found, about 6 o'clock last evening, murdered in a wood a short distance from the depot of the Bath and Coney Island Railroad. He appeared to have been shot in the back, and his head was nearly severed from his body.
lead_paragraph: MYSTERIOUS MURDER IN BROOKLYN.--A man supposed to be an Italian, named D. ANTONI, was found, about 6 o'clock last evening, murdered in a wood a short distance from the depot of the Bath and Coney Island Railroad. He appeared to have been shot in the back, and his head was nearly severed from his body. Upon his person was found a gold watch, $3 in money, and a loaded revolver. Also, two letters directed D. ANTONI, No. 235 Bowery and Rose-street, New-York. Subsequent investigations by the police of the Forty-eighth Precinct disclosed the following facts: At about 4 o'clock in the afternoon, four men, supposed to be Italians, were seen by Mrs. RIZZI to pass by her house, on the corner of Thirty-sixth-street and Third-avenue, in the direction of the woods in which the body was found. In about an hour after, she saw three of the same men return to her corner, and then get into a Greenwood car, going in the direction of the ferry. She noticed them on account of their being, as she supposed, Italians and countrymen of hers. These men are supposed to have committed the murder. The murdered man is about five feet seven inches in height, of heavy build, had black hair, a heavy board and moustache. He was dressed in dark plaid pants, black cloth coat, light boots, and a plaid woolen shirt. The body was taken in charge by Coroner LYNCH, who will convene an inquisition to-day, at the Forty-eighth Precinct Station-house.

abstract: -- Says the Paris correspondent of the London Star: "I hear from many quarters that the furore of enthusiasm which 'L'Africaine' created on its first performance, has been succeeded by a fit of coolness, and that many Parisian amateurs do not hesitate to speak of the work in terms of considerable disparagement. If this is so, it really has but little significance. After an almost frantic excitement, we must expect a reaction, and it would be as unreasonable to expect the expression of really sound judgment while the chill is on, as during the fever. Meanwhile there are some calm judges, connoisseurs of ripe experience and cultivated taste, who are far too old stagers to be carried away by surrounding popular enthusiasm, and their opinion is unanimous in regard to the grandeur and beauty of the work, but they are also of one mind as to its excessive length. Most fortunately there seems to exist a means of removing this defect, not only without detriment, but with substantial advantage to the scope. The 'ship act,' in which great scenic triumph was expected to be achieved, appears to have been a quasi j[???]o, and it is al[???]ged that it may be expunged altogether without serious loss. As it takes an honor to set this scene, and a very considerable time to strike it, the saving effected by its excision would bring the opera within reasonable limits."

abstract: FAST IN THE MIRE. -- Officer BRENNER, of the Forty-sixth Precinct, on Thursday evening, was attracted toward the swamp in the rear of the chemical works in the Nineteenth Ward, by the cries of a young boy named EDWARD HOLLINS, whom, on approaching, he found almost up to the neck in the soft mire. With the assistance of another man be succeeded in rescuing the little fellow, who was much exhausted by his efforts to extricate himself. The man who assisted BRENNER came near sinking himself.

abstract: United States vs. Bales of Hair; Undervaluation
snippet: United States vs. Bales of Hair; Undervaluation
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. One Bale Containing Human Hair. -- This was an action to forfeit the goods for alleged fraudulent undervaluation. The article was imported from Italy by the claimant, Gaspar Perine, and invoiced by him at 100. On appraisement at the Custom-house the value was advanced over fifty per cent, and thereupon this libel was filed to forfeit the goods.

abstract: HUDSON COUNTY COURT--SENTENCES.--In the Hudson County Court, on Friday, a young man of good family, living at Hoboken, who was charged by a girl named ANNE S. DECKER with having violated her person, was tried and acquitted.
lead_paragraph: HUDSON COUNTY COURT -- SENTENCES. -- In the Hudson County Court, on Friday, a young man of good family, living at Hoboken, who was charged by a girl named ANNE S. DECKER with having violated her person, was tried and acquitted. It was proven conclusively that this was a conspiracy to extort money, concocted by the mother of the girl and her paramour, who, it is alleged, keep a disreputable house in New-York, -- The case of the State vs. MICHAEL BUCKLEY, indicted for murder at the last October term, and the State vs. CHAS. MCIVER, indicted this term for manslaughter, were postponed until next term. The following-named persons were arraigned and sentenced: John Brady, two indictments, stealing from a store, sent to the County Jail 5 months; Daniel Sullivan, a boy, for larceny, County Jail 3 months; Samuel Duty, for larceny, County Jail 30 days; John Madden, a boy, stealing $60, County Jail 3 months; James Artis, two indictments, atrocious assault and battery on Mr. Grote, fined $75 in one case, and $25 in the other; John Petrel, assault, and battery, fined $10; Bernard Murta and wife, assault and battery on John Gerahgty, fined $5 each, and committed until costs be paid; Mary Singler, keeping a disorderly house, fined $25; Patrick Mchan, a constable, assault and battery, fined $30.

abstract: Gladstone, Hon. W. E., and Oxford University; Gladstone, Hon. W. E., and Oxford University; London Daily News on; Hardy, Gathorne, and Hon. W. E. Gladstone
snippet: Gladstone, Hon. W. E., and Oxford University; Gladstone, Hon. W. E., and Oxford University; London Daily News on; Hardy, Gathorne, and Hon. W. E. Gladstone
lead_paragraph: If Mr. GLADSTONE had committed no graver offence against the political sympathies of his learned constituents, than that of joining a Cabinet in which Mr. MILNER GIBSON was a member, and for which the late Mr. COBDEN was ready to act as a special plenipotentiary, he could hardly have looked for a reelection at the hands of the University Dons. But Mr. GLADSTONE has even graver political crimes to answer for than taking office with British Liberals. The University of Oxford sent him to bless, and lo! he has cursed altogether. His mission, as the representative of the most learned and orthodox constituency in the kingdom, was to uphold the constitution as it was left under the slight paring process applied to it in 1832; to defend the ecclesiastical establishment at all hazards; to maintain Church rates; and to oppose the inroads of radicalism, as he would resist the devil and all his works.
headline: {'main': 'Mr. Gladstone and Oxford.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Mr. Gladstone and Oxford.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Seven-Thirty Loan, New Series; Increasing Popularity
snippet: Seven-Thirty Loan, New Series; Increasing Popularity
lead_paragraph: Popular subscriptions to the new series of the Seven-thirty national loan, which averaged only $1,292,550 a day in the early half of the week, have grown to a daily average of $2,172,000 within the past few days, as against an average of $2,017,783 a day through the preceding week, the first in which the new series was offered to the public. These figures indicate an encouraging improvement in the demand for the notes, which the Treasury Department will commence to deliver to subscribers in the course of another six or eight days, and which will be thenceforward promptly supplied through the distributing agencies all over the country.

abstract: North Carolina, Receiving Ship, Officers of
snippet: North Carolina, Receiving Ship, Officers of
lead_paragraph: The duties of transferring and discharging sailors at the Brooklyn Navy-yard continues to engross the entire attention of the officers of the receiving-ship North Carolina. Since the close of the war, the reduction of our vast navy, which at one time numbered over seven hundred vessels of war, has become of the first importance; and as the New-York naval station is the most important and central in the Union, the responsibility and labor of the officials is, of course, very considerable at this juncture. Sometimes, 100 men a day are discharged the service at the yard. A great many of the best hands are retained to man the Mediterranean fleet, which is to sail very soon. The following are the principal officers of the North Carolina: Commander, Capt. J.P. MCKINSTREY; Lieut.-Commander, J.N. Quackenbush; Surgeon, John G. Abernethy; Paymaster, A.W. Russell; Assistant Paymaster, C.L. Burnett; Chaplain, George W. Dorrance; First Lieut. Marines, H.A. Bartlett.... The following vessels will be sold Tuesday next at 12 M.: Screw-steamers Flag, Kensington, Vicksburgh, Proteus; barkentine Horace Beales; schooner Rachel Seaman. Twenty per cent. of the purchase money to be paid on the day of the sale, and the remainder before the vessel is removed from the yard, which will be done within six days after the date of sale.

abstract: Yesterday morning one MARY A. DUVALL, keeper of an unsavory den in Water-street, near Oliver, was tried for enticing and endeavoring to corrupt three young girls, namely: MARY ANN HOGAN, of Williamsburgh, aged 14 years; ROSANNA DUFFY, of Baxter-street, aged 13 years, and MARY ANN COFFEE, of Mott-street, aged 14 years. It appeared, in evidence, that the prisoner, seeing the three girls in Oliver-street, near Water, at about 3 o'clock on Friday afternoon, urged them to enter her place, and that the girls unsuspectingly accepted the invitation, and were given food and such light beverages as the siren could induce them to drink; that fine clothing was promised them if they would enter the prisoner's employ as dancing-girls; that later in the day several seamen whom the keeper of the den introduced, took such liberties with the three captives as opened their eyes to the character of the prison-house into which they had been led; that they then tried to escape, but were held; that the females DUVALL then sought to allay their fears by promising that if they would remain in her den she would give them gaudy attire, and require only that they would dance with her customers; that at length they attracted the attention of a citizen, and through him sent information of their situation to patrolman CHARLES W. CRITTENDEN, of the Fourth Ward; that thereupon the officer released them and arrested the keeper of the den. On the trial, yesterday morning, the female DUVALL said that the girls voluntarily entered her dance-house and sought employment therein; but Justices DOWLING and KELLY thinking this story improbable, sentenced the prisoner to a term of six months in the Penitentiary.

abstract: Mason's Chair Factory; $66,000
snippet: Mason's Chair Factory; $66,000
lead_paragraph: Messrs. MASON & CO.'s extensive chair manufactory, at Nos. 186, 188 and 190 Avenue C. was totally consumed, and several tenement dwellings and other buildings in the immediate neighborhood were very seriously damaged by fire and water, at about noon on Saturday. The flames were first observed in the fireroom of the chair factory; but they sped upward with such velocity through the inflammable stock and reachiery with which the building was filled, that there was literally no time for the escape of the occupants of the upper stories; and had it not been the dinner hour, when nearly all of the workmen were absent, the loss of life, must have been appalling. The occupants of the fifth story -- that story having been occupied by families -- were within the building, and they escaped only by pressing into service a rope which had been used in hoisting furniture outside on the front. Three of their number, however, in their eagerness to make their exit, flow to the windows, and, attempting to get thence to the pavement, fell, and were mortally injured. The name of one of these -- a French workman in the factory-- who undertook to descend from the fifth story by hanging on the outer wall, and retaining a hold on the window-sill until the firemen could raise a ladder to rescue him, has not been reported. The volumes of smoke from a fourth story window beneath suffocated him, and he fell while the fireman were preparing, under intense and almost overpowering heat, to take him from the vast, consuming furnace. FRANK STIVER, one of the workmen, who was employed on the third floor, leaped from a window, and was mortally injured. DENNIS GIBORD, of No. 206 Church-st., was also mortally injured. The three men were taken to Bellevue Hospital. Several occupants of the upper floors narrowly escaped death; but the three men above reported are all that are known to have been injured beyond hope of recovery.

abstract: New-York, East Tenth-street, Sanches, T., in his room at boarding-house; Morse, Calvin S.; Paymaster's Clerk on School-ship North Carolina; Brooklyn and Williamsburgh, three burglaries; together $135
snippet: New-York, East Tenth-street, Sanches, T., in his room at boarding-house; Morse, Calvin S.; Paymaster's Clerk on School-ship North Carolina; Brooklyn and Williamsburgh, three burglaries; together $135
lead_paragraph: AUDACIOUS ROBBERY IN A BOARDING-HOUSE. -- About 8 o'clock, Saturday evening, two men of genteel address one apparently a Spaniard, and the other an American rapped at the door of the room occupied by Mr. THEODORE SANCHES, on the second floor of the large boarding-house at No. 263 East Tenth-street, and instantly on gaining admission, seized Mr. SANCHES by the threat and threw him to the floor. Informing ing him that his only chance of life lay in maintaining perfect quiet, one of the outlaws held him pro trate while the other stole his costly gold watch and rifled his trunk of seventeen double[???]s and $270 in Treasury notes. They then departed, having him unconscious, and in that state he was found half an hour subsequently by his wife. This remarkable robbery was committed in a large house which was at the time full of boarders.

abstract: Border Raid; British Circumlocution on
snippet: Border Raid; British Circumlocution on
lead_paragraph: THE BORDER ROBBERIES -- OFFICIAL CORRESPONDENCE. -- The batch of official correspondence relative to the Vermont robberies which we publish to-day, shows how much the roundabout way in which Lord MONCK and his advisers had to reach a decision, at each successive stage of the trial, must have added to the complications. The Governor of the Provinces had no power to take counsel direct from the British Minister at Washington. Official etiquette likewise forbade his corresponding direct with the Foreign Office in London. He was compelled to address himself for advice to his immediate chief in the Colonial Office, Mr. CARDWELL. The latter had then to bring Lord MONCK's appeal before the Cabinet. From the Cabinet, Lord RUSSELL caught the cue, which he transmitted to Mr. CARDWELL, who, in turn, sent it to Lord MONCK. The circumlocution hardly even ended here, for all the while another round of correspondence was going on by a different route, in the shape of news transmitted direct from Quebec to the British Embassy at Washington, thence dispatched to the State Department, by that department copied into dispatches for Mr. ADAMS, who had the reasoning of the case with Lord RUSSELL to attend to.

snippet: Life in Heaven; Greene's, Prof. G. W., American Revolution; Lovers and Thinkers; Loomis, Prof., Treatise on Astronomy; Kavanagh's, Julia, Beatrice
lead_paragraph: -- Life of Marcus T[???]s Cicero. By WILLIAM FORSYTH, Q.C., &c. 2 vols, post 8vo. New-York; CHAS. SCRIBNER & Co. The classic elegance of the "getting up" of these volumes id in fine keeping with the subject, and the interesting nature of their contents. To too many, even of our men who pass for well-informed, C[???] but little more than a name. It is Mr. FORSYTH's o[???] to present him as a man to his fellow-men, in place of the old classical abstraction that we are apt to figure to ourselves when the heroes of antiquity are referred to. We cannot know too much of one who -- either as an orator, a moralist or a statesman -- stands, if not first of all in the very front rank; of one whose influence in his own age, by his deeds, is only exceeded Thy the immense power he exerted over posterity, by his literary works. The biographer of CICERO fortunately possesses in the rich store of his correspondence (a treasure of the ancient world, perfectly unique in character) the means of depicting the public and private life of the Roman Senator in all its strength, as well as in its most private hours of confiding affection and abandon. Mr. FORSYTH has made an excellent use of the materials that he tells us have been the object of his devoted study for many years, and his work has consequently all the spirit and vivacity of contemporary memoirs. Nor is the story of CICERO's life one of private interest merely; it is part and parcel of the grandest history ever recounted to an awe-struck world -- that of the fall of the Republic of Rome. The book is, in its minutest details, most emphatically a gentleman's book, and is sure to find its way to the library tables of all readers of taste and cultivation.

abstract: Texas Braggadocia
snippet: Texas Braggadocia
lead_paragraph: It was amusing to see, just when the rebels in Texas were, for the first time, seriously threatened with attack, how closely they imitated the language of their brethren on this side of the Mississippi, when placed in a similar position. Before the real pressure had begun to bear on the rebels in Virginia and Tennessee, they luxuriated in meetings, resolutions and declarations of unconquerable hate; they swore they would never surrender, while there was a man or musket left. There was a great sea of blood between them and the Yankees, which could not be bridged over. They would never lay down their arms while the breath of the vandals polluted the pure air of the sunny South, and so on. In reading the accounts of the proceedings at the war meetings lately held in Texas, we seem to be carried back once more to those early days of the war, in which every batch of papers that reached us from the rebel States were filled with this sort of stuff. And what was most comical about it all was that the plainer defeat began to stare them in the face, the more evident it became that they would have to submit very soon, the more loudly they swore that they would never submit under any circumstances. The language of the Virginia orators and journalists was never so fierce and determined as during the great meetings in the African Church, held shortly before the fall of Richmond, and when, as is now known, every man of intelligence in it knew that the Confederacy was on its last legs, and that the opening of the Spring campaign would finish it.

abstract: National Academy of Design, North Room
snippet: National Academy of Design, North Room
lead_paragraph: The room of the north and eke of the cast contain several pictures of satisfactory merit. As a rule, too, they are better hung than in the coridor. Human vanity, for which FRANKLIN says we should be thankful, inasmuch as it is the source of much comfort in life, is the same all the world over. He who holds the power of seizing the best place, is generally content to occupy it. Can we blame the academicians for being a little blind to their own imperfections? Why, for instance, should Mr. T. ADDISON RICHARDS be blamed for placing No. 173, "Early Spring," on the line? The picture is a very bad one, and for that reason requires a very good place. Granting this, does it not follow quoad hoc that a better work should be placed to greater disadvantage? What is the use of a prime position if the advantage to be derived therefrom is to be dominated by contiguous, even if exalted talent? No. 174, by J.B. BRISTOL, A., is worthy of its neighbor. We desire to say the same of Nos. 175 and 176, by Miss STROUGITHARM and Mr. WM. BRADFORD. The dull level of mediocrity is well preserved in these four works. Rising slightly superior to it, Mr. A.F. BELLOWS, N.A., in No. 181, gives us a war subject it is called the "Departure of the Regiment." The aged parents of a recruit are assembled in a field, and in the distance a regiment is seen crossing the village bridge. The subject is theatrical, and inaccurate. Regiments did not leave in such wise, although companies may have done so. Even where the latter was the case there was some excitement, and few parents, we opine, would have taken to the woods for the purpose of howling, as these appear to be doing. For the rest, Mr. BELLOWS seems to have studied Mr. A.T. RICHARDS with emulation and success. It were cruel to add another word. No. 183 is by EDWIN WHITE, N.A., a gentleman whose knowledge of color is too admirable to satisfy us with its loss in the trivial subjects which now occupy his brush. This work represents MURILLO in his Sunday clothes painting a beggar boy -- in scarcely any -- who is basking in a gleam of sunshine. The composition is huddled and not interesting. It merely indicates a warm and glowing sense of color -- especially in the grey. What can be said of No. 189, called "Ida," by J.B. STEARNS, N.A.? It represents a child gathering peaches on a step-ladder, and is, we presume, a portrait. As such we shall reserve it for discussion in a future number dedicated especially to this annoying, but inevitable, branch of art.

abstract: The General Assembly of the New-School Presbyterian Church, held their usual session on Saturday, in Brooklyn. The morning was prolonged and no afternoon session was held. The principal business before the Assembly was the reading and consideration of a report from a Special Committee on the State of the Country, read by Dr. FISHER. This document exhausted the subject, and set forth the past conduct of the church and its proposed line of conduct in the future, and claimed that the church must be ready to exercise due vigilance in politics as well as in religion. A memorial was also presented by Dr. SPEARS demanding the right of franchise for the colored man, contending that the freedmen would be necessary to reorganize the South. Both papers were unanimously adopted. The commmittee on overtures reported upon several submitted to them, on the proposed union of the two branches of the church, and upon theatres and card playing. On the first they advised postponing action, and on the others they recommended careful watchfulness among the churches. Pending the consideration of the report of the committee on Church Polity, the assembly adjourned until this morning.

abstract: Effect of Abroad
snippet: Effect of Abroad
lead_paragraph: We shall probably witness, during the coming year, both in France, England and Germany, some very striking and very important results of the contest which has just closed on our soil. The influence upon European politics of the events of the years 1860-1-2 was, as our readers know, very marked. The apparent "breakdown" of democracy in the United States, following as it did close upon the long series of disorders caused by the slavery agitation, satisfied all its enemies that its failure was settled and final, and led even its friends to doubt seriously whether their own expectations of it were not doomed to be seriously disappointed. The divisions at the North, the reverses in the field, furnished the reactionary journals in England, and all over the Continent, with abundant materials for "exposures" and denunciations of popular governments. In England the effects were soon visible in legislation. The movement for an extension of the franchise, which, down to 1860, seemed irresistible, and which every Ministry, whether Whig or Tory, had for fifteen years previously been forced into recognizing and adopting, was definitively abandoned. Even the Liberals confessed, with the most humiliating weakness, that the events in America had demonstrated its danger. Tory orators ranged over the country at will, preaching up the policy of exclusion; Tory books on government enjoyed a success which had been denied them for forty years, and even the Morning Herald began to find itself rising into the novel position of a great political authority.

abstract: There are but few changes to note at the theatres. The season, indeed, is almost over. After a time we shall, of course, have fresh ventures, but for the present the regular managers are expiring with singular meekness. The hardy raiders from the country will have no difficulty in infusing new life and spirit into the various places of amusement all of which will remain open during the hot weather.

abstract: Yellow Fever Plot and Dr. Blackburn
snippet: Yellow Fever Plot and Dr. Blackburn
lead_paragraph: THE YELLOW FEVER CONSPIRATOR. -- BLACKBURN, the yellow fever conspirator, it seems, set out on his mission as a breeder of pestilence by volunteering his services gratuitously to the British Admiralty during the prevalence of the fever at Bermuda. For his labors there, he was highly complimented by Vice-Admiral HOPE in a letter which we publish elsewhere. A reward of 100 sterling was tendered him by the Lords of the Admiralty, and he appears to have enjoyed the repute of a man supremely devoted to charitable and philanthropic enterprise. It is not denied, moreover, that BLACKBURN was an educated man, and had some standing in his profession. The facts altogether point with strong emphasis to the moral and mental debasement to which the principal rebel conspirators, from DAVIS to BLACHBURN, must have sunk, as the hopelessness of their cause began to stare them in the face.

abstract: And Mr. Stanton
snippet: And Mr. Stanton
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERMAN is in greater peril at the present moment than he has been at any time since the war began. He is in danger of seriously impairing the profound respect which his noble devotion to duly throughout the war, has inspired in the breasts of the American people. He cannot blind their eyes to the splendor of his military exploits or chill their glowing gratitude for his transcendant services in crushing the rebellion. But he may add another to the long list of instances which history affords to prove that great military genius is not inseparable from political wisdom and a disinterested devotion to the public good.

abstract: An official dispatch from Secretary STANTON conveys the welcome intelligence that the land and naval forces under command of Gen. KIRBY SMITH have been surrendered to Gen. CANBY. The belligerent power of the rebellion has thus passed away forever, the army of Gen. SMITH having been the only organized force that held out after the surrender of JOHNSTON.

abstract: This steamer arrived at this port this morning from Hatteras Inlet. She put into the Delaware Breakwater on account of a northeast gale, and remained there until the 28th inst. She has been absent over two years, doing duty on the York, James, Appomattox and Pamnnkey Rivers, off Wilmington, and at Beaufort, N.C., as guardship; also for several months past in the sounds of North Carolina, and was in the advance up the James River in May last, and at the battle of Deep Bottom.

abstract: -- The universal acquiescence of the Southern people in the issue of the war is shown in the fact that, though small detachments of our troops are now penetrating all parts of the Southern States, we have not heard of any of them being in any place molested. Shall detachments have gone out and garrisoned various important points in Virginia, and have entered all parts of North Carolina, with perfect freedom. A negro regiment has gone as far as Orangeburgh, in South Carolina, and no [???]e has meddled with them. Steamboats and troops penetrate the Savannah River as high as Augusta, and a few hundred Union soldiers occupy Milledgeville, and the Georgians make no protest. Our steamers and soldiers go up the Alabama River as far as Montgomery and Selma, without molestation. And so it is all over the South. The Southern people have had quite enough of a war in the interests of JEFF. DAVIS and slavery, and are now disposed to be peaceful.

abstract: Acquiescence in Surrender
snippet: Acquiescence in Surrender
lead_paragraph: -- A few days after the surrender of LEE, President LINCOLN intimated, by proclamation, that the rule of certain neutral Powers, by which United States vessels of war were put on a level with pirates, would be at once applied in reprisal by our government to the war vessels of these neutrals visiting United States ports. It takes usually some time to get an idea into an Englishman's head. But in this instance Lord RUSSELL seems to have got at the meaning of this proclamation with uncommonly quick perception. He can only have been studying it five or six weeks, when he issued the order, of which we have the intimation to-day by the European steamer. That order rescinds the offensive regulations to which our vessels were subjected in foreign ports. And it prepares the way for Lord RUSSELL to withdraw the patronage and protection of his government from the only remaining pirate afloat

abstract: The New School Presbyterian General Assembly brought its sessions to a close yesterday afternoon. The day's proceedings were chiefly remarkable for the action taken toward cooperating with sister organizations against the alleged spread of Roman Catholicism, and a committee to that end was appointed. The remainder of the proceedings was necessarily taken up by the customary routine business on closing the assembly preparatory to final adjournment. The closing scenes were very interesting and harmonious. The next General Assembly will be convened at St. Louis on the third Thursday in May, 1866.

abstract: South, the Whole of Quiet
snippet: South, the Whole of Quiet
lead_paragraph: -- The whole South is now profoundly quiet. There is railroad travel from Washington to South Carolina. There is telegraphic communication between Washington and Central Georgia, which will presently be completed to Montgomery and Vicksburgh. The lines of telegraph between Memphis and New-Orleans have been opened, and all the old connections will soon be resumed. Steamers traverse all the rivers of the South, and preparations are everywhere being made for the resumption of business. Before the close of Summer, the commerce and trade of the South will have a great development. Its products, long held back, will find their way to the markets of the world, and the activity of its people and of the North will find a most profitable field.

abstract: Diederichs, R; New-York Merchant
snippet: Diederichs, R; New-York Merchant
lead_paragraph: Mr. ROBERT DEIDERICHS, of Hoboken, a wealthy importer, committed suicide, yesterday afternoon, by shooting himself through the head, at his warehouse, No. 15 South William-street. The cause of this act does not appear. Mr. DEIDERICHS had recently suffered under mental depression, and yesterday, at about noon, he said to one of his clerks that all seemed black and hopeless to him, and almost immediately after making this misanthropic remark he went to a loft of the store, and there, placing the muzzle of a revolver into his mouth, delivered the charge, and fell dead. The explosion was heard in the store below, and suspecting a tragedy, the clerks ascended, and found their employer a corpse. The friends immediately summoned Coroner GOVER, and requested a permit to take the body home, and this was granted. Mr. DEIDERICHS, who was a native of France, was a bachelor of about 50 years of age.

abstract: Our Physical Development of
snippet: Our Physical Development of
lead_paragraph: -- All those who had the fortune to see the review of the Army of the Potomac and the army of SHERMAN in Washington last week, were greatly struck with the superb physical development of the two hundred thousand young men who then marched past the President. Their healthfulness, strength and size, their litheness and vigor, their freedom from superfluous fat and muscle, the firmness of their tread and force of their movement, were very notable. Those ignorant European writers who assert that man in America has physically degenerated would have found their theories completely overthrown by this spectacle. Observers on the spot generally estimated that the Western army averaged somewhat more in height -- say about an inch -- than the Army of the Potomac; but the men of either army were much taller than the French or any other European troops. As for the average age of the troops, Gen. GRANT puts it now, at the close of the war, at about twenty-three years.

abstract: The Belgian at Father Point yesterday brings us intelligence from Europe to the 19th inst. The question of the withdrawal of the recognition of the belligerent rights of the South was brought up in Parliament on the 18th. In the House of Commons Lord PALMERSTON, and in the House of Lords, Earl RUSSELL, made very cool and rather evasive speeches on the question, to the effect that matters must take their own course without any interference from the British Government. When the parties to the great "civil contest" cease to fight, there will be no belligerent rights to acknowledge, is their argument, and they will wait to see what becomes of KIRBY SMITH and his army of Texans. The progress of our arms has, however, compelled the British Government to remove the restrictions placed on our ships of war in British ports. Hereafter they are at liberty to remain as long as they choose, and to purchase whatever supplies they may stand in need of. President JOHNSON's policy is much discussed in the English papers. The news from the Continent is of little importance. Herr VON BISMARCK, the tool of Prussian tyranny and intolerance, has received from the Emperor of the French the cross of the Legion of Honor, for his services in perfecting the customs arrangements between France and the Zollverein. The King of Italy meets with grand receptions on his travels through his dominions.

abstract: Hoboken and Spring-street, Sold by Auction and to be Resold; Festival at Jones' Wood
snippet: Hoboken and Spring-street, Sold by Auction and to be Resold; Festival at Jones' Wood
lead_paragraph: Jones' Wood is an institution. In connection with the squatter interest of the Nineteenth Ward, it has made that section of the city familiar to all lovers of fun and frolic, and is well worth a visit from the curious. The police under that veteran virtuoso, Capt. HART, are kept busy during the Spring, Summer and Fall months in guarding the frequent gatherings which are held there, and when the force is not on duty at the woods watching pretty girls and keeping off rowdies, it finds ample occupation in supervising the goat business at Mackarel Hill, and the squatter community on the rocks beyond. Human nature is the same all the world over, and it is by no means surprising that the newspapers, which so frequently chronicle rows, disturbances and murders in every other quarter of the city, should occasionally find food for a paragraph in the troubles at Jones' Wood.

abstract: Proclamation on Reconstruction, North Carolina
snippet: Proclamation on Reconstruction, North Carolina
lead_paragraph: The President has promptly responded to the reviving spirit of loyalty in North Carolina, by naming Mr. HOLDEN Provisional Governor, by proclaiming liberal terms for the assembling of a convention of citizens prepared and entitled to take the amnesty oath, and by opening wide the door for the early return of the State to her place in the Union. The grand feature, of the President's plan is its simplicity. He imposes no conditions but those of simple obedience to the laws and support of the proclamations of the national government. He leaves the question of suffrage -- without regard to negroes or whites -- to be determined by the convention, or the Legislature constituted and organized by that body.

abstract: FIRE IN WEST TWENTY-FIFTH-STREET. -- At about 1 o'clock yesterday morning a slight fire occurred in the cellar of Mr. FREDERICK NIEWOHNER's grocery, at No. 191 West Twenty-fifth-street; and after it had been extinguished, with trifling damage, the appearances indicating incendiarism, Capt. HEDDON apprehended NIEWOHNER and sent him to Jefferson Market, where Justice DODGE held him to await an investigation by Fire-Marshal BAKER. That officer, however, finding no evidence against the accused to warrant his detention, made the fact known, yesterday afternoon, to the Justice, and thereupon the prisoner was released from restraint. The less by the fire, which is trivial, is covered by $1,000 insurance in the St. Mark's Office.

abstract: Mr. HEYMAN AURBACH, of No. 91 East Broadway, made affidavit that on the 6th of May, one HARRIS COHEN introduced GEORGE BURNETT, alias TAYLOR, and recommended him as a gentleman of wealth; that, relying upon this statement he delivered 18,900 cigars, which he valued at $403, to TAYLOR, at that person's office; No. 213 Fulton-street; that TAYLOR drew a check for that amount, requesting him to present it at the Irving Bank on the next day; that, subsequently, on the day of the sale, COHEN applied to him demanding brokerage; that he promised to pay COHEN when he received the money for the check on the Irving Bank; that COHEN departed and did not return, and that at the time designated, on presenting the check, he learned that TAYLOR's account there amounted to the sum total of the five dollars, precisely. The accused were apprehended by Policeman LINES, of the Tenth Ward, and the Justice, committing TAYLOR without bail, required COHEN to recognize in $500. Of course the cigars were not recovered.

abstract: Washington Club of Williamsburgh, First Annual Regatta
snippet: Washington Club of Williamsburgh, First Annual Regatta
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon the Washington Club of Williamsburgh gave their first annual regatta, for double and single scull races, the course being from the foot of Broadway around a stake boat, about one mile and return. There was quite a large gathering of the boating fraternity present to witness the several contests, and great enthusiasm was exhibited by the parties interested. Mr. H. EGGERS furnished the prizes, the first of which was for seventeen feet working boats, (give and take four inches, two pair sculls.) First prize, $15; second, $2. The entries for this stake were Messrs. W.H. HAYES and BLUE, in boat Chas. B. Elliott, who won easily in twenty-four minutes. Their competitors were Messrs. BRENEGAN and R. ELLIS, boat Marks, who gave up on the last rounding.

abstract: Grievances which led to the Rebellion; "Desperation" Never Existed
snippet: Grievances which led to the Rebellion; "Desperation" Never Existed
lead_paragraph: The want of persistence and pluck displayed by the Southern population in their resistance to the national arms, and the extent to which, in spite of the awful threats and promises by which the conflict was both heralded and accompanied, the real work of the war was left to the regularly organized armies, is probably the best refutation that could possibly be afforded of the theory that the revolted States had any real grievance to complain of.

lead_paragraph: On the 24th instant, the main Ordnance Department, at Mobile, blew up with a terrible explosion. About three hundred persons were instantly killed, and many more wounded, while large numbers were buried in the ruins. Eight entire squares of the city were demolished, and about eight thousand bales of cotton destroyed. The whole city was more or less injured by the explosion, the cause of which was not ascertained.

abstract: WINTER GARDEN. -- The drama of "Camille" was revived at this establishment on Monday evening -- the part of the heroine boing sustained by Miss HOSMER, who is new to our audience. The lady has evidently been disciplined in a good school, and has fully mastered her arduous profession. Her voice is agreeable, her appearance stately, and her manner lady-lilie. In a piece like "Camille," it is hardly possible to display these points to the best advantage; but Miss HosMEit did so Fufficiency to make good her claim to a Metropolitan position, and the lady will, we doubt not, in a more dignified walk of the drama, achieve a marked success. She was well supported by Mr. BARTON HILL, Mr. JOHN DYOTT, and other members of the company.

abstract: The gunboat Hunchback, JOSEPH P. FYERE, Lientenant commanding, from Shorn River, N.C., arrived at this port yesterday. She left New-York in 1861 on her first service; was in the Burnside expedition on Roanoke Island, in which fight she was struk by eight 32-pound shots, which passed completely through her, and also by one 100-pounder, which disabled her engine.
lead_paragraph: The gunboat Hunchback, JOSEPH P. FYERE, Lientenant commanding, from Shorn River, N.C., arrived at this port yesterday. She left New-York in 1861 on her first service; was in the Burnside expedition on Roanoke Island, in which fight she was struck by eight 32-pound shots, which passed completely through her, and also by one 100-pounder, which disabled her engine. She was actively employed in the sounds of North Carolina, participating in every engagement for two years. In October, 1863, she was in the noted Blackwater fight, (the late Capt. FLUSSER being Flag-Officer,) in which she received between eleven and twelve hundred musket balls in the hull. For the past eighteen months she has been doing active service on the James River, and in March last was again ordered to North Carolina. Her officers are:

abstract: The New York Conference of the African M.E. Church, which commenecd its sessions in Zion Church, met again yesterday morning.  The conference embraces upward of 180 churches, principally in New-York and New-Jersey. Superintendent BISHOP presided, and was assisted by Rev. Mr. BROOKS.

abstract: ARREST OF HORSE THIEVES. -- Between 11 and 12 o'clock on Monday night, Officers MANGAN and HOYT, of the Forty-fifth Precinct Police, arrested two suspicious characters in First-street, (E. D.,) named JOHN J. HAYES and JAMES MORAN, on suspicion of having three stolen horses in their possession. Yesterday it was ascertained that the horses had been stolen from Green Point, and were the property of Messrs. LUCIEN M. BROWN, ARCHIBALD and JOHN S. BLISS. The prisoners were held for trial.

abstract: In accordance with the announcement made on Monday, the franchise of the Spring-street Ferry was again put up at public auction yesterday morning. The attendance was small and the bidding was confined as on the day before, to the agent of the Atlantic Mail Steamship Company and J. W. ROBINSON. It was knocked down to the latter for $10,000. The purchaser stated that he would make the requisite deposits of 20 per cent., but as he failed to do so, the franchise was again put up and was knocked down to Mr. JOHN K. DAVIDSON for $5,900. The purchaser is a wealthy resident of the Eleventh Ward, and, it is stated, will set the ferry in operation immediately.
lead_paragraph: In accordance with the announcement made on Monday, the franchise of the Spring-street Ferry was again put up at public auction yesterday morning. abstract: The Feast of Pentecost commenced last evening, special services held in all the synagogues of this city. The feast continues for two days, Wednesday and Thursday, during which time the Jewish places of worship will be decorated with flowers, and floral tributes will be presented before the ark enshrining the scrolls of the law. This festival was instituted, says Dr. RAPHALL, in his book on The Festivals of the Lord, to commemorate the declaration of the law on Mount Sinai which "constituted the Israelites a nation,and appointed them the peculiar and chosen people of God."
lead_paragraph: The Feast of Pentecost commenced last evening, special services held in all the synagogues of this city. The feast continues for two days, Wednesday and Thursday, during which time the Jewish places of worship will be decorated with flowers, and floral tributes will be presented before the ark enshrining the scrolls of the law. This festival was instituted, says Dr. RAPHALL, in his book on The Festivals of the Lord, to commemorate the declaration of the law on Mount Sinai which "constituted the Israelites a nation,and appointed them the peculiar and chosen people of God."

abstract: Now that the war is absolutely at an end, we begin to think of the rapidity of its conclusion. Six months ago the Confederacy held half of Virginia, both Carolinas, half of Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississsippi, and the greater part of the Trans-Mississippi territory in its grasp. It had a seacoast line, and cruisers ran the blockade with European products.
