abstract: Fifty thousand people constitute a great crowd, and if united in any cause must make themselves felt sooner or later. To the Workmen's Union there is a membership, we are informed, varying but little from this vast number. Not quite a year ago some fifty or sixty protective associations joined themselves together, forming what has since been known as the "Union." Distinct in minor forms and policies, these several bodies were united in the one single purpose of elevating, socially and otherwise, the workmen and women of these vast cities. abstract: The slavery question in Kentucky is likely to be practically if not legally settled by the disappearance of the contraband altogether. Tens of thousands have gone to other States, and of those who are left the greater portion of ablebodied men are enlisting in our armies. By such enlistment their families become free. So it is not improbable that if the white citizens of Kentucky should resolve -- in their coming election -to hold on to the odoriferous carcase of a dead institution, they will be able to count only decrepid and used-up old paupers for their gains. And it will serve them right.

abstract: BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. -- The Board of Aldermen, at a meeting Monday night, added $3,000 to the appropriation of a similar amount heretofore authorized, to be expended for celebrating the approaching anniversary of our national independence, making in all $6,000. A portion of this sum is to be devoted to the reception of Brooklyn soldiers who have returned from the war. Considerable routine business was done and the report of the Committee on Returning the Streets was consequently laid over to be acted upon at a special meeting on Wednesday evening.
lead_paragraph: BROOKLYN COMMON COUNCIL. -- The Board of Aldermen, at a meeting Monday night, added $3,000 to the appropriation of a similar amount heretofore authorized, to be expended for celebrating the approaching anniversary of our national independence, making in all $6,000. A portion of this sum is to be devoted to the reception of Brooklyn soldiers who have returned from the war. Considerable routine business was done and the report of the Committee on Returning the Streets was consequently laid over to be acted upon at a special meeting on Wednesday evening.

abstract: Yesterday, at 12 M., the United States screw steamers Flag, Kensington, Vicksburgh, Proteus, barkentine Horace [???], and schooner Rachel Seaman, were to be sold at public auction at the Brooklyn Navy-Yard. Quite a number of merchants were present, but there did not seem to be much disposition to buy the heavier crai't -- vessels which should bring $75,000 or $100,000. The Horace Beals find the Rachel Seaman were sold, the former bringing $11,000, and the latter $13,500, twenty per cent. of the purchase money to be paid on the day of the sale, and the remainder before the vessels leave the yard, which will be within six days after the date of the sale. The Horace Beals, 269 tons, was purchased by the government in 1862, for $16,000: was at Vicksburgh, and engaged in blockading and other duties since, on the Atlantic coast. The Rachel Seaman, 303 tons, is also a purchased vessel. She was bought in 1861 for $18,000. She is 114 feet long, 30 feet wide and 9 feet deep. She was engaged at Sabine Pass, Texas, and has done a great deal of service as a supply and tranport steamer. The Glaucus arrived at the yard yesterday, and will be another vessel added to the list of those to be sold at public auction.

abstract: President JOHNSON has well done a very difficult piece of work. An amnesty of some sortwas a necessity. Statutory punishment of all who have committed treason, would bring to death nearly every man and woman in the South, for nearly all have either "levied war" against the United States, or given those who did so, "aid and comfort." A universal amnesty, on the other hand, would have been a full absolution of the greatest crime of the age, and the greatest of all injuries to the authority and majesty of law. The amnesty must needs be only partial. Its limits had to be fixed with reference to two objects: First, security for the future; second, equity.
lead_paragraph: President JOHNSON has well done a very difficult piece of work. An amnesty of some sortwas a necessity. Statutory punishment of all who have committed treason, would bring to death nearly every man and woman in the South, for nearly all have either "levied war" against the United States, or given those who did so, "aid and comfort." A universal amnesty, on the other hand, would have been a full absolution of the greatest crime of the age, and the greatest of all injuries to the authority and majesty of law. The amnesty must needs be only partial. Its limits had to be fixed with reference to two objects: First, security for the future; second, equity.

abstract: INTERESTING PARTY IN THE EIGHTH WARD POLICE STATION. -- Between 12 and 1 o'clock yesterday morning Capt. MILLS sent out a squad of men in civilian attire, with orders to apprehend all street-walkers whom they might find on Mercer, Spring and Wooster streets, between Broome-street and Bleecker, and within half an hour the officers returned with 18 females, of from 16 to 30 years of age, and of various experience in their peculiar calling. Nearly every prisoner rendered a fictitious name, and two, in derision, stated their age as 65 and 75 years respectively. The Eighth Ward Police Station was a bedlam indeed until sunrise; some of the prisoners killing time by singing, others by objurgation, and others by bewailing their unhappy fate.
